text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Madam President, we obviously have to be hopeful that the parliamentary process in the UK will lead to an outcome conducive to an orderly withdrawal and we have to be as supportive of this process as possible. Should this positive scenario indeed materialise, then we have to realise that the agreement reached on 25 November was just the first step in a long process. We will have to keep the implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement under close watch so that it delivers in the interest of citizens and businesses. The negotiations on the future relationship are unlikely to be easy.  We will therefore count on your cooperation at all the stages of these processes in the years to come. Thank you very much once again for your attention.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. (The sitting was suspended for a few moments) Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Birgit Collin-Langen (PPE)
text: Writing. The situation in the United Kingdom is extremely worrying. It is clear to us that the withdrawal agreement will not be renegotiated. We must now wait and see what course the British Government takes. We need a clear position from London. The stakes are too high. I hope that an unregulated Brexit can be averted, because the damage that such a break will cause will be devastating for our and the British economy.

name: Tanja Fajon (S&D)
text: Writing. – The British Parliament has made it clear that it does not want an agreement that the British Prime Minister has agreed to deal with the EU. He also said he doesn't want a hard exit, but he's more likely today than ever. Last night's vote was a major defeat for the British prime minister. But it is time for Britain to finally communicate what it really wants. I am convinced that Brexit is hurting everyone. I regret last night's rejection of the deal, but dramatising is not necessary. There's a lot of uncertainty in the air right now. An early election is possible, a new referendum is possible, but the decision is on the part of the British people. Leaving the UK is the worst-case scenario we must try to avoid. The uncertainty that both citizens in the EU and the economy would fall into is too great and too risky. The Socialists and Democrats in the EP are sending a stark warning to the Member States that we will not be prepared to weaken the agreements already reached in the negotiations with Great Britain. If Otok requests an extension of the exit, which could lead to a more ambitious agreement, then we should not oppose it in Slovenia either.

name: João Ferreira (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – The sovereign decision of the British people to leave the UK from the EU must be fully respected. With this assumption, manoeuvres, pressures, threats or blackmails should be rejected, in particular by the EU, which aim to defraud, misrepresent or even reverse it. What reality shows in the UK and more is a deep sense of rejection of EU policies, which attack the rights and aspirations of workers and peoples, who promote the concentration of wealth at the expense of impoverishment, which disrespect national sovereignty and the right to development of various countries. It is possible to build another Europe of cooperation between sovereign states, on the basis of mutual respect, equal rights, cooperation, solidarity, mutual development, social progress and peace.  In the present framework, the Portuguese Government must intervene resolutely, either with the UK authorities or in the EU, to ensure the protection of the rights of Portuguese citizens working and living in that country. It must also take the necessary initiatives to promote the conditions for the development of mutually beneficial bilateral relations between Portugal and the United Kingdom, within the framework of respect for the sovereignty of each country and the rights and aspirations of the Portuguese people and the British people.

name: Danuta Jazłowiecka (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. "Over the past two years, we've seen more twists and turns than in many good sensational films. We should be concerned that, a few dozen days before the official withdrawal date, it is not known whether this will be on the basis of a negotiated agreement or whether it will be a so-called hard Brexit. It is not even certain whether the United Kingdom will actually leave the Community. Any option is likely. We should not be pleased with this, as uncertainty is growing among ordinary people and entrepreneurs. Eu citizens living in the UK and Britons settled on the continent cannot be sure what status they will have in two months. Micro, small and medium-sized enterprises are unable to plan for the next six months, and many of them will have to close down due to this uncertainty. We do not have to look far for concrete examples of uncertainty. In the European Parliament itself, British officials and assistants do not know whether they will be able to benefit from unemployment benefits or pension rights after Brexit and when they return home. This is unacceptable!!! From the point of view of ordinary people, this must be ended. As the European Parliament, we should call loudly and firmly on the House of Commons to decide immediately on future action, including the possibility of another referendum.

name: Светослав Христов Малинов (PPE)
text: in writing. – The British political elite, all together, slowly and gradually pushed the boat towards the collision. For two years we've been watching it as a slow-motion catastrophe and there's nothing we can do because the signals from the UK were the most divergent and we can't take sides. Theresa May does not have a majority in the British parliament on Brexit issues. The worst option is to leave without an agreement. What is best for European citizens now is postponing Brexit and extending the deadline after 29 March 2019. The next few weeks will be key.

name: Urmas Paet (ALDE)
text: Writing. - Now that the UK Parliament has rejected the withdrawal agreement and the political declaration, the UK Government and Parliament need to let the EU know what kind of relationship they want with the EU. The withdrawal deal is the best and only possible compromise within the "red lines" set by the UK. This will create legal certainty where Brexit creates uncertainty. The EU does not accept the amendment of the guidelines on the peace process and the border on the Island of Ireland or citizens' rights. In the UK, a cross-party agreement is needed to achieve a majority, both to resolve the impasse and to possibly reshape the "red lines."

name: Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón
text: in writing. – The impasse that faces both the EU and the UK results from the deeply flawed method by which the Brexit negotiations have been conducted. These have been designed in two sequences: first to establish the conditions for an orderly withdrawal; then those of a future relationship. Aggravated by huge political fractures on the British side, and the steely determination to maintain unity on the EU side, this approach has been driving both sides towards a brick wall. A divorce process can only be well managed if not just the terms for a separation but also those of any alternative future relationship are mapped out. The two sets of terms are interdependent, as is shown by the ongoing controversies within the British political system regarding whether Brexit should be hard or soft. The UK should have been asked first to clear as a matter of principle and policy what future relationship it sought. The EU should have indicated what relationship it found acceptable. Agreement would have been sought on this. Negotiations would then have been about proceeding from a status of full membership to that of the proposed new relationship. Instead, another episode is being played in a soap opera that frankly has become rather dreary.

name: Kārlis Šadurskis (PPE)
text: Writing. – To say just 'no' is very easy. It is more difficult to offer a solution. Now that the British Parliament has voted against the agreement proposed by the Government, it would only be logical for parliament to take one of the two possible paths: to offer a new constructive solution or to ask British citizens in a referendum whether they support a Brexit that the government has achieved in the negotiations with the EU. The worst solution would be Britain's withdrawal from the EU without an agreement. While it would be most painy to feel the British themselves the next day – because, for example, a large proportion of medicines and food products come from other EU Member States – the status of EU citizens in Britain and securing their rights would also be unclear. At the same time, I would also like to point out the continuation of other projects, which have gained less publicity but are extremely important, whose viability could be jeopardised by a free Brexit. I am concerned about the status of Latvian students in the UK and the fate of various research programmes involving scientists from both the Latvian, EU and British. For cooperation in the various education and science programmes to continue after Britain leaves the EU, an agreement is absolutely necessary.

name: Henna Virkkunen (PPE)
text: Written. "Unfortunately, the UK's withdrawal from the EU does not seem to be clarifying, but is becoming increasingly chaotic. Yesterday's vote in the British Parliament was not a surprise in itself. The withdrawal agreement negotiated by Prime Minister May collapsed with clear figures (432–202). This means that the means to secure a controlled separation are running low. The risk of a no-deal brexit increases. Britain's departure from the EU is just over two months away. It is not realistic to start new negotiations, knowing that the agreement that has now been rejected was negotiated for 18 months. Nor do we need to open the agreement. The withdrawal agreement, which was rejected by the British Parliament, would have covered the three main objectives that the EU Parliament wanted to secure. The agreement would have safeguarded the rights of EU citizens living in the UK and agreed on the UK's payment obligations to the EU, and there would have been no hard border between the Republic of Ireland and Northern Ireland. The most important contribution to the agreement would have been the transition period for withdrawal until the end of 2020, during which the UK would have complied with all EU laws and paid membership fees, but would not have been involved in the decision-making process. When, according to the initial main lines, Britain would like to be involved in almost all activities in the future, the question arises as to why then resign. It is clear that Britain outside the EU cannot get a better deal than as a member. It is to be hoped that all this chaos in Britain will lead to yet another referendum. That would be fair. Now the public has a better idea of what separation really means. Britain's withdrawal is a great tragedy and shows what can happen when populism gets too far. This is particularly unfortunate for young people who would have liked to remain in the Union.

name: El presidente. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate with the President of the Spanish Government, Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón, on the future of Europe (2018/2748(RSP)). Mr Prime Minister of Spain, thank you for accepting the European Parliament's invitation to speak with us, with Members, about Spain's position on Europe. Today is a politically very important day, because we have the problem of Brexit; but it is also important for us to talk about the most important dossiers in the Union: immigration. The European Parliament voted in favour of reforming the Dublin system. We asked the Council, the Member States, to vote in favour of our proposal, to conclude a very long debate on refugees, on the relocation of refugees. We also have the budget problem. Parliament is calling for more investment, from 1.1 to 1.3. We believe that money can be added without asking member states, but with own resources. That's why the debate is open. It is a proposal for the reform of Parliament's Europe, a proposal on the European Parliament's investments. It is important for us to defend Parliament's position as the heart of European democracy. There is here, in the European Parliament, an exhibition by the EFE Agency on the occasion of the 40th anniversary of the Spanish Constitution, a country which is also very important for the European Parliament. I would like to thank and greet the presence of the Minister for Foreign Affairs of the Kingdom of Spain, Mr Borrell, who was President of this House. Thank you for being with us. (Applause) Mr Prime Minister, President of the Government of Spain, thank you for being with us, for accepting the invitation. Now you have the floor.

name: Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón
text: President of the Government of Spain. – Mr President of the European Parliament, Mr Vice-President of the European Commission, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, it is an honour, a real honour to address all of you in bringing Spain's vision to the exciting debate on the future of the European Union.  And I say "exciting" with all conviction and from one's life experience. In 1985, when Spain's act of accession to the then European Economic Community was signed, I was 13 years old. And, despite the time elapsed, I remember clearly that day.  I remember the emotion felt by those who had suffered for decades the absence of democracy and freedoms in my country, in Spain.  I remember the emotion in a whole generation of Spaniards, that of my parents; men and women for whom Europe meant, during many years of dictatorship, freedom and the rule of law, progress and cohesion.  That moment represented many things for Spain, above all it represented the guarantee that there would no longer be going back; that, at last, we were at peace with our history; that at last no one would ever, ever take democracy back from our country.  (Applause) Since then, later generations of Spaniards—my own—have seen the inner borders turned into relics of history and built solidarity and affections with once distant peoples. Always from respect for the values we identify today as European: legal certainty, respect for the social and democratic state of law, dialogue and tolerance, feminism and equal opportunities, fraternity and coexistence, environmentalism and intergenerational solidarity.  So, yes: you can consider me a passionate Europeanist. Proud of what this attribute represents and, precisely, proud now, when some use anti-Europeanism as an alleged electoral asset.  Thank you, President Tajani, for giving me the opportunity to address this Parliament. Putting it at the heart of this debate seems to me to be a great success, precisely when we are going to celebrate the 40th anniversary of the first European elections. The Union is not understood without the primacy of democratic values.  Ladies and gentlemen, first of all, I would like to mention yesterday's vote in the British Parliament.  I respect — as it cannot be otherwise, as President of the Government of a Member State — but I can only regret the negative rejection of the UK withdrawal agreement from the European Union.  An agreement which has been negotiated for more than a year and a half and which, moreover, I would like to acknowledge in the figure of the chief negotiator, Michel Barnier, the extraordinary work he has done in maintaining the unity of the 27 Member States. As I said, an agreement that has been negotiated for a year and a half, and which I think is the best possible deal. It is the option that better protects the interests of the United Kingdom and also of all the Member States of the Union and, therefore, of European society. It is the option that protects not only the rights of its citizens, but also the rights of the main economic operators.  An agreement, therefore, which contains a balance of concessions which is very difficult to reach and which seeks, first and foremos say, an orderly exit.  In this regard, it is for the United Kingdom Government to adapt or take the decisions it deems appropriate on the steps to be taken. We are, as Member States and also as Community institutions, doing our job; adopting, both the Member States and the European Commission, the necessary measures to minimise the impact of a possible exit without agreement.  Ladies and gentlemen, I have always expressed my opinion, both in the Spanish Parliament and also in successive and different interviews with the media, that Brexit is a disgrace to the British people and also to the whole of the European Union. No one wins; we all lose, especially the British and, in particular, those who need their government the most, those who are the most vulnerable.  But it is a sovereign decision which we can only respect and, therefore, I want the United Kingdom to choose to maintain as close a relationship as possible with the European Union as a whole. The decision rests with them, but our principles are clear: the integrity of the internal market, the indivisibility of the four freedoms and the autonomy of the Union's decision.  Within the framework of these three points we will always find ourselves.  Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to speak to you about the need to mobilisation Europe.  I would like to talk to you about the need to relegate Europe to new challenges, but also to those who want the destruction of Europe. Let's be clear: there are, inside and outside, important actors who they want the destruction of the Union.  As leader of the Social Democratic family, I know that you expect me to talk about social Europe, the Europe I am covering; and I'm going to do it, because I think social Europe is the Europe of convictions.  However, precisely because of this moral conviction and because it is necessary to reconcile the idea of Europe with what is expected of it by the public, if you ask me what the central idea is in my speech, it is a much broader appeal. It is very simple, it is summed up in one sentence: for Europe to protect, it is up to us, right now, in this historical time, to protect Europe. Protecting Europe is building a Europe of rights that protects the most vulnerable.  (Applause) It is to promote a Europe of opportunity for our young people and also for the long-term unemployed , who must not necessarily be 60 years old, but, in countries like mine, are 45 years old and are suffering from long-term unemployment; is to move towards a social Europe that strengthens our business fabric and our industrial fabric, but also to safeguard labour rights from the precariousness that floods the labour markets of each and every Member State of the Union.  Protecting Europe is to ensure the safety and defence of our fellow citizens by making the Union a global player, capable of defending its values and ideals.  To protect Europe is to reaffirm our commitment to the Paris Agreements, in the fight against climate change. It is also the culmination, once and for all, of economic and monetary union.  Only in this way, with a Europe that reconciles itself with citizenship, with an autonomous Europe to defend its model of welfare status, with a Europe that completes economic and monetary architecture, will we be able to address the challenges that will mark the coming decades with sufficient guarantees.  So this is no time to hesitate. To Europe's enemies I say that our conviction and determination will overcome authoritarianism. As harsh as it is the exclusionary rhetoric of some, however questionable their methods and lies are logically, it is time to show conviction and determination in defending our common project which is Europe.  Today a real battle is taking on the field of ideas. This is a scenario in which this battle is surely also unfolding, as in each and every national parliament: involution in the face of progress.  We know that the future was never conquered by taking steps backwards and, therefore, we cannot go back a millimeter in defending the European model. Europe protects whether each and every one of us who feels concerned — not only the Member States, not just the European Parliament and the national parliaments, not just civil society, but all of the citizens — protects Europe.  To those who also extend messages of retreat from this rostrum, I say that Europe is and will never be a threat to the extraordinary diversity of our countries, of our languages, of our cultures.  Europe is quite the opposite. Europe is multiplication, never the division of identities. You're no less Spanish because you're European, on the contrary.  The European Union was never and will never be a mere geographical expression, it is what unites us. It was, is and will always be a community of values, the values of the French Revolution: freedom, equality, fraternity — so important in our day – values that are typical of open and optimistic societies, those that innovate and those that believe, because they see the future as an opportunity and never as a threat. Societies that link necessary competitiveness and economic development with something fundamental that defines us as European, such as social cohesion and our welfare model.  This commitment like the one that unites us in the Sustainable Development Goals of the 2030 Agenda, which is a real global contract of the next decade, which must find in Europe its main activist and ambassador. Ladies and gentlemen, it is clear that there is social unsenchantment in the context of globalisation. We live it in each and every street, the villages, the squares of our cities throughout the continent. Disenchantment that feeds ultra rhetoric and is born of a great paradox: on the one hand, globalization has redistributed wealth between regions of the planet and, consequently, has reduced global inequality; but, on the other hand, it increases inequality in this or within our own societies.  And in short, if we think about it, the rise of anti-European messages owes much to this latter phenomenon. However, globalization is not a natural catastrophe for which we must be helpless. Goethe said parents should give their children "roots and wings." Similarly, the European Union must provide their citizens with "roots"—that is, an anchor, protection, protection—and "wings"—ultimately empowering them—so that they can thrive from opportunities in a global world.  We are, ladies and gentlemen, facing a change of time, and on 26 May it will open a new political cycle in Europe. And the priority must therefore focus on regulating globalisation to ensure the validity of the European social model.  We must consolidate the foundations of economic and monetary union, complementing it with the indispensable basis of a political, social and , I would also like to add, environmental union.  A decade after its inception, many of our fellow citizens still suffer the consequences of the Great Recession in the form of wage inequality, social exclusion, precariousness, pay drop. A crisis that unfairly associated Europe's idea with austerity. To austerity, by the way, of those who were always austere out of necessity, in front of those who were never austere and were behind the responsibility of the financial crisis that affected and hit all European societies. (Applause)  The consequence was inequality and, in particular, intergenerational inequality, the inequality that young people suffer on our continent. And, of course, gender inequality, because women are the ones who are suffering with the greatest impact and intensity the precariousness and inequality in the workplace. Therefore, inequality, precariousness and the weakening of the welfare state.  This account, it must be acknowledged, divided societies, but it also divided us, as a Union: it divided countries between north and south between east and west, between creditor countries and debtors. So it's time to close that stage and relegate Europe where it's most needed, which is among the citizens.  And to achieve this, we must vindicate social Europe, the Europe of rights. Social and territorial cohesion is an essential pillar and, I would say, unique in the world of European societies. In order to regain legitimacy, the Union must promote a new social contract; make globalisation, under European protection, a source of opportunity and not just a source of threats.  It is essential to strengthen social cohesion, with clear and measurable objectives for employment, for social justice and also for the sustainability of our welfare state. We must strengthen this perspective in European economic coordination procedures and also in cohesion policy.  That is, and not another, ladies and gentlemen, the philosophy of the proposal advocated by the Government of Spain within the European Council, such as the creation of European unemployment insurance — a genuine backstop for people — from which to give content to such important concepts, for those of us who believe in the Union, such as solidarity and as European citizenship is. A path that we must actively promote and in parallel with the culmination of economic and monetary union.  And, in the same line, it is imperative to complete the task entrusted to us by European trade unions — the Directive on the reconciliation of personal and work life and also that relating to transparent and predictable working conditions throughout the European Union — and to ensure that all persons, regardless of their race of sex or age, , have access to free work —worthy, rather —on our continent.  The Union must be present in the fight against occupational precariousness. Uncertainty at work implies vital uncertainty, and we cannot allow the idea that young people on our continent are destined to live worse than the previous generation. It is paramount at this point – and this is the position of the Government of Spain – to bet on the Youth Guarantee.  Ladies and gentlemen, seven months ago Spain formed the Government with the most women from the OECD. It is a milestone on the path of real and effective equality between men and women, which still has a long way to go.  (Applause) A path we could never have walked without the impetus and without the example and inspiration of Europe. So today, in this house, I would like to thank the commitment of women, mePs across the continent, to the ideal that is already part of the European acquis, such as feminism.  In the cause of gender equality, what I can guarantee you is that Spain is not going to take any steps back; we'll keep taking steps forward. But we also need the competition from Europe.  That is why today I would like to propose the adoption of a european Union gender equality strategy on a binding basis, a strategy to combat the gender gap, the higher unemployment rate faced by women and the precariousness it suffers with particular intensity of women. May the voice of Europe lead this struggle in what is already the 21st century of women. (Applause) We must, ladies and gentlemen, make progress in binding on the principles of the European Pillar of Social Rights, on equal opportunities in access to the labour market and on fair working conditions, as well as in protection and social inclusion. I therefore reiterate my support for the Regulation on the European Labour Authority to ensure the rights of workers in the labour market.  Europe must be able to expand equal opportunities and ensure access to all studies, including those of high improvement. In culture, in science, in research, we will all agree that we have a fundamental strong point against those who want to destroy the European dream. Ladies and gentlemen, in order to ensure the safety of our citizens and to strengthen our role in the world, as a genuine global player, decisive progress is needed, with determination, in the Europe of security and defence. Just over a year ago we launched Permanent Structured Cooperation. We are taking the first steps to building our own capabilities in the field of defense after decades of paralysis. And now is the time to do it with a decision. To move forward, openly, in the creation of a true European army. The Union, ladies and gentlemen, has to show the world that it is a soft power — if I may say so — by choice, not by weakness. For conviction. The ability to project forces together, beyond our borders, and the political will to do so, are fundamental conditions for being a credible power on the international board. The Union is undoubtedly an attractive model for the world in many respects. A lot of times we forget, but we do. It is precisely the union that allows us to aspire to a leadership role at the global level. We represent the possibilities of a multilateral order, which is now being challenged by very important international forces; a multilateral order based on law and commonly accepted rules.  Spain I want to tell you that you are ready to contribute to this leadership. Providing. And contributing decisively, thanks to our privileged relationship with Latin America, with North Africa and with the Middle East. But, however, in the face of major global challenges, Europe's weight is much lower than in other areas, where the Union has exclusive competence. And in this sense, I would like to make some reflection. We have to become a true global player. We're not today. And to do so it is necessary to eliminate the rule of unanimity; not only on foreign policy, but also on such important issues as taxation, the multiannual budget and the mechanism for verifying respect for the rule of law and human rights. (Applause) Protecting Europe is, today more than ever, providing it with tools that need to be necessarily agile in decision-making. To bet, in short, on a new sovereignty, which is the sovereignty that you represent, which is neither more nor less as important as European sovereignty. Thirdly, ladies and gentlemen, we must complete the architecture of the single currency and move forward in the Multiannual Financial Framework. Fifty years ago, in The Hague, the heads of state and government of the then European Economic Community opened the way for economic and monetary union. And there is a paradox that the final year of each decade was always marked by substantive progress in this area. Note: – In 1969, the Hague Summit, to which it referred earlier; – In 1979, the adoption of the European Monetary System; – In 1989, the Delors Plan to Achieve Economic and Monetary Union; – And in 1999, the official implementation of the euro. Between the latter date, 1999, and the year we just premiered, 2019, there is only one striking gap in this almost perfect sequence, which is 2009, when the international financial crisis revealed the shortcomings of our unique currency architecture.  So nothing better illustrates the impact of the crisis than this broken cadence. So, let's make this 2019 a definitely year to move forward. The euro, in my view, despite the difficulties it has logically entailed, especially at times as difficult as those of the decade of the crisis, is a success story that brings economic and political benefits to the European project. But without the reforms needed to strengthen our single currency, economic union will remain incomplete and exposed to instability. It's not just about strengthening the financial system through a banking union in the three fundamental and mutualized pillars — that's clearly, you know this and have defended it—but also to undertake, in the medium term, closer fiscal integration. With stabilization tools to mitigate adverse effects on economic activity and employment in the face of future crises. To relegate Europe in this area to me seems to be key. It's critical. And to do so, citizens must feel the protagonists of these reforms, they must feel at the heart of these reforms: protect their savings, protect them from inflation, or protect them and protect them when there is economic crisis and unemployment. A common currency is a key pillar in a shared political project such as the European Union. Reform of Economic and Monetary Union must ensure that social protection and inclusion are present from the very conception of our common economic policies. The time is this. Moreover, this is when economic conditions remain favourable. Let it be the policy that, for once, anticipates events. Let these not be the ones to redial the European Union's agenda. We must complete the structure of the euro before the next crisis weakens our currency and our Union. Let us learn from recent experience and move forward with decision; we can't afford the price we know the inaction would have. For institutions, but above all for those we represent in this forum and in many other institutions, at the national level. And look, with regard to the new Multiannual Financial Framework, we face new challenges to be addressed. But we must also consolidate strategic initiatives, such as the common agricultural policy or cohesion policies, which are as important to countries as Spain; urban Europe cannot be neglected from rural Europe, if I may have the synthesis of this reflection. Reducing the budget means accepting the idea that Europe is withdrawing from a backward Europe. So, let's also think about who benefits from such messages. The Commission's proposal, in the view of the Government of Spain, contains positive, very positive elements, such as the level of expenditure, the external dimension of migration policy, to which I will subsequently refer, or the strengthening of innovation and technological development programmes. Europe needs to be sovereign in innovation, and reduce its reliance on artificial intelligence, quantum computing, cybersecurity and automation. Only by pooling our capabilities and resources can we compete with guarantees. And so the proposal to double the Erasmus programme funds is particularly timely, and of course the Government of Spain supports it. But progress is also needed on other lines. There must be a European response to phenomena that we believed to be banished in our societies, and which are growing at the cost of rising inequality, such as child poverty. The Europe of Opportunity has been starting, ladies and gentlemen, from childhood. That is why I would like to expressly support, as President of the Government of Spain, the need to promote a child guarantee to tackle the earliest social exclusion. (Applause) Ladies and gentlemen, the proposal we have - even with shortcomings in this area - is a good starting point. But it's time to take a leap forward. Our Union is worth much more, it weighs much more than 1% of europe's gross national product. So, prudence in spending, rationality in spending and ability to address the priorities arising from the transnational challenges we face. We all win with a reasonable, forward-looking Union budget, creator of synergies and economies of scale. To protect Europe is to move forward, as I said, in social Europe, in defence Europe and economic and monetary union. A Europe, in short, federal, which is re-edituted if it regains the favor of its citizenship; who needs to confront the story of distance with measures that make it a close reality; and that finds its north, its guide, in the values that identify it. Ladies and gentlemen, I would like to return to this idea by addressing the last vector of my speech, which alludes to climate change and migration challenges. In both frameworks, I want to appeal to clearly and purely European values. And to do so from a sincere will to reach consensus, beyond ideological boundaries; consensuses that unsern those who benefit most from the division of those of us here. These matters are the chosen battlefield, if we think about it, by those who neither believe nor believe in Europe. They are the conceptual framework from which they seek to undermine the foundations of liberal democracy.  This is where, again, I invoke the need to protect Europe. To preserve, to defend our European model, but also to our European values. In climate change, recent international forums show the advancement of skeptical, resigned, or even belligerent positions. Our perspective in this area must combine global commitment and future opportunity. The energy transition can and should be a vector of modernization and opportunity creation in our countries. But also cohesion, with the boost of energy interconnections to improve our efficiency and reduce emissions. The consequences of this challenge are devastating. You have certainly discussed it on many occasions within this forum. The very entity of this challenge reaffirms to us the validity of political union. Because neither authoritarianism nor exclusionary nationalism can deny evidence that borders can do nothing against this climate change challenge. That's why they militate in irrational denialism. Climate change is being combated from reason and from science. And they're both on our side. On the side of a Europe whose voice is essential in the face of the retreat of very important actors from the international stage. And in similar terms I would also like to refer to the second area to which I referred earlier, which is that of the migration issue. We are talking about a subject, ladies and gentlemen, in which joint and coordinated action, in collaboration with the countries of origin, transit and destination, is essential. For Spain, this perspective is crucial. Especially from our status as the Union's external border. From that point of view, we are very mindd at the key role played by countries very important to the whole european continent, but also to Spain, as is the Kingdom of Morocco in this area in terms of cooperation and control. A role that I would like to highlight expressly in this House. We need to drive a parallel global approach in this area. The Marrakesh Conference represents or represented a first step towards multilateral management of the migration issue, and Spain is, unfortunately with very few European countries, one of the signatories to this global pact. I know very well, as you all know, of the dividing potential of this debate in our societies. But we cannot start from a negative approach to the migration issue, focused exclusively on irregular migration. Regular migration has positive implications for our economic development; plays an essential role in labour-deficit sectors and helps alleviate one of the challenges we have on our continent, such as population ageing. But there is no possible response to this challenge without a commitment to a continent, to Africa, which needs a profound socio-economic transformation. This medium- and long-term political route must pass in parallel with border control, which is an obligation of each and every Member State. A single area, without external borders, requires a joint migration policy, in which the reform of the Common European Asylum System is at the heart. We need rules adapted to today's reality and two principles must guide this reform, such as the principles of responsibility and solidarity. May the complexity of the negotiations not make us lose sight of the original meaning of this reform when it was proposed: to fulfill our duties — derived from international conventions for the protection of human rights — towards people fleeing persecution, war and conflict. The prestige of Europe, ladies and gentlemen, is questioned when attitudes contrary to the most essential humanity emerge within us. Being supportive and empathizing with others also helps us to be with ourselves. Europe is not following fashions, ladies and gentlemen. Europe, with its democratic acquis, is the one that creates trends. That's where our fortress lies. Ladies and gentlemen, our division, here in the Union, is our greatest weakness. Only those who, as I said at the beginning of my speech, seek failure, bankruptcy and defeat of our model benefit from it. A model that crystallizes in a triangle in my virtuous judgment, and that is unique in the world: democracy, economic progress and welfare status. Overcoming our divisions requires mutual understanding and fighting stereotypes. In May of this year, we faced a crucial test. We are faced with those who are sending a message already known on this continent, ladies and gentlemen. A message that sowed this land with ashes decades ago, not many ago. Also then many found this rhetoric and gestures harmless. Peace, democracy and freedom can never be taken for granted. I saw it with my own eyes in the late 1990s in Bosnia, working for the United Nations in a city devastated by the civil war and hatred. En Sarajevo. Barbarism, which we believed to be banished from the history of this continent, was present when no one expected it. Fed by forces that always put hatred before reason and coexistence. The strength of these forces not only threatens our integration project. It also subtly conditions — and I would also like to ask all of you – the agenda of actors in principle contrary to them. Today, I ask in this House that no Europeanist should be dragged by these forces. I turn to all of you to ask you to remain firm in defending European values; and strength to resist the siren songs of authoritarianism. Because they are only pursuing one goal, which is to destroy Europe. That is why today I appeal to the need to protect Europe, for Europe to protect its citizens, Europeans. Over the next few years, I am convinced that our common project, despite the difficulties, will continue to move forward. There will be divergences, of course, there will be setbacks, but there will undoubtedly be more progress in the global computation than setbacks. Consensus that will not completely fill anyone. That is the toll that we must assume naturally. The Union is the synthesis of different, and even contraposed, ideas. Ideas that are peacefully confronted to make progress in well-being and prosperity, preserving stability in an increasingly changing world. We have, however, despite the difficulties, a solid foundation: de facto solidarity, which has continued to grow over the last few years. We see it every time we've suffered the bush of terrorism. They are the germ of a real, tangible European citizenship. When a Spanish citizen covers his profile on a social network with the flag of France, in solidarity with a terrorist attack in Paris, he is embracing the flag of Europe. When a German citizen feels his own the attack on Barcelona's Ramblas he is embracing the flag of Europe.  And when today we honour the victims that this very city of Strasbourg suffered in an appalling terrorist attack just a month ago what we are doing is embracing the flag of Europe. (Applause) Nothing can Europe's enemies against this growing sense of invisible but real solidarity. May it take root strongly, especially among the youngest, among the young people of Europe. They are the ones who display the European flag as a symbol against injustice, against authoritarian drifts, against machismo or against racism. Or simply to express your discomfort at decisions contrary to the logic of the times and your interests. Forgetting history, ladies and gentlemen, is a luxury we cannot afford. Being conservative in the face of uncertainty makes us more vulnerable. It is determination, conviction in our ideas, that will allow us to regain the impulse lost. We are faced with an authoritarianism that lives on invented nostalgia. But there is no nostalgia worse than longing for what never happened, as a song by a great Spanish author says. To all those who live from such invented nostalgias, and I stress the "invented" thing, I ask: Was peace firm when the borders separated us? Was there economic progress when customs limited trade? Have social and citizenship rights advanced in each state more than they have in recent years throughout the European Union? Very close to here, on the battlefields of World War I, we have the answer. That is why today I want to say: in the face of involution, progress. In the face of the rhetoric of exclusionary identities, identities that add up, which are not nullified by each other. The past, a good colleague of the Party of European Socialists and an extraordinary Vice-President of the European Commission, Franz Timmermans, told me, the past will never be the future of our societies. The past is a place to learn from our successes and our mistakes. It's time to move around Europe. It is time to protect and defend the values that make ours a unique project in the world. Envied in the world. Only in this way can we defeat those from the outside, but also from within, who want to destroy our ideals. And they want to do it, and I would like to underline this and remember it, for one reason only: for the values defended by the Union. In defending such values must be our answer. On this path, ladies and gentlemen, we need conviction and determination. To combine ideals with the search for pragmatism, as we have done during these last sixty years of life. Our task, as heirs and depositaries of this great legacy, is to preserve and improve what is received to pass it on to generations of Coming Europeans. If a lesson we have learned is that, at specific moments in our history as we are, to resist is to move forward. Today, it is up to the generations you represent in this Parliament to have a single but momentous task: to protect Europe so that Europe can protect its citizens. Thanks a lot. (The Assembly, standing up, applauds the speaker)

name: Frans Timmermans
text: First Vice President of the Commission. – Mr President, I want to start by thanking Prime Minister Sánchez Pérez—Castejón for his inspiring speech. One notion he tried to share with us is that, if Europe wants to protect its citizens, we politicians have a collective responsibility to protect Europe. Only a Europe that is united and strong can actually protect its citizens.  And those who sell the illusion that you can protect citizens by isolating those who are different, by building fences and walls, and by selling a pipe dream of nationalism will only lead to disappointment because there is no protection in protectionism, but there is isolation in isolationism. Nations left on their own in Europe will not be able to face the many challenges the world is throwing at us. Only a united Europe can do what its citizens demand, and that is protect them and help them shape their futures as independent people – free people. I know that Europe runs deep in Pedro Sanchez Pérez—Castejón’s veins. He is from a generation that was the last to be born under dictatorship, a generation that went on to grow up with the hope of freedom and democracy and then to realise the rights and freedoms of European membership, as Spain took its rightful place at the heart of Europe. The message I have for the Spanish Government today is – looking back over the last 40 years – that it is right to say that Europe shaped Spain as it is now, because that was the wish of the Spanish people. But I also believe it is right to say now that Spain should step up and shape Europe. It should take its responsibility as a leading nation in Europe. Use the potential you have to shape our collective future. (Applause) You are strong and resilient. You have shown in this terrible crisis that affected the Spanish population how you can come out of it stronger. Yes, unemployment is still at 13% – it’s much too high – but you’ve made huge progress in the last couple of years to put that behind you, with a determination from the Spanish people that was an inspiration to all of us in the rest of Europe. The Spanish people also share the analysis that Europe is first and foremost about democracy, liberty, freedoms and prosperity, and that these things are precious and can never be taken for granted. Spain has such a unique and important place in our Union, and its European story goes back much further than 1985, in particular about how much Europe owes to the determination and the ideas of people like Salvador de Madariaga, who helped to build the European project after the Second World War. He never gave up on the idea of a free Spain and a democratic Spain. People who never give up on their ideals, even in the darkest days, are the people who shape our future best. He saw our European destiny as intertwined with the destiny of Spain, our identities linked, and our successes linked. This is why he would be proud of what he sees today, a democratic Spain, celebrating 40 years of its Constitution, now at the heart of a strong and united Union. He would be proud of the social and economic progress made since 1985. Whilst growth is now above 2%, unemployment, as I said, is still too high at 13%. So there’s clearly a lot that needs to be done, but there are so many positive signals in the economy – the economy that’s back on its feet – and I again want to stress that this is thanks to the courage and determination of the Spanish people and also the solidarity of the European people – a solidarity that was more than reciprocated by Spain. It did receive solidarity from its European partners during the financial crisis, but it has shown time and again that it will also show solidarity to Europe, and it is showing it on a daily basis if I look at the issue of migration.  Countries like Spain and Malta, even in difficult times, really show solidarity with people in dire need. Spain has been a leader in many respects, and you, Pedro, have been a leader in generously welcoming those stranded on board the Aquarius boat. This was for me a defining moment in Europe when you stood up and said, on behalf of the Spanish people, ‘we will not let these people float on the sea and get into trouble’.  (Applause) That is true political leadership, not the easy way out of looking away, not the easy way out of blaming refugees, but taking the responsibility for their destiny, and I salute you for that. The images of these boats and the divisions caused by only a small number of arrivals on our shores show the need for Europe to overcome its differences and find a sustainable solution that works for all. It is now high time we conclude the necessary reform of our Common European Asylum System (EASO). Only if we make all these reforms, can we come to a sustainable situation. Border protection alone will not get us there. We also need a working asylum system based on solidarity and the fundamental values of the European Union. I also want to underscore, Pedro, what you said about Africa. If there is one continent that will be defining for the future of Europe, it is Africa. There is no one else in the world that can take this responsibility – or wants to take this responsibility on their shoulders – other than Europe. This is our sister continent, a stone’s throw away from our shores, and if we do not work towards a collective responsibility for the future of both continents, then the troubles of Africa cannot be kept away from Europe, however high the fences you want to build. Only stability, prosperity, optimism and a future that people in Africa can believe in will create the necessary stability for Europe also to be stable, prosperous and free in the future. I call upon you, Pedro, to lead in Europe and to lead Europe to understand that this relationship with Africa should not just be an issue for Mediterranean Members of the European Union, but for every single Member State, whatever its position in the European Union.  In our budget, there will be an almost threefold increase in funding for migration and security to reach nearly EUR 33 billion. This will be especially important for Spain, not only because you have shown such responsibility and solidarity as concerns migrants, but also because you know all too tragically the horror of terrorist attacks on Spanish soil. Funding for research and innovation will also be increased by 50% and the new Digital Europe programme, with EUR 9 billion, will support Europe’s digital transformation. Both of these will provide real opportunities to further boost the productivity of the Spanish economy. We will build on the success of the Juncker Plan, which has already triggered more than EUR 46.2 billion of investment in Spain’s economy and supported almost 150 000 small businesses. It is already making a difference on the ground through cleaner, more efficient buses in Palma de Mallorca and a new mill for recycling paper in Zaragoza for example, creating 110 jobs in the local community and supporting Spain’s circular economy in the process.  Prime Minister, I know your Government’s strong attachment to the Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs), and I know Spain needs to make that transformation, as Europe needs to make that transformation. I want to use the opportunity to salute my colleague here, next to me, who has been a leader in the world to make sure that Europe can really attain the Paris climate goals. I think he has been one of the global leaders in this respect and he deserves our recognition for that.  The new programme InvestEU has the potential to go much further by triggering another EUR 650 billion of investment across Europe between 2021 and 2027. Following in the footsteps of Manuel Marin, the founder of the Erasmus exchange programme, we will more than double its funding to more than EUR 30 billion. I had the pleasure of working with Manuel Marin in the past. If ever there was an explosive character, it was he, but he could get things done.  This increase will open up new opportunities for many more young Spaniards to gain new skills and experiences. All of us in the rest of Europe have had experience with young Spanish people coming to work in our countries and we were all inspired by their knowledge, their determination and their openness to differences. All of these investments can, and will, make a real difference on the ground in Spain and across our Union. So it is crucially important that we can agree on our new budget as swiftly as possible. I count on the support of Pedro, his counterparts and this House to make it happen. I also want to emphasise the importance of the equality agenda the Spanish Government has put forward. Why don’t we have a better plan to put an end to the pay gap in Europe between men and women? Why don’t we all agree that we will put an end to the pension gap, which is still 40% in Europe? Why don’t we all agree to break the glass ceiling and to make sure that more women are on boards? Why do we put 50% of our human potential on the back burner in Europe? This is unacceptable. I count on Pedro’s Government’s leadership to make this happen. Why don’t we finally put an end to violence against women? Why not? This is our duty. (Applause) And why don’t we call out those who falsely claim family values as an excuse to deny women their full rights in society? These are not family values, to say that women should not have full rights. These are not family values if you use them to justify violence in a marriage. Never ever can there be a justification for that.  Prime Minister, in my eyes, Spain and its European story are an example for the future of our Union. It shows what the values that we talk about really mean, and it shows how much can be achieved when we work together, take responsibility and make European solidarity truly meaningful. If Europe is to protect, then we need to protect Europe. (Applause)

name: Manfred Weber
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, welcome. Your presence is a great kick-off for the year 2019 firstly because you as a person, as a leader, are a committed and clearly pro-European prime minister and politician and your country is clearly pro-European. Thatʼs why itʼs great to have you here. For Spain, Europe has meant peace, stability and prosperity for more than four decades, and for Europe, Spain means strength, fresh ideas and leadership. Thatʼs why itʼs great to have you here.  Secondly, itʼs great because 2019 is a year when we will celebrate democracy in the European Union. The European elections will take place.  I also thank you for your commitment on the so-called Spitzenkandidaten concept. To support Franz Timmermans in your capacity as a Socialist leader gives us a clear indication that you believe in a democratic idea for the future of Europe and we have to keep this alive after the elections too – like me? – ... as a reminder.  (Applause) Talking about the future of Europe, we have to speak about extremism and nationalism: thatʼs clear, bearing yesterdayʼs vote and the developments in Europe in mind.  Many of the founding fathers of this European dream were Christian Democrats, Liberals, and colleagues from your parties, the Socialists and Greens. We are in one boat, and the reason why the anti-Europeanists are attacking is that we represent everything that they hate. The extreme right is a danger. There is no doubt about this. But let me stress that extremists have no colour. You are a committed pro-European – there is no doubt about this – but your government could not exist without the support of the extreme left and the pro-separatists in the Spanish Parliament, and that worries us. The answer to populism, we believe, is first of all to create stability, to do a good job as politicians. Frans Timmermans praised the perfect – not perfect – but very good development of the Spanish economy during the last few years since the economic crisis.  I want to remind everybody that this was due to the efforts of Mariano Rajoyʼs Government to create the conditions for economic success in Spain. (Applause) And now you are considering going back on Mariano Rajoyʼs labour market reforms. That, we think, would be the wrong signal. To create opportunities for the future, to create an economic future, means to be ready for reforms, and a real social Europe means creating jobs and increasing peopleʼs income. So please donʼt follow the populists: keep the reforms in place. And the second thing which I want to underline is that we have the utmost respect for your Government, even if we donʼt share the same political values and ideas. But we are worried about political stability. For the moment you have been unable to secure a constructive and stable majority in your Parliament for a budget for 2019. You are representing one of the biggest economies in the European Union, in the eurozone, and such a big economy without a stable budget means less stability and more uncertainty. Thatʼs why this cooperation – this sum of the parts of the Spanish Parliament – is increasing uncertainty in Europe.  And then, finally, there is migration, which you mentioned. We as the EPP have a clear picture, a clear priority. The first way in which we care is with the Marshall Plan for Africa, with the idea of a strong and an ambitious resettlement programme. We want to help people from Syria and other regions who need our help. But one thing is clear: illegal migration has to be stopped.  We have to destroy the inhuman business model of the smugglers and send illegal migrants, after a fair procedure, back home. And Spain has a special responsibility: illegal crossings in Spain have doubled for the second consecutive year to 57 000 migrants. I very often hear the argument that it is difficult to protect the border. During the summer break last year I was on the other side of the continent on the Bulgarian-Turkish border. There the Prime Minister installed a 5 metre-high fence over more than 180 kilometres, and he showed that if you have the political will, then you can protect the border and stop illegal migrants from crossing borders, for example with a fence.  You do this as well in Ceuta and Melilla, so you have the same concept there. We are looking to you to fight extremists. We have to solve problems, and that means that we are looking to Spain to protect borders against illegal migrants. The extreme form of populism is nationalism. The old ghost is alive again, and in Spain it has a concrete name. It is a Catalan question. We as the EPP stand behind the Constitution of Spain. We stand behind the territorial integrity of Spain and we stand behind the Government in preserving the unity of Spain.  Europe is built upon the rule of law and Spain is built upon the rule of law. We stood beside the Rajoy Government and we would do the same for you if you needed us.  So thatʼs why we should together fight against the nationalists on this continent. My group, for example, voted here in this House in favour of a Communist Vice-President, but we refused to vote in favour of a far-right Vice-President of this House because we want to guarantee that nationalists will never have anything to say about the future of Europe. They are our enemies. Thank you very much for your presence. We have a lot to do. My group and I thank you for your clear determination in support of Spainʼs European path. The EPP has a clear direction: no more fears, but hope; no more egoism, but solidarity; no more nationalism, but a common European future. Thank you for your contribution.

name: Udo Bullmann
text: en nombre del Grupo S&D. – Se'or presidente, querido presidente del Gobierno espa ol, querido Pedro, bienvenido al Parlamento Europeo. Dear Pedro, I cannot help quoting you again: 'if Europe has to protect us, we have to protect Europe'. I wish that this would be the motto of all European governments. I wish that this would be the slogan of all European leaders and for it to become the new benchmark which everyone with political responsibilities in Europe has to live up to. But unfortunately we are far from that. And this is the very reason why we were looking forward to having you here, to listening to you, to this ambitious speech, to this passionate idea of justice and progress for our homeland, Europe. Unfortunately, Mr Weber, it is not as easy as you are. We are all in the same boat. But if we want to counter nationalism, if we want to prevent Europe from becoming the victim of the right-wing extremists, then this boat must also sail, it must develop a certain dynamism. And we must overcome the stalemate of the last few decades, where the people of Europe are waiting for us to deliver and that we take care of their jobs, their social situation, their pensions, their prospects in the modern world of work. That's the real problem, that everyone always says they're in a boat, but no one is developing the momentum of riding through the waves, through the dangers of this modern world. What are we waiting for? We know that on the other side is someone like Putin who has no interest in our idea of freedom. But we also know that on the other hand, there is Trump, who has no idea of our ability to organize social justice in our society. What are we waiting for? Why do we not ignite the dynamism that lies in European societies? I have to say here that I really liked what Pedro Sanchez said, because it is a programme to bring the European Union together in the light of the interests and fears that the people of Europe have. We need to learn to deliver again! That is the crucial point. I liked this speech, Pedro Sanchez, because it broadcast it, because it has sprayed what we need – and we also need it in the next five years of the new mandate. But I must honestly say that I also liked it because it was presented by the head of government of Spain, a country – and I would like to underline what Frans Timmermans said – in which the fate of Europe will be decided. A country with cultural wealth, a country that knows about its different roots, knows its history, a country that has overcome Franco – the authoritarian fascist regime – and has developed the democratic power to resist everything that wanted to move back to the time of injustice, to the time of the state of government, to the time of the abolition of democracy. We rely on Spain and we know that Spain is in good hands. The programme he has presented is a programme which my group accepts, which we ourselves draw up. Yes, we say we never want to talk about the economy again without the perspective of working people. But we cannot talk about the economy and work without acknowledging that there must be this change – a change that saves the planet. But this change will only succeed if we take people with us, if we give them hope, if we give them perspective, and it will not go against the people. Look at France and the experience that Mr Macron has had to have. We need to make people strong so that they can go through this change with us. That is why the social perspective, the social justice that we must establish, has a very crucial part to play. And to conclude: yes, it also depends on how we govern. The many news that have come from Madrid: that you, Pedro Sanchez, have succeeded in putting together an intelligent cabinet, a forward-looking cabinet, where competences are pooled, energy and the environment, a High Commissioner for the issue of sustainability and, finally, finally, a clear signal not only for gender equality, but a breach of the dam for qualified women in the front row. I would like to see more of this in Europe. I would like to congratulate you. We want to work together along the lines you drew today. (Applause)

name: Hans-Olaf Henkel
text: im Namen der ECR-Fraktion. – Herr Präsident! Sie hatten zur Zukunft von Europa gesprochen und Sie haben – ich finde zu Recht – Ihre Rede mit Ihren Gedanken zum Brexit ausgeführt.  Davor hat in dieser Diskussion Vizepräsident Timmermans seinen Dank gegenüber den britischen Soldaten ausgesprochen, die sein Land von den Nazis befreit haben. Herr Vizepräsident, mein Vater – ich bin Deutscher – ist im Krieg geblieben. Unser Haus wurde 1943 von den Briten zerbombt und ich muss Ihnen sagen: Ich bin froh darüber, dass wir – die Deutschen – die Schlacht um England verloren haben.  I’m happy we lost the Battle of Britain, but I tell you I will be totally destroyed if we lose the battle for Britain. Prime Minister, said earlier – and rightfully so – that Brexit is a lose-lose situation for both, not only for Britain, but also for the European Union. I believe it is a lose-lose situation economically, politically and morally. Economically, because Brexit is equivalent to 19 other countries leaving the European Union and the Common Market at the same time; politically because Britain has always been the voice of reason, of subsidiarity, of competitiveness and of decentralisation; and morally, because rightfully many people in this Parliament have said earlier that Brexit makes everybody poorer, so it is actually an immoral proposition. In the earlier discussions we heard, everybody here seemed to regret Brexit, except these people here to my left, but not a single person has offered anything to stop it. It’s time to do that. More than 140 Members of this Parliament earlier wrote a letter addressed to the people of Britain asking them to come up with a second vote. I support that. But they should have written the letter to themselves, because let’s not forget – contrary to what Mr Verhofstadt said – it’s not only a catfight within the Conservative Party, there was a reason for the British to start thinking about Europe.  In the Lisbon Treaty we talked about subsidiarity – and what was done? More and more centralisation. In the Lisbon Treaty we talked about competition – and what was done? The opposite: harmonisation. In the Lisbon Treaty we talk about self-responsibility of a country for its debts – and what are we doing? We are trying to socialise them. So there are good reasons for this Parliament, the Commission and the Council to start doing something else.  I agree with everybody who said that it is unlikely we will come up with a new deal that will help Theresa May get the support of Parliament, so let’s change the strategy. Let’s offer Britain a deal which enables Britain to stay in the European Union. That is the call of the day, and not moaning and blaming Britain. It is also up to us to agree that we have a responsibility for Brexit. So let’s offer a new deal to Britain for them to stay in the European Union, and that can only be a special temporary deal on immigration. So that’s what I’m saying. Instead of always blaming Britain, let’s also recognise that Europe and Brussels are part of the problem. They should become part of the solution. Let’s fight a battle for Britain.

name: Guy Verhofstadt
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, I will try to say this in four minutes because I have a Catalan colleague and a Basque colleague who want to speak and I do not want to be killed afterwards.  But, Prime Minister, there is one underexposed characteristic of Spain which you too have demonstrated, namely that it is maybe for the moment the most pro-European country in Europe because it has the guts to talk about a federal Europe. There are not so many of your colleagues who are come here and have the courage to talk about a federal Europe. This is no accident. The reason, I think, is that European history and Spanish democracy are interlinked. Over the last decades those who have taken responsibility in your foreign affairs departments were all Members of this House: Íñigo Méndez de Vigo, Ms Mendez de Vigo, Ms Palacio, Josep Borrell, my good friend, who was a former civil servant, and Miguel Moratinos. Last but not least, there is competition in Spanish politics to be the most pro-European party between the Partido Popular, the PSOE, and Ciudadanos, and I like that. I like to see national political parties in every country in the European Union competing among themselves to be the most pro-European. That’s the way forward. But I have to tell you that after – I don’t know – the 15th debate that we have had on the future of the European Union, I am a little frustrated because every time there is a prime minister, or a president, who comes here to make a whole list of all the new European policies that we need to have – social policies, tax policies, migration policies, or a European army – and we never tackle the question why doesn’t it happen today? What is the obstacle? Why do we always do too little too late compared, for example, with our American friends, who in nine months can tackle the financial crisis, whereas after nine years we still do not have a banking union?  (inaudible) after several years of an enormous tragedy in the Mediterranean, I want to congratulate you on the way that you dealt with the Aquarius refugees, but let’s be honest: that was the consequence of inhumane nationalistic policies by Mr Salvini, who was the real source and reason in that case, and of the lack of European policies. Why do we still not have a European border in Ceuta? Why do we still not have an agreement on the reform of Dublin, for example, after so many years of tragedies in the Mediterranean? Why do we today not have a European army? Why are we still struggling with the reform of the eurozone nine years after the start of the financial crisis? That is, for me, the key question and I hope that in your reply in a few minutesʼ time you will go into it. To my mind the problem is that for the moment we have bad institutions in the European Union and bad institutions create bad results. Good institutions create good results. The problem – and I want to repeat this again and again and again, and will continue to do so, together with a number of you –is the unanimity rule that exists in our Union and especially in the European Council: that is the main problem which has to be solved.  (Applause) That’s the main problem. The imbalance that exists between the European Parliament deciding by a majority and the European Council that continues to act unanimously. All five of the examples that I have given are blocked in the European Council. So my plea to you, now and in the coming years, is to take up this political battle that we need to win, as otherwise all our long lists will be wish lists that will never be realised. Mr President, I think that I have for the first time done something which is impossible, namely to keep more or less to my four minutes.

name: Ska Keller
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his speech, which I believe was very strong and very pro—European, and I’m happy about that because a lot of people are very concerned when it comes to the future of Europe. We see many governments who are actually falling short of providing rule of law and progress on democracy in their countries. So it’s good to see that things can be done differently – very good to see. Let me congratulate you specifically on some of the measures that have already been taken in Spain, which reflect the commitments you were voicing here. Namely, first, your decision to increase the minimum salary to EUR 900, which helps many families who suffered considerably in the past from the budgetary cuts and anti—social reforms, and also, especially, in combination with your taxation reform, which will be a great improvement. We want a true social union, and for that we need more effort in the Council and in every single Member State, so I really hope that others will follow your example. Secondly, your decision to make sure that families who put up solar panels on their roofs will actually benefit from doing so is a way not only to combat climate change but also to reward people for their own initiative and make sure that everyone will contribute in this big quest to save our planet. We need these concrete steps. Lastly, I’m very happy that, as you also mentioned today, your cabinet has the highest proportion of women in the whole European Union. Women’s rights are human rights, and we’re still far from real gender equality but we need to take progressive steps here. We are seeing a big backlash in many Member States inside the European Union against women’s rights, against human rights, and it’s very good to see that there are still some governments left who can champion an ambitious agenda on gender equality. However, your job in Spain is certainly not an easy one and, of course, you’ve inherited a lot of problems, among them the situation in Catalunya. The harsh and uncompromising way in which your conservative predecessor dealt with the issue hardened the conflict and made it worse. Now the issue is on your desk, and it’s very clear that only a democratic political solution can open the way forward, and this includes a solution for the prisoners. Two former members of our political group are currently in prison and what they’re accused of does not stand up to scrutiny, as has been pointed out by courts in Belgium and in Germany. So we urge you to initiate a sincere dialogue because only goodwill from both sides will bring us closer to a solution, and that is sorely needed for Catalunya, for the whole of Spain and for the whole of Europe. Prime Minister, you mentioned European values and how all of us need to stand up for them. I am very concerned in that regard when I look at Andalusia because an extremist right—wing party will be included in a governmental deal and tolerated in the government. I am sad to see that the conservatives and liberals are agreeing to a deal which will not only make sure that those nationalists have a say in our future and the future in Andalusia, but which also goes beyond that context. I am sure that many of you are concerned about that. I’m sure that many of you are not happy about it, but it is something on which, precisely, you can take concrete action, and all of us and all our groups have to work towards ensuring that this does not happen – because it’s a shameful deal, as it would be for any one of us to make a coalition with an extremist, nationalist, right—wing party. Let’s not do that. Use all the powers that you have in your hands – and you have those powers – to end that deal. We support the women who are protesting right now for gender equality because machismo and violence against women have no place anywhere in the European Union. I would like to remind you, Prime Minister, that many of the goals that you mentioned – all of them, in fact: gender equality, ecology and social Europe – need action at European level, so we hope you will take the initiative in the Council as well. We hope for your support in the Council, and we hope your colleagues in the Council will follow your example. And, if you are going to continue working for a progressive, social, ecological and democratic Europe, then you can count on our support.

name: Paloma López Bermejo
text: GUE/NGL Group. – Mr President, Mr Sánchez, I would like to thank you for your presence in this House and for your contributions to the European debate. A more necessary debate than ever before in the face of the push of far-right populist forces, which are whipping Europe, including Spain.  However, beyond whether or not it coincides with your diagnosis of the dangers and threats that plague the European Union, I have to disagree on the solutions that you and other European leaders have brought to this Parliament. With reference to the far right, these formations of fascist tendencies, must be confronted and fought from the root. The origin and breeding ground for the emergence of these phenomena lies in the leave of functions that many governments have done with regard to their obligations to the working class.  I don't need to remind you how neoliberal policies driven from Brussels have only reduced the already diminished welfare state. The crisis has heightened existing problems, and crisis management is responsible for unsustainable inequality. With their policies, at the service of the privileged, they have caused enormous social pain and a crisis of legitimacy.  The Governments of Spain, no matter their color, have been participants and collaborators of the bitter moments we live in. Express constitutional reform involved cuts in health, education, pensions, dependency and two labour reforms that are extremely harmful to workers. This is something that can't happen again. They have created a perfect storm for the far right to take advantage of the defenselessness and despair of the social majority and offer false enemies and false solutions.  Mr Sánchez, the European Union today has more than 140 million poor people and precarious workers, also the result of the territorial asymmetry of the productive model with which southern Europe is punished. We are condemned to subsidiary models based on cheap labour and little added value. Today we have thousands of people whose jobs are pending a thread because in their companies, or they are not paid, or they will be kicked out with an employment regulation file.  There's Alcoa: they've reached a pre-agreement with the unions. I hope you ratify it. Vodafone, Deliveroo, Globe, Amazon. The list is too long to read whole. This is the result of leaving democracy in the hands of the interests of multinationals, when the priority is the real problems of citizens, wherever they live and wherever they are. That is why public policies, which promote quality employment and prevent labour exploitation in any of the Member States, must be promoted. Because, so far, the free movement of capital has been in parallel with the free movement of poverty and inequality.  Do not continue to agree on economic policies with the right, do not continue to weaving sterile alliances, tend from now on to the problems affecting the working class.
