We don't need good intentions. We need commitments. For example, for social policy to become the axis of European policies, will it force ratification of the European Social Charter? That's a good social contract. What are you prepared to do to make the European Union's foreign policy a factor of credibility without contradictions, as in the case of Western Sahara or Palestine?  Ended. Derogue the begging vote and reform the Organic Law of the Electoral Regime. And finally, equality between women and men is threatened. The gap is suffered by women. It is structural and occurs in all areas. But we're not going to give in to it. We will continue to fight to defend our interests as women.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: EFDD Group. – Mr President, Mr Prime Minister, thank you very much for being here with us today.  This is the fifteenth debate on the future of the European Union that we are holding here in the European Parliament. For the fifteenth time we must repeat that the Union is undoubtedly going through a moment of extreme difficulty and, for the fifteenth time, we have to wonder why. Our answer is always the same: wrong policies lead to harm and injustice. I'll cite only two examples.  Austerity policies have caused enormous damage to our society. Yesterday President Juncker admitted in plenary that these austerity policies have caused some damage.  It's called "better late than never." But not here, we've spent the maximum time here. We have created economies that have dismantled the system of protection of workers and the most vulnerable categories, leaving the needs of those living in difficulty dissatisfied.  Talking about social justice, respect for human dignity, the drama of poverty, lack of work and social exclusion that millions of European citizens live on does not mean being populist, but means taking note of reality and giving immediate answers.  Juncker, Commissioners, enjoy these last few months that the Commission has left, because the next elections will bring a wind of change not only to this House, but to the whole Commission.  The second example of the wrong policies I want to cite concerns migration policies. Here, the failure of the Union — a Union of name and not indeed — is evident.  The lack of a common position on the equitable sharing of responsibilities and solidarity in asylum and migration policies among all Member States has sunk the reform of the common European asylum system. These two principles are laid down in Article 80 of the Treaty, but have already given way to national selfishness. This means that the highest levies on the management of migration flows fall mainly on border states and on few (incomprehensible words) collaborators. The European Union's failure in these policies has a very large impact on fundamental rights and also in terms of social and economic costs, estimated annually at around EUR 49 million, according to a recent study. It is no coincidence that you have cited these two examples, Mr Prime Minister: Spain and Italy are two Mediterranean countries that have matching interests, such as managing migration flows and the economy.  You and I are an expression of two different political forces. However, our countries should work together to combat austerity and find solutions to the migration crisis. On this issue, the whole European Union should give signs of life; and we, ladies and gentlemen, should give other signals to the citizens.  Citizens ask us for concrete facts and answers. For example, we could start by killing the waste. We are going to start a great fight against the collapses of the Union, and let us do so on the part of this Parliament here of this useless and unjustifiable triple seat.  Maintaining Strasbourg costs citizens up to 1 billion euros for each legislature, or 200 million euros each year to be open forty-eight days a year. With what face and with what encouragement can we justify these huge figures to our citizens? It's not possible.  Ladies and gentlemen, asking for the cancellation of this waste is not an attack on democracy, and democracy is not a privilege, nor is it a building.  Ladies and gentlemen, Mr Prime Minister, on one side are decimals, austerity, waste, privilege; and in the other are the citizens and the request for change. People must be put at the heart of European Union policies and decisions. Respect for the rights and well-being of all citizens must be put first and not sacrificed in the name of certain economic and financial interests that benefit few people.

name: Nicolas Bay
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, Prime Minister, less than a year ago you were accidentally at the helm of Spain thanks to the scandal that has engulfed Mariano Rajoy. Your arrival was miraculous for the Spanish Socialist Party, which has only 80 seats in the Chamber of Deputies, but disastrous for the Spaniards who are now suffering from your politics. Your first step was to welcome the Aquarius, the ship of a Franco-German NGO, whose trade fund is to support illegal immigration in the Mediterranean. Mafias that thrive on human trafficking use and abuse the naivety of Europeans. Smugglers are the main beneficiaries of these so-called humanitarian operations, which allow them to save money on the fuel of their makeshift boats, where they pile up migrants. Mr Macron and Mrs Merkel, delighted to receive this unexpected support for their crazy migration policy, were obviously quick to congratulate you. Last summer, you twice received Mrs Merkel, the second time, for that matter, at your summer residence in Andalusia. Without consulting the Spaniards, you have reached an agreement with the Chancellor to recover the overflow of migrants which she finally wants to offload after opening its borders wide in 2015.  In your zeal, you did not even realize that you were treating Morocco as an underdeveloped country by referring, I quote, to an "abyss of inequality". However, your predecessors have concluded several agreements with this country, the most stable and prosperous in the Maghreb, including an agreement on the readmission of illegal immigrants, which is all the more important since only 14 kilometers separate southern Spain from northern Morocco. But after showing your willingness to welcome illegal immigrants, they obviously rushed to your doors and we saw chaotic scenes of migrants rushing to Ceuta and Melilla attacking your border guards, including sometimes with weapons. Submitted to Berlin, you are also in Brussels. And for a long time now. In 2011, in the discretion of the summer and under your leadership, the Socialist Party decided to support a major change in the Spanish constitution. Since then, any government has been obliged by its own constitution to comply with the European Commission's budgetary injunctions.  But the Spanish people are waking up. Since the beginning of December, a party that your friends have treated condescendingly has made a historic breakthrough in your Andalusian stronghold. I am obviously talking about Vox, which, as part of a coalition, has helped to free up the Socialists who have held this region for 40 years. And this is just the beginning, because Santiago Abascal puts you in front of your responsibilities: in 2018, because of you, the arrivals of migrants have increased by 129% compared to 2017. Conversely, in Matteo Salvini's Italy, illegal immigration has fallen by more than 95% because the message is clear: Italians can no longer stand the violation of their laws by arriving illegally on their territory. This is all the less so since the mafia - the real one, the one against which Matteo Salvini fights tirelessly - exploits human misery in all these traffickings. A recent article in The Guardian newspaper reported that migrant trafficking was more profitable than drug trafficking. Not to mention multinationals that often welcome the arrival of cheap labour.  Prime Minister, solving the migration problem is only a matter of political will, because the men of the Guardia Civil are just as competent and determined as their Italian counterparts. But instead of relying on them, you preferred to announce before Christmas the creation of a special fund dedicated to the integration of migrants. Well, I predict that the Spaniards won't be able to bear your irresponsibility for very long.

name: Kazimierz Michał Ujazdowski (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Colleagues, i would like to thank you for your excellent work. I would like to start by thanking the Prime Minister for speaking out and, on this occasion, to pay tribute to Spain, because I understand that every head of government here represents not so much his political party – this debate is too partisan – but his country. So I would like to warmly congratulate Spain on all its efforts, that it can celebrate the 40th anniversary of its constitution and that it has saved its integrity under previous governments. Mr Verhofstadt sees in your speech an expression of federalist doctrine. I am a convinced European, but I believe that Europe today needs realism and a more practical approach, greater respect for countries, competitiveness of the economy, a retreat from centralism. That is what I missed in your speech. I would also like to say that the idea of solidarity must be understood very precisely. Solidarity is a need, a necessity to come to the aid of others, especially when it is in an unhappy state through no fault of its own. But solidarity is not paying for the waste of others. Europe needs financial responsibility. This responsibility lies with the Member States. And I hope that Spain will, in a practical sense, be a partner for talking about a more realistic approach to European policy than what the Prime Minister presented today in his speech.

name: Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón
text: President of the Government of Spain – Mr President, thank you to all the participants and thank you also for the tone of the debate, which has been encouraged as each of the interventions has been aroused and developed. I am going to be allowed by the spokespersons of the various groups to answer them as a whole and not personally, because I believe that if we would not over-extend the answer to their questions. The central idea of intervention, of all the time, is that Europe must be protected in order for Europe to protect us. And that is clearly what has flown in many of the interventions, at least those of the main parliamentary groups. We all agree that we need to strengthen Europe, above what the ideological discrepancies we have. The question is in what sense, in what direction. I want to refer first of all to migration. I would say to Mr Weber that it is right for him to move the vision of the People's Party of Spain, but it would be good if he also knew and contrasted that information, because migration did not come with the Socialist Government last June. For an idea to be made, in 2017 the increase in migration flows in Spain was 137%. 137%. Therefore, what came with the Government of Spain was not migration, it was migration policy, which did not exist until then; that didn't exist until then. What I will tell you, and what I will also say to the other Members, is that we have always known, we have always known – and that is why we also take the decision to host the Aquarius, to offer as a safe port Valencia – that the challenge of migration requires all countries, all Member States, to have a shared position , a common position, based on two fundamental axes. The first, responsibility and the second, solidarity.  Of course we, and the Government of Spain, are defending a policy, a foreign policy like the one raised by the Vice-President of the European Commission. It argues that we need to dump economic resources for Africa's development and momentum. It advocates bilateral cooperation with many of the countries of transit and origin of migration. We have strengthened bilateral dialogue with Morocco, Mauritania, all the Sahel countries in seven months, not only in the interests of Spain, but in the interests of the European Union as a whole. To get an idea, Spain, for many years, has had return policies, with Morocco, with Mauritania and with so many other countries in Africa, of the Sahel. In fact, a few days ago I was in Mali, where we also promoted, or somehow reopened, a policy of voluntary return of Mali nationals who are living in Spain right now. Therefore, return policies are being promoted by the Government of Spain.  We are also strengthening our border policies. And, without a doubt, what we are doing is also strengthening integration policies, because we believe it is important to strengthen these migration policies for all those migrants who are on our continent. And, without a doubt, what I want to transfer to you in this matter is that we are, the Government of Spain is, of course, in favour of reforming the common European asylum system and not questioning Schengen, and, by the way, I am concerned that minority parties, ladies and gentlemen will not do so. It has been made by parties that are part of large parties in the European Parliament, such as the People's Party. And I don't think we can do any throwbacks on that. That is why what concerns me, speaking and simply referencing the far-right, what worries me is not so much the presence of the far-right, ladies and gentlemen, what concerns me is how subtly the far-right is conditioning the discourse and political agenda of parties that were again European and which wanted the strengthening of the European project. This Government , and I recognise its oratory brilliance, Mr Verhofstadt , this Government certainly supports the adoption of the multiannual financial framework. We have also done so at the European Council. We have defended and defended in particular, and not only I, also the previous government, with President Rajoy at the helm, approved the Multiannual Financial Framework before the elections. Because we consider it to be fundamental to essential policies in Spain, such as agricultural policy, such as cohesion policy, but also important policies, such as immigration policy or policies related to science and innovation. By the way, Mr Weber, don't worry, because we are going to approve the general budgets of the State probably in April. The previous administration, with Mr. Rajoy at the helm, presented the budgets at the Congress of Deputies in April. So what I want to say to you with this is that it is not that we are going in a timely way, but that we are going to anticipate what the previous administration proposed as a budget offer to the House as a whole. And I think we are going to take it out, because I think they are good budgets, not only in the social sphere, with a considerable increase in the items linked to redistribution, but they also propose innovative formulas from the point of view of tax justice, such as the imposition on large technology corporations, such as the creation of the financial transaction tax , which are undoubtedly some of the measures that you have proposed here in this House and which we are also leading at the level of Spain. Let me also speak for an instant about Catalonia, because this is how the spokeswoman, Mrs Keller, has done so.  First of all. In Catalonia, since 2014, since 2014, there have been five votes, five votes, around three regional electoral processes and then two referendums contravening the Constitution, the Statute of Autonomy in Catalonia. Well, what has been the result of these referendums and those votes also in the Spanish statutory context? At most, 48% of Catalan society has supported pro-independent formations and 52% have not supported pro-independent formations. Therefore, first conclusion: independence in Catalonia does not have a social majority. It has a parliamentary majority, product and derived from the Electoral Law, but does not have a social majority. I insist 52% of society in Catalonia does not support independence, it does not support independence. Well, therefore, independence has to recognize is that there is no social majority in Catalonia. And, therefore, it cannot support, or cannot impose a political project on a majority that is repeatedly telling it, since 2014, that it does not share this independence drift. First. Secondly. It is clear that, in Europe, not only in Catalonia, if we go, for example, to Germany, in Bavaria, or if we go, for example, to Italy, in Veneto, or if we go, for example, to France, in Corsica, there are territorial tensions, there are movements of territorial fragmentation, of decomposition of what were the state nations. What is the difference between what has happened in Catalonia and what has happened in Veneto, for putting a case, or for example in Bavaria, when the independence of Bavaria from Germany or the independence of Veneto from Italy have been defended by different political formations? That when the Constitutional Court or the Supreme Court has ruled in Veneto, rather, in Italy with the Veneto case or in Germany with the case of Bavaria, those independence forces have said is 'we abide by those judgments'. It hasn't happened in Spain. In Spain, despite repeated rulings of the Constitutional Court, what the pro-independence formations have done is unilaterally break the Statute of Autonomy, that is, the regional constitution in Catalonia and the Spanish Constitution. Therefore, the problem is that, in some way, the constitutional mandate has not been fulfilled or not complied with by the independence forces, because that regional and state constitution has not been recognized. Thirdly, it is clear that since 2010 Catalonia has a regional Constitution, a Statute of Autonomy of Catalonia, which in its entirety was not voted by Catalan society. So that's a problem we have to solve. And the Spanish state is aware of it. One thing is also true. For ten years to this part, it is clear that there are political parties that, when in opposition, use Catalonia as a territorial grievance to make opposition to the socialist government on duty and, when they are in government, what they do is claim loyalty, in this case, to the Socialist Party. We're always going to do it. We're going to be loyal, not with the government on duty, when we're in opposition, but with the state. Spain is a great country. Spain is a country that has a level of decentralization, economically, socially, culturally, in the recognition of languages, in what represents the educational approach of children who are in communities that have a high feeling of very important nationality. There are indices in the international community that are not minor and quite solvent, by the way, that place Spain as the second most decentralized country in the world. Therefore, first of all, I think it is clear that independence in Catalonia has to do is open a sincere dialogue and recognize the other party, which is a majority in Catalonia, which is non-nationalist, and therefore Catalonia has to talk to Catalonia. And Spain, the Government of Spain, has to facilitate that dialogue between the two, say, the two dimensions that exist right now in Catalonia: the nationalist and the non-nationalist. And, of course, what I can guarantee you is that the Government of Spain, unlike in past times, does have a firm will to resolve through dialogue, but always in compliance with the Constitution and the Statute of Autonomy, the situation in Catalonia. But first, what independence has to do in Catalonia is to recognize 1, that it has no social majority and 2, that it has to talk to the majority part of Catalan society, that it wants a new agreement to get out of this loop in which it has been installed for more than ten years. To be summarized in a very synthetic, very simple way, in Catalonia the problem is not independence, it is coexistence. And finally, you have made, Mr Weber, an allusion to the motion of censure. The motion of censure had a mandate, which was democratic regeneration in our country. What has happened in Andalusia between the People's Party, the Liberal Group and the Brothers of the National Front in France is an involution, a question of rights and consensus assumed and consolidated during recent years, such as gender equality and the fight against gender-based violence. Therefore, in Andalusia, what has happened, ladies and gentlemen, is that a border that exists in Europe has crossed, which is that it cannot be agreed with the far right. Of course, we, social democracy, will never agree with the far-right one, as we have very well seen with its approaches. In any case, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to tell you that the approach of the Government of Spain is to make Europe strong. There are the proposals that we have put forward in terms of the strategy of gender equality, in what represents equality, or rather, the fight against occupational precariousness, which represents the guarantee of children, the guarantee of youth. In short, in all those aspects that have to do with the strengthening and protection of Europe to protect us and, above all, those most vulnerable will be able to find the Government of Spain and, without a doubt, the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party, which is also represented here. And finally, Mr Verhofstadt, I will also tell you one thing: you have been in the European Parliament many more years than I have. I have been at the head of the Spanish government for seven months. I'm sure you can share your experience of frustration with me. I will also tell you one thing: I believe that in my speech I have pointed out some way out of this lack of speed in many of the decision-making that is needed in the field of economic and monetary union, in the field of foreign policy, which has to do with the change in decision-making procedures, both of the Council and Parliament and the Commission. And, of course, there we are going to be, so I have done from this rostrum, arguing that it is not unanimously on matters as essential as the ones I have referred to above. There are some of them that will need an amendment to the Treaty, but others will not. There are the catwalks reminded me of by the Foreign Minister, Mr Borrell. We can perfectly use these gateways to reinforce, say, the global character of our continent, of our Union in the field of foreign policy. Thank you very much, Mr President.

name: Esteban González Pons (PPE).
text: – Mr President, we live in a time of false news, but also, as we have seen, a time of false convictions.  It cannot be said "I will never agree with the extremists" when you are in government thanks to the vote of the independenceists, the former terrorists and the extreme, far left, and when, in the same intervention, it has just been announced that the general budgets of the State will be approved – and can only be approved – with the vote of the independenceists , the former terrorists and the extreme, far left.  Anyway, let me tell you, Mr Sánchez, that what hurt me most about your speech today is that in your first speech, in which you have talked a lot about globalization, you have been unable to talk about the unity of Spain, unable to defend the Spanish rule of law.  They've had to squeeze the "yellow posters" for you to say something about Catalonia. And what he has said is that it is not a problem of independence, but of coexistence, when the Supreme Court is about to start a trial on rebellion in Spain. We all expected the President of the Spanish Government to defend the rule of law of our country here. I'm telling you as a Spanish deputy. We have been defending the unity of Spain here for two years. But defending here, with conviction, the unity of Spain, Mr President, is not only a problem of your job, it is also a problem of conviction, and of conviction that is not false.  It has not come to you today, unfortunately for the interests of our country, being the President of the Spanish Government in the European Parliament. We do get it.  It hurts, but I hold on.

name: Iratxe García Pérez (S&D).
text: – Mr President, President Sánchez, this is a delicate time for Europe, and listening to your speech with a firm commitment to European values really is a respite for those of us who believe that the solution to our problems is in Europe. In more and better Europe. There are those who cannot resist the temptation to bring madrid's arguments to earn points before the acronyms of their party, but I think we respect Europe's project little if we do not use this space, if we do not use the heart of Europe to talk about how we are able to solve people's problems. More social justice, more balance, avoid inequalities, move forward in an egalitarian Europe between men and women, be able to look head-on at people and say that in Europe there is the solution to their problems. That is the commitment of the Europeanists. That is the commitment of social democracy, and we will work tooth and nail to defend Europe more and better. A Europe that looks in front of people and is able to return the illusion to the European project. Thank you very much for having governments within the European Union which continue, together with this Parliament, to defend the fundamental values of the European project.

name: Joachim Starbatty (ECR).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The great Social Democrat Ferdinand Lassalle has said that politics begins with the consideration of reality. Yesterday we celebrated the euro here, and I heard six speeches that had nothing to do with reality. You have presented a pipe dream.  Prime Minister, you want a social Europe. A social Europe is one that gives citizens work and employment and prospects for young people. That is the most important thing. One has to ask: why is the euro area, the slowest growing region in the world? Why is that? Why are we doing investment programmes? Mr Timmermans said how wonderful what Mr Juncker has done is. Yes, we need private investment. Why do we not have private investment? Because a gap runs through Europe and that gap is the euro. Look at Germany, tax sources are bubbling. We have no unemployment.  In other countries we have a precariat, or as they say, we work for less money. We are working more for less money, and that is not the social Europe we want.

name: Javier Nart (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Sánchez, we are facing the growing and growing threat of populists and separatists, but condemnation is not enough.  We must give effective answers to the cause of paradigm shifting: the diffuse economy, which has precarious the middle classes, which are the basis of democracy. But today we have more doctrine than solutions and more political than politics.  President Sanchez, the road is neither with the separatists nor with the left-wing or right-wing populists who want to destroy and weaken Europe. In the face of populism and separatism, we must find those who believe and have built and want to continue to build Europe. And defending her.  I would also like to remind you — for those who think Catalonia is a catalan problem — that in Catalonia the first party is a party that believes in Spain and is called Ciudadanos. Not the separatists, Citizens. The exclusion and sectarian use of what is everyone's—for example, feminism—is enough and let us work together to defend the common. Our soul, more than ever, must be equality, solidarity and unity.  President Sanchez, that applies to Europe and also to Spain.

name: José Bové (Verts/ALE).
text: Mr President, Mr President of the Spanish Government, on 5 November I went to visit my former colleagues in the European Parliament who are now incarcerated in Spanish prisons. Is it conceivable today that we are in such a situation, that people who have been elected, first at European level, then in Catalonia, legally, can be imprisoned for their political ideas? This Parliament has been repeatedly denounced for Mr Orbon's illiberal policies; Poland's illiberal policies have been denounced; the rights attacks that are taking place in other European countries today have been rightly denounced. Is Spain, because of its constitution and because of the policy that is being carried out in Catalonia, joining the camp of these countries? I think it's a shame. I heard your speech, but how is it today that people, members of Parliament, members of regional governments and community leaders are in prison? I have heard your call for dialogue and I share it, but if we want to talk, it is not with people in prison. You need to get these people released, so we can talk. Never has any of them decided not to assume their responsibilities, including in court, even if they do not agree to be in court. Release these people, and then you will act as a democracy.

name: Le Président. –
text: Mr Bové, I would remind you that the Hondt system must be respected. If you speak for two minutes, a member of your group will lose their time. I just want to let you know. That's the rule, you have to respect it.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr. President. Mr Sánchez, your government began hosting the Aquarius and six months later ended up blocking the Open Arms in Barcelona. By the way, to the delight of fascists like Salvini. He promised the repeal of the "Gag Act" and there it goes. He promised to repeal labor reform, and not only has he not, but it does not prevent profitable companies, such as Alcoa, from firing hundreds of workers. He promised a tax on banking and it seems the tax never comes. He promised to regulate the bubble of rents that drive thousands of people out of their homes and it looks like they're winning vultures. The question, Mr Sanchez, is whether the Socialists will remain complicit in the neoliberal policies of the grand coalition in Europe. To stop the reactionary wave that is advancing, and now ruling in Andalusia, we need a 180-degree shift in austere policies and cuts at the service of elites. It is urgent to turn Europe around and, Mr Sanchez, we are running out of time. We have to take sides.

name: William (The Earl of) Dartmouth (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, I’m going to speak in support of what Mr Bové said about the Catalan prisoners, who, incidentally, have languished for a year in pre-trial detention. These are political prisoners. Political prisoners, but the European Commission does nothing. The Council does nothing. The Parliament, as an institution, says nothing, and even Mr Verhofstadt stays quiet. The European values that we hear about all the time are suppressed, and one wonders why. The likely reason is that Spanish governments support the EU project and, somehow, that makes it okay to have political prisoners. This is to be deplored, and the hypocrisy is extremely hard to stomach. I suggest that you people should look at yourselves in the mirror and start campaigning for these political prisoners to be freed.  (Applause)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, welcome. I have some questions to ask you. What practical steps will you take to ensure that your country, Spain and Italy, as well as my country, Greece, cease to be places of permanent residence for illegal immigrants? You said you were in favour of the creation of the European army. However, in order to justify the increase in the European Union's military capabilities, there must be an enemy threatening Europe. Can you tell us who this enemy is and which countries it is threatening? Because, as you know and as I know, the only countries in Europe threatened by a third country are Greece and Cyprus, threatened by Turkey. You also said that the European Union must be able to intervene outside its borders. Is this the Europe of the future you envision? The role of a global gendarme? You also argued that the principle of unanimity should be abolished. However, if this principle is abolished, then the power of states, especially small states, will be reduced. Can you imagine your country being harmed, in the minority position, and not being able to defend those interests?

name: Esther de Lange (PPE).
text: – Mr President, first of all I would like to thank the Prime Minister for a very constructive speech. It is clear that Spain is a reliable partner in Europe and Europe will be a reliable partner to Spain. So yes, we will for example continue the youth guarantee, cohesion policy, etc. But let’s be clear, responsibility for a social Europe starts at home, so calling for a European unemployment scheme to take attention away from the work you have to do at home is, I think, a dangerous strategy. Economically we’re lucky. Spain is standing on the shoulders of giants. It has a good economic situation thanks to the work of previous governments. So let’s continue that work, let’s not burden future generations with unsustainable levels of debt. I think that’s where social policy starts. Responsibility and solidarity go hand-in-hand, and on that basis, I look forward to continuing work with Spain.

name: Antonio López-Istúriz White (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Sánchez, we are here at the moment, as your colleague said, talking about the future of Europe. And in that respect for Europe, I did not understand why, in the end, your speech has become a small electoral rally in support of Mr Timmermans, the Socialist candidate, and from him to you.  And many of my colleagues also wonder if the same energy he uses in accusing and prosecuting dictators of the past will be used in today's dictatorships, in Venezuela and in Cuba. Are you going to sue the Council for sanctions on the Venezuelan regime and the Cuban regime, or will it keep quiet? A lot of colleagues want to know if that's going to change.  You were talking about the European democratic acquis that you respect: demonstrate that Europeanism by denouncing in the European Council and not supporting the dictatorial regimes of Maduro and Castro — because it is still Castro who runs Cuba.  And let political prisoners be released. There's talk of political prisoners here. There are political prisoners in Cuba and Venezuela: freedom for them, already.  And please announce it to the Council. Then I will believe that you are Europeanist.

name: José Blanco López (S&D).
text: – Mr. President. Mr Esteban González Pons, to be a patriot is not to shout 'Long live Spain!', but to maintain constitutional and European values and not to go hand in hand with those who want to destroy them. You had a chance to prove here that you were a Spanish patriot, supporting the Government of Spain, as we socialists have always done in this House when Spain was threatened and you were coming to ask us for help. But I want to tell you something. You came to the Government of Spain to the cry of 'Spain is broken!', and this government received a more broken Spain than ever before, with more independenceists than ever before, after two illegal referendums that were held when you ruled and with impaired coexistence. And with this heritage we regret that you do not contribute to generating spaces of coexistence, which is precisely what the Government of Spain is promoting.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: Mr. President, Dear Prime Minister, thank you for your contribution to this debate. Since the Brexit referendum, the EU has focused on the issue of further political reintegration, and president Trump's election and the redefinition of the US position have further pushed us in this direction, which I consider completely wrong.  I am pleased that you have addressed some major challenges that are not related to political integration, such as labour rights and public services, which you have united under the term social Europe. Europe must remain a bastion of workers' rights, but equally, if it wants to remain globally competitive, it must not kill entrepreneurship with high taxes and unnecessary regulation.  We are certainly on the verge of another recession and in this context we have to be very careful with public spending. I would especially recommend it to you, because Spain's long-standing deficit play can make a future crisis in Europe a real disaster.

name: Izaskun Bilbao Barandica (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, President Sánchez. Citizens hope that the Union will be useful, that it will provide a model of soulful, people-centred economic development that respects diversity, is built through voluntary and convinced accession.  That's where the Basque Nationalist Party has been in since the 1930s. From there we are ready to bring stability to our Union, contributing to it in a State facing four challenges: transforming its model of development; strengthen their social protection system; bet on projects with European added value; and solve cohabitation problems that need dialogue and politics.  Faced with such complex problems, we saloit your willingness to escape simplism, a good principle that sounds much better than the well-known and failed recipes sold in thirty-second clips by fashion telepredicators.  We hope that good words will be transformed into budgets encouraged by these principles and a courageous commitment to coexistence that assumes that, although outside the law, nothing is possible, only with the law, either. Much less, if it twists to turn a political problem into a criminal case, as has happened in Catalonia.  That's what these photographs report. Count on us if you decide to bet on the complex, the empathetic, the humanist, the European, so useful to be able to build coexistence and solutions.

name: Florent Marcellesi (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President. Mr Sánchez, we saloon the progress of the draft budgets in Spain, because they remind Europe that another, more social, greener, path is possible. In the face of market Europe and hate Europe, there is another solidarity and sustainable Europe that is watching and calling for more ambition. More ambition is to dare with a human migration policy. Mr Sanchez, are you going to end the gag law and the hot returns of immigrants and refugees? Are you going to allow ships, like the Open Arms, to keep saving lives in the Mediterranean? More ambition is also to dare to lead an ecological and just transition that leaves no one behind. If you really bet on the Paris Climate Agreement, clean energy and jobs, are you going to put a closing date on coal plants and nuclear power plants? It's in your hands, show in favor of what Europe is.

name: Lara Comi (PPE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, good morning, Mr President, welcome to the European Parliament.  You spoke a lot about women, women's rights and violence against women. I hope, however, that next time we can also present with a somewhat female staff, since today there are only men present, because from words to deeds I think it is also a greater plus, so this is a wish.  Since Italy and Spain have always had a good relationship, including on the starting point of immigration, I think that you can be the spokesman, at the level of the Mediterranean countries, for the Dublin reform, because when it is said that Europe has left us alone, and I say this as an Italian, there is a first and last name called the European Council, there is a name and surname called the Member States. The European Parliament voted in favour of the Dublin reform, in favour of compulsory returns, but we need you and the other prime ministers to come to an agreement. On the subject of violence against women, we in the PPE are in favour of a budget and also a link that can be that of family and work, and we think that women are ennobled even more with work and not by staying at home or simply being a housewife by obligation and not by choice.

name: Markus Ferber (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank My request, if you compare Catalonia and Bavaria, would be that the facts are correct and that you are now listening. In Bavaria, there was only once an independence movement of the ultra-left more than 100 years ago, at a time when the Federal Republic of Germany – or the German Reich at that time – was non-existent. There is a big difference to the catalones and therefore please do not make these comparisons, which do not fit. Secondly, you have now told here what must be done at European level. I would also have liked to hear what your government is doing. It is not enough to call for a European unemployment insurance scheme if, on the other hand, you withdraw measures from the previous government aimed at liberalising the labour market. In other words, growth in jobs in Spain is falling significantly.  They themselves do not take action to create more employment for young people. I would have liked to have heard something. It is not only enough to call for European solidarity, but it is also part of taking your own measures. Subsidiarity and solidarity go hand in hand.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank you for your support. We are debating the future of Europe today, when european democratic systems are facing huge challenges. Today, for example, Europe cannot deal with the fact that the government of one of its Member States has started to build an illiberal system by denying democracy. Yes, I am talking about Viktor Orban's Hungary, where the prime minister's friend in a few years could go from a mere rural gas fitter to the richest man in the country. Where the government has built a state media machine from the public media and completely dominates the Hungarian media. Where opposition MPs are physically abused and the authorities do nothing. Where, while some people get incredibly rich with public money, more than 100,000 children are starving. Where the prosecutor's office constantly covers corruption cases committed by the government, but constantly launches conceptual proceedings against the opposition and civilians. Prime Minister, your country, Spain, has very successfully gone from dictatorship to world-renowned and respected democracy in recent decades. I ask you what we need to do at European level to stop dictatorships in Europe, in the Union, from being re-formed.

name: Mark Demesmaeker (ECR).
text: Mr President, Mr Sánchez, on 21 December I was still in Barcelona. You were there at the time. I wanted to visit four Catalan prisoners who had just ended their hunger strike. It is not for me to judge their political project or their strategy, but what I do not accept is that people have been imprisoned for more than a year and risking severe punishment, accused of rebellion.  I can assure you that no one has seen a dangerous rebellion with us, and neither has the judiciary in my country, in Germany and in Switzerland, because the Catalan exiles are free. We do politics through dialogue, not through the courts. Mr. Weber misses the point when he talks about dangerous nationalism. Yes, it lives in Spain, but not in Catalonia. It is in the form of a dangerous neo-franquism. I hope, Mr Sánchez, that you overcome your political fear of the far right, that you engage in a real dialogue and that you release the political prisoners.

name: Ramon Tremosa i Balcells (ALDE).
text: – (The rapporteur begins his speech in Catalan). Mr President, Mr Sánchez, the previous Government of Spain last year created a terrible precedent in the European Union, imprisoning peaceful social leaders, ministers of the Catalan Government and the president of the Catalan Parliament for authorizing a debate. Spain is now closer to Turkey than to Britain, which agreed and authorized an independence referendum in Scotland.  In Catalonia there is a growing majority in favour of a referendum, which is not a crime in the Spanish Penal Code for a zapatero reform in 2005.  And one last question. Commissioner Almunia was in favour of the use of Catalan in this House. We asked PSOE deputies if it was possible today to speak Catalan. Federalism is speaking each other's language. What day can we speak in Catalan in this House?  And finally, in Catalonia there is not a conflict of coexistence, but of Spanish centralism. And it is in the referendum that all majority converges. In the dialogue you will find us.

name: Pilar del Castillo Vera (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Sánchez, let me begin by telling you that says the Spanish saying of 'works are loves and not good reasons'. You talk about extremism, you talk about the rhetoric of exclusionary identities, and the problem is that, in reality, in reality as president of the Government of Spain, you do not practice any of this. From minute one, from the minute a motion of trust ended Mr Rajoy's presidency, you are in the hands of political parties — Catalan independenceists — who are exclusionary in their practical rhetoric, and not just in rhetoric, who have tried to break the constitutional order, who break the law and who have no institutional loyalty. Mr President, you can come here, you can tell a story, but when in the end reality and facts differ in such a remarkable way, everyone, beyond our own borders, the Spanish ones, find out and find out. You have to be consistent and you're not. He's proved it one more time.

name: Georgi Pirinski (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I would like to address the Prime Minister. You mentioned the need for new legitimacy for democracy in Europe and you appealed for more European democracy. Don’t you feel that people feel deprived of their sovereignty, of the right to decide their own future? Regions are being massively depopulated, deindustrialised. The people working there feel they have no say as to how their lives will develop. What would you say about the notion of sovereign democracy, which in a new way matches the will of the people to have a say in their future, and join this with the understanding that Europe has to have a new beginning. This challenge, Prime Minister, is central to every issue that was up for discussion, from Brexit to Catalonia.

name: José Ignacio Salafranca Sánchez-Neyra (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr President of the Spanish Government, welcome to the European Parliament.  You said and rightly said that the European Union is a value-based union. That is why this Parliament has an indeclinable and inderogable commitment to the cause of human rights, which must not be preached from a region, from a country, from a continent, but must be planetary or universal in nature.  That is why this Parliament has instituted an award for freedom of conscience named after Andrei Sakharov, who left a legacy of moral integrity and peaceful coexistence among peoples.  This Parliament has awarded the Sakharov Prize to three Cuban dissidents: Oswaldo Payá, Guillermo Fariñas and the Ladies in White. And last year to Venezuela's democratic opposition. I would like to ask you what opinion this Award deserves. Do you think that awardees to this Award are honorable people who defend their freedom and dignity?  Have you been to Cuba? You haven't met with them? I ask him: Would you be willing to meet with them?  And, with regard to Venezuela, Mr President of the Government, this Parliament has adopted by a large majority a resolution calling for the European Union and its Member States to join the lawsuit filed with the International Criminal Court for serious human rights violations in that country.  What do you think of this initiative? Do you think, like other Member States — Germany, France, Canada — to join this proposal?

name: Elena Valenciano (S&D).
text: –Mr. President. You see, Mr President of the Government of Spain, that you must have thought that the People's Party was already mourned from Spain for losing the motion of censure, but no. Actually, we haven't heard a single idea about Europe. That said, they cried over spilled milk. And it has also become very clear, here in this House, that the patriotism of the People's Party is absolutely intermittent. I mean, they demand PSOE patriotism when the PSOE is in opposition, but they don't give us a bit of patriotism when we're in government. In any case, and to consolidate the idea that you have brought to this House, which seems to me central, airs of populism blow, airs of national populism blow, airs of rupture blow, of fracture in Europe, airs of extremism blow, airs of reaction blow: a reaction against European unity, a reaction against the strength of the Union, a reaction against the strength of women. It's a national-populist reactionary movement that claims to have no complexes. Well, neither do we, Mr. President. Go ahead, Europeanists, progressives without complexes!

name: Rosa Estaràs Ferragut (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr President Sánchez, welcome to this House.  Europe is the world's first destination and Spain is the second country, after France, where more tourists go and the second country from which the most income is received, after the United States. The tourism sector has its proven strength.  But tourism, in addition to innovation, sustainability and quality in services, needs security and stability. And that's what I want to talk to you about.  You owe your Government to the same people who fight tourism, who demonize it, who really expel common sense from daily life with vandalism — in Gandia, in the Balearic Islands, in Valencia, in Catalonia — by undermining coexistence.  Mr President, when there is no stability, it is a dart in the waterline of the entire tourism sector and the coexistence of a country.  Europe gives us an example, every day, of strength, principles and convictions, but you strive, every day, to go in a different direction. It deliberately promotes division among citizens: it is tolerant of the intolerant, irresponsible with those who want to fight Europe and the institutions.  To combat authoritarianism, the best medicine is to comply with the law. That is why I ask you to return to the path of Europe and to govern with a pact, but as long as it is not secret and that it is by the ballot box.

name: Evelyn Regner (S&D).
text: Mr President, Prime Minister, I would like to thank the Prime Minister for his excellent work and for the work she has done. Thank you very much for this inspiring speech for a Europe for people. A speech that gives hope and courage. My question is addressed to you on the women's issue. We have on the table a fixed and ready-negotiated report that was voted on in Parliament a long time ago, which states that women and men should have the same opportunities to progress on supervisory boards. What can we expect? How can we get you here as an ally? They are absolutely in favour of it.  I am now addressing President Tajani with this question: do you also look at the fact that there are really enough women when giving the speaking time? Here is an absolutely unbalanced relationship. In order to be able to articulate these women's issues, we also need the voice of women, who can also make greater contribution to the European Parliament by giving them the floor.

name: Presidente. –
text: I would remind you that I am one of the signatories of the European Commission's proposal to give more seats to women on boards. I was the second signatory at the time. I give the floor to Mr Beazley. Armor Bildt. You see women talking.

name: Anna Maria Corazza Bildt (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I say to the Prime Minister: I share your concerns about the anti-EU rhetoric from the extreme right and the need to recover the legitimacy of the European institutions. This Parliament has been voting across political and national boundaries, constantly regularly for a single seat of the European Parliament. We want to be able to decide when and where to meet. Chancellor Angela Merkel and Sebastian Kurz showed leadership last year and took a clear public position in favour of one location for the European Parliament. Are you, as pro-European, willing to take a stand, to put it on the agenda of the Council, to talk to the people of Europe and of Spain during the election campaign about that and to engage in a constructive dialogue – a pro-European, pro-democracy dialogue – or are you going to ignore it and risk letting a symbol of peace, a reconciliation in Europe which is so dear to us all, to become a symbol of waste?

name: Christine Revault d’Allonnes Bonnefoy (S&D).
text: Mr President, dear Prime Minister, thank you for your speech. Thank you for this speech, which gives the European Union a new colours of hope by highlighting social issues, ecological issues, issues of solidarity and values, as well as European budgetary issues, where you have been extremely ambitious in view of the fact that 1% of the Member States' GDP is not enough to have strong European proposals. You have also gone a long way in daring to talk about federal Europe; it is a pleasure to hear and I thank you for that. I wanted to go back to the situation in Andalusia. We are very concerned here and we absolutely need to stop any form of ambiguity, any form of unnatural alliance between right-wing and far-right forces. This is absolutely outrageous. Know that you can count on us to always mark this coherence and alliance with progressive leftist and environmentalist forces.

name: Carlos Iturgaiz (PPE).
text: – Mr President, allow me to make a motion of order, first of all, because I would like to reject and regret that posters of alleged excarcerated criminals are allowed, which are disrespectful to this House and to the interveners, in this case, the President of the Government of Spain.  Mr. President.  Mr Sanchez, you have come here asking to protect the European model, among other things, from the extremist ideologies that threaten it. Let me tell you that this saying of 'advice I give, which I do not have for me', can be applied to you. Because you, Mr Sánchez, are talking about the danger of extremism in Europe, which is true, but at the same time, please explain to this House and to the whole of Europe that you are president of the Government of Spain thanks precisely to these extremists. That is, the Catalan nationalist coupistas, the Rotten Chavistas, the Batasuna proetarras of Bildu, who are the political arm of the ETA terrorists, with whom, by the way, you are ufana to share tablecloths in certain shameful meals. I would do better by explaining what you are doing, Mr Sánchez, governing with those who are the greatest slug in Spanish politics and the whole of the European Union.

name: Javi López (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Mr Sánchez, today brought here the voice of the Europeanists who believe in a Europe (inaudible words) the voice in the world. A social Europe that cares about job precariousness, child poverty and wants to improve workers' conditions. An environmental Europe that leads the fight against climate change in the world. An open Europe that makes tolerance its raison d'eer and that fulfils its international obligations in terms of refuge from solidarity and responsibility. And a feminist Europe that makes gender equality one of its flags.  That is the Europe that the Government of Spain is defending today, a voice that we Europeans need and which is well received by this House.  A Europe that, moreover, understands that its future will only go through the construction of a common, joint citizenship that makes coexistence, dialogue, its raison d'e miss. And, moreover, it brings the voice of a new Government that has also entered a new political stage in my land, in Catalonia: a stage of dialogue, self-government, constitution, a stage of respect for coexistence, which seeks political outings.  That is what the new Government of Spain has brought and is the only solution for the future of Catalans.

name: Gabriel Mato (PPE).
text: – Mr. President. Mr Sánchez, I hoped at least that here today, in Europe, in a speech that lasted thirty-seven minutes, I would spend at least ten seconds referring to the outermost regions of the European Union, including the Canary Islands. He's disappointing again. It tells us about the future of Europe, but the future Europe is necessarily linked to the future of the UPRs, regions recognised in the Treaty itself, far away and with peculiar characteristics, which need all the support. I know that for you the Canary Islands is nothing more than a tourist destination to spend the end of the year. But for this Parliament and for the European Union, the UPRs are much more than that: they are an opportunity and an example of what the policy of integration, cohesion and solidarity should be. President Tajani has repeatedly stated that the outermost regions are ultra-important. And it's true. I am confident that, after your time in this Parliament, they will also be so for you. Meet the Canary Islands. Comply with pending agreements. Defend the interests of the UPRs and have no doubt that from here, from the heart of Europe, you will have our full support.

name: Jonás Fernández (S&D).
text: – Mr. President. First of all, I would like to welcome to this House the President of the Government of my country, his entire government and, of course, his Foreign Minister, Josep Borrell, former President of this Parliament. I would like to highlight simply the word federalism from your intervention. The need to continue to claim the construction of a federal Europe, an idea that also serves the organization of our country, Spain, which is nothing more than the recognition of harmony, the ability to live in freedom and equality. A harmony that we need in the Union to protect citizens; a harmony that we need to protect the European Union, which needs to reform the monetary union as well. We need this fiscal pillar hand in hand, probably, with that unemployment insurance that the Government of Spain is defending and which in this House the Socialist Group has been fighting in recent years, and we have to build a majority in the next elections with the Commission, with the Council and with Parliament, in order to have unemployment insurance that protects citizens.

name: Francisco José Millán Mon (PPE).
text: – Mr. President. Since Spain's accession to the European Union, the Ibero-American question has been a priority for a Spanish leader. I wonder how today you have forgotten to quote not only Venezuela, but, for example, the very important negotiations with Mercosur, Mr President. In his speech I am concerned about not only what he says, but also absences. Another issue whose importance I would also like to stress is Brexit and, in particular, fisheries issues. I would ask you, in the context of the future negotiation with Brexit, which we will see how it ends, to pay priority attention not only to Gibraltar, which deserves it, but also to the issues of fisheries, reciprocal access to water and resources. There are many interests at stake, Europeans, Spaniards and also in my region, of Galicia. And I'm done. I am pleased with the accounts and budgets of the European Union, and I would like to point out that the new Multiannual Financial Framework and the Commission's legislative texts do not leave some Spanish regions, which may suffer serious funding cuts, in a good place. Please pay attention to that point as well.

name: Michael Detjen (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Mr President, Minister, I am pleased that you are giving us the honour today. We have high hopes in you that with your new style of politics, which is to listen to the needs of the people, you will bring Spain forward. I can tell you that many people in Germany also have a very positive image of the new Social Democratic government. Instead of confrontation, you rely on negotiation and moderation, instead of backward-looking policies, you are counting on better protection of women, instead of pure austerity, you are striving for economic incentives and economic growth and a balanced budget. I would ask you to tell us what the implementation of new labour market laws can look like; Your previous Conservative government disenfranchised workers by neoliberal means. What can you do to re-strengthen the position of workers?

name: Pedro Sánchez Pérez-Castejón
text: President of the Government of Spain. – Mr President, thank you to all the MEPs who have taken the floor. First, I want to thank you for the tone; secondly, I also thank you — why not say it — for the intensity of the interventions, because I believe that it also encourages the debate, especially after having to listen to many interventions, a significant number of interventions of different signs and different orientations.  If it seems to you, what I will do will logically be to answer you as a whole, not individually, and I will also do so around two axes which I think you can sum up not only the spirit of my first speech, but also the spirit and content of the responses in this reply to the interventions of each Of The Members: firstly, , multilateralism and, secondly, as a Spanish socialist MEP has said before, federalism.  With regard to multilateralism, I said in my first speech, ladies and gentlemen, that the Government of Spain believes, defends Agenda 2030, not only from the point of view of a political agenda of transformation at national level, but we also believe that in the next decade the European Union has to be the great ambassador, the great activist of the 2030 Agenda in the multilateral order.  There is, for example, this 2030 Agenda, which makes a closed and unequivocal defense of gender equality; is absolutely incarnating with the approach I have made to all of you in relation to the European Gender Equality Strategy. Or also what we are doing at the Spanish level with the adoption of a series of measures related to the fight against gender-based violence, but also with the implementation of the State Pact against gender-based violence or the adoption of laws that reduce the gender pay gap, and labour equality between men and women.  In this matter, I would also like to say one thing: there have been some people who have spoken of unemployment, which is absolutely unacceptable still in Spain, in comparative terms with other countries of the European Union and in terms of average of the euro area and the European Union. But I will also tell you one thing: right now in Spain there are around 19 million affiliates and affiliates, and it is the first time in the history of Social Security that 48% of social security members in our country are women. More than eight million women have found work, are affiliated with Social Security and are integrated into the labour market.  I will also tell you one thing: the move that the Government of Spain has approved to increase the interprofessional minimum wage by 22%, that is, the most important increase that has been taken since 1977 in the history of our country, in the democratic history of our country, benefits, by 70%, especially women, who are the ones who are charging , unfortunately, a lower salary and are therefore the perceptors of the interprofessional minimum wage.  Therefore, gender equality, child poverty...  The fight against child poverty is also one of the main axes of the 2030 Agenda. We here have not only raised to the House the need to reinforce this proposal for the 'child guarantee', but we are also raising the same thing at the level of Spain.  In the general budgets of the State that we presented in the Courts last Monday, what we do is a determined commitment in the fight against child poverty, reinforcing – and much – everything related to child guarantee — if we could call it or translate it this way – in the field of Spanish politics.  With regard to climate change, there have been some stakeholders who have spoken about the degree of commitment of the Government of Spain in relation to this issue. We will approve in a very short period of time, I hope, in the General Courts, presented by the Government of Spain, a climate change law, a national ecological transition plan or strategy, where, if I may say so, one of the fundamental issues — at least for the Government of Spain — is that this transition is fair, that is, that those mining basins , those areas of Spain where there is a strong presence of thermal power plants can find opportunities and that, logically, make understandable to those affected, the main affected, the need to make that transition.  And finally, reference has been made to a comprehensive package of rights, of freedoms which, unfortunately, during seven years of conservative rule were launched by the previous Administration.  There has been talk of the 'gag law', there has also been talk of everything that has to do with labour reform and the labour rights of workers in our country.  And two questions. The first, in relation to the "gag law". It is currently in the process of amendments, in presentation at the Congress of Deputies, and I hope that it can be resolved and approved by the General Courts at the session to be opened from February. Secondly, with regard to labour rights, I would like to tell you that the Government of Spain has promoted social dialogue, which has approved in seven months – in just seven months – a youth employment plan to reduce the youth unemployment rate by three years by ten points and mobilize EUR 2 billion.  We have also approved a plan to combat labour exploitation, a plan to combat labour precariousness, which has brought out more than 50,000 jobs, which were not, say, in line with our country's legislation and are now indefinite hires.  And finally, I would also like to tell you, in this area, that you know that self-employed people, that is to say, employed workers in our country, who amount to more than three million people, men and women, thanks to an agreement we have reached with trade unions and employers in just seven months have been strengthened by all the social guarantees linked to unemployment benefit and also to coverage in accidents at work , et cetera, et cetera, et cetera. And we have done this, logically, with the hand of social agents and also entrepreneurs. Therefore, multilateralism, a clear social agenda on the part of the Government of Spain, not only at European level, but also at national level, and I also wanted to make two added reflections that have emerged in line with the interventions.  With regard to foreign policy and linked to Venezuela, I would like to tell you that the Government of Spain, but I too, as leader of the opposition before elected president of the Government, did not recognize the legitimacy of the Venezuelan elections, nor have we acknowledged the Maduro regime at all. The proof is that we have not been present at the inauguration. We have consistently called on, on the recurring occasions, for the Maduro regime to release political prisoners – there are political prisoners there. Thanks to the good efforts of the Minister for Foreign Affairs, we have also managed to enable some political prisoners – the last, a young boy with which I had the opportunity to meet – and, without a doubt, the approach that the Government of Spain has with the question of Venezuela is to try to forge an alliance, a group to facilitate dialogue , both in European countries and in Lima Group countries.  I would also like to make a point. France has not participated in the decision taken by the Lima Group, and I can also assure you that the Government of Spain is not in that idea. The Spanish Government is trying to build a facilitation group which, precisely, it does is allow a dialogue to resolve, once and for all, the Venezuelan crisis.  I was surprised that when we talk about Venezuela, let us not talk about the migration crisis in Venezuela, because one of the main – say – affected are our asylum offices in Spain, because there are many Venezuelans and Venezuelans who are seeking asylum in our country. But neither of the migration crisis that exists throughout the Latin American continent and, in particular, in Colombia, in Peru, in Brazil, in Chile..., in many countries with which I have had the opportunity to meet during these seven months as president of the Government.  I have to tell you that, at the Foreign Affairs Council, the Foreign Minister – and also the Government of Spain as a whole – has advocated the unlocking of economic resources to help these countries to be able to manage in a at least reasonable way the huge amount of migration flows that are reaching those countries and, in the first place, Colombia which , logically, it has all our support.  On the Canary Islands, I would just like to tell you that the Government of Spain..., that thanks also to this Government, the renewal of the Statute of the Canary Islands has been processed in just over seven months and all the agreements that were pending to be signed have been signed in a timely and form. Therefore, it is not that we believe in the outermost regions, not that we believe in the opportunities, in the rights of the Canary Islands, but that we are exercising them with the signing, for example, of a road agreement for 1.8 billion euros – nothing more and nothing less – to be managed by the Canary Government.  And finally, I would like to reflect, a global reflection on some of the interventions most linked to the People's Party and also to the question of Catalonia.  I said it in the Spanish Parliament. I would also like to raise it with the Members of the European People's Parliament who are of my nationality, who are Spanish. I want to tell you that, right now, the right agenda is being set by the far right. And it is being marked by the far right on two fundamental issues that are typical when the right is in opposition: the first, territorial grievance and using Catalonia, that is, coexistence and territorial cohesion, as an element and as an ariete to make opposition to the Government of Spain.  The Government of Spain , the Spanish Socialist Workers' Party – is and will always be loyal to the Constitution. And we are in opposition and we are in government. And we would also like the People's Party to do the same when it is in opposition.  And secondly, if I have to look to find some governance formulation that gives stability, whether in regions or in countries, I like the Swedish example more than the example we have just seen in Andalusia. (Applause)

name: El presidente. –
text: Thank you very much, Mr President of the Government of Spain, thank you for answering members' questions.  I think this debate has been a very interesting debate. There has been a lot of talk about Spain, but also a lot about Europe and politics in Venezuela.  It's a very important thing for us. We defend the rights of Venezuelan citizens. You cannot starve in that country, where there is neither democracy nor freedom.  Thank you all. The debate is closed. Written statements (Article 162 of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: in writing. – I appreciate that you want a Europe in which we guarantee the rights of work of all citizens, in which we protect the most vulnerable. You want a united Europe, signaling that inequalities in the EU have increased. Many of my fellow citizens work in Spain and I would be happy to apply these principles to any European citizen living in Spain. That is why, Prime Minister, I ask you what you think of Austria's decisions to discriminate against children, mothers by nationality? I know, Prime Minister, that you have measures to support young people up to 30 years of age. But I have received messages from my fellow citizens living in Spain, telling me that for those over 30 there is no measure. Do not grant dual citizenship and this creates great problems for European citizens who are of another nationality. You are pro-European and must, Prime Minister, improve access to the labour market in your country and take precedence over the criterion of vocational training and not nationality, religion, gender. I hope that Spain will act for the non-discriminatory application of the Treaty and the exclusion of the double measure. I ask you, Prime Minister, to support the entry of Romania and Bulgaria into the Schengen area because they have been meeting the conditions since 2011.

name: Daniele Viotti (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am only stealing one minute of this House's time from the votes, because several journalistic sources confirm that a very harsh repression of the homosexual population has resumed in Chechnya: dozens of arrests, many tortures and three deaths have been identified, because of a regime that tends to repress these people simply because they are homosexual.  This Europe cannot be just economics and finance. In relations with Russia – I thank High Representative Mogherini because he reminded Mr Lavrov of this – but, in relations with Russia, there cannot be only economic issues. We are the world champions of human rights, of civil rights, we must prove it. We must strongly call on the Russian Federation to open an investigation into what is happening in Chechnya, because it is intolerable that people should be killed by a regime because they are homosexuals.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is voting time. (For the results of the votes and other details concerning them: see Minutes)

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would just like to remind you that our friends from Morocco, from the Moroccan Parliament, are sitting on the observation points, so I would like to welcome them through you.

name: Presidente. –
text: Of course, we greet the Moroccan delegation, thank you for being here.

name: Maria Arena
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, the European Transition Fund scheme recognises the need for a solidarity tool for workers affected by retraining, and I welcome this. I would like here, however, to draw the attention of my colleagues to an amendment, Amendment 96, which aims to give the economic sector the opportunity to support economic conversion following a major crisis. It is important to give priority to workers, it is also important to give priority to companies in order to have a concrete response in terms of job creation. That is what I am proposing in Amendment 96, and I hope that I will have the support of this House.

name: Verónica Lope Fontagné
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, in accordance with Article 59(4) I request that the report be returned to the committee to begin institutional negotiations.

name: Pascal Arimont
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank all the colleagues who have worked on this text, which was also adopted unanimously in committee. Following yesterday's Brexit vote in London, it is reassuring and a good hopeful sign that the vast majority in this House stand for cross-border cooperation. That's what Interreg stands for. Thank you very much for that. With this in mind, I would also ask the House to refer this report back to committee for interinstitutional negotiations under Rule 59(4) of the Rules of Procedure.

name: Presidente. –
text: That concludes voting time.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the Globalisation Fund has the potential to make a real contribution to supporting employment. Because at a time when globalisation has led to huge unemployment, to the outsourcing of businesses and to the blow of small and medium-sized enterprises, I believe that the Globalisation Fund can support and have supported the effort so that the unemployed can both be trained and, of course, receive financial support. Unfortunately, in Greece so far the funds of this Fund have not been used, which could have really contributed to ease somewhat the poverty of the Greek people that has occurred with the memoranda over the years. From then on, the new regulation will also provide the opportunity for further support in relation to unemployment caused by automation and new technologies.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Mr President, in the Committee on Budgets (BUDG), we regularly receive and approve reports on the Globalisation Adjustment Fund. Nobody wants to consider these reports because of the circumstances, but it gives us concrete action to assist people who have been thrown out of work in large-scale redundancies. We’ve had them recently from AirFrance, from Nokia, from Almaviva, major department stores in Finland, in the retail sector in Greece, textiles in Portugal and so on. I’m proud of the fact that the European Union is able to offer solidarity to people in the most difficult of circumstances.  The new Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) will make available around EUR 1.6 billion over the course of the years. I accept and welcome the changes in this report that simplify and broaden the scope of the fund, and that move towards proactive and just transition funding. Since 2007 to July, there were only 161 cases from 21 Member States. Unfortunately, the UK Government didn’t participate in any of them.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I support the idea of a European Globalisation Adjustment Fund to help industries and areas in transition and to respond to the challenges of an ever-changing global economy presenting all the challenges that brings, whether it be new technology, artificial intelligence, automation, moving to a low-carbon and zero-carbon economy.  I urge colleagues to learn the lessons of recent history, particularly in parts of the UK, where that move has seen people lose good, well—paid jobs in industries like coal mining and steel, with those jobs being replaced with low-paid, precarious jobs on zero-hour contracts. In bringing forward funds, such as the Transition Fund and the Globalisation Adjustment Fund, I would urge colleagues across the European Union to be mindful not just of creating jobs, but to be mindful of the types of jobs we are creating as well. We want good, well-paid jobs with dignity.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, as a result of globalisation, the restructuring of companies puts many workers at risk. However, I don’t claim that globalisation is a negative phenomenon, it brings us enormous opportunities that our parents did not have. However, what we need now is more solidarity, and I want to thank Maria Arena, my Socialist colleague from Belgium, for keeping this spirit in her report. I welcome the amendments that speak about the technological, energy and environmental aspects of globalisation. It brings significant added—value to the Commission proposal. However, tackling globalisation is not possible without adjusting social policies. If you look at Latvia, my country, low birth rates and high levels of emigration are changing the face of our labour industry very rapidly. As a report by the Baltic Centre for Investigative Journalism concluded, almost half of all Latvian residents would be over 50 years old by 2030. That is why the EU must help our country or it will be made up of pensioners.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome the report on the Globalisation Adjustment Fund to provide support to those who have lost their jobs as a result of major structural changes in world patterns due to globalisation, or as a result of economic or financial crises. I particularly welcome some of the provisions proposed to reduce the level of redundant workers from the original figure of 500 down to 200, and it is very important for smaller countries such as Ireland – and indeed for SMEs – to reduce that threshold, because it has been difficult to qualify under previous provisions.  The Globalisation Adjustment Fund has been enormously successful in Ireland.
