There have been at least 10 projects that have qualified including Dell in Limerick, TalkTalk in Waterford, and Andersen in Limerick, as well as Lufthansa. So I welcome the provision, and it is important to say that this complements national measures that are there to support workers and reintegrate them into the workforce.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – A Uachtaráin, cosúil le mo chomhghleacaí, Deirdre Clune, fáiltím roimh an tuarascáil seo agus molaim go bhfuil sé glactha againn an Coiste seo a leathnú air feadh a lán blianta eile.  Ó bunaíodh is in 2007, bhí caiteachas de €611 mhilliún aige agus tháinig sé i gcabhair ar 147,000 duine. Do dhaoine a bhí dífhostaithe, thug sé jabanna nua dóibh, traenáil, cáilíochtaí oideachais agus, i gcuid de na cásanna, thug sé seans dóibh a ngnó féin a bhunú. Molaim go háirithe, go bhfuil an t-uasphointe íslithe ó chúig chéad go dhá chéad agus cabhróidh sé sin go háirithe le daoine in áiteanna tuaithe a bheidh ag cailliúint a jabanna.  Dá bhrí sin, is iontach an Coiste é, taispeánann sé go bhfuil croí agus comhbhá an Aontais beo fós.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, austerity and violent fiscal adjustment have filled Europe with armies of unemployed people and millions of poor people. This policy, unfortunately, continues to this day and any measures that come to be added to ease the consequences of this policy through the European Social Fund cannot strike evil at its root. In any case, the funds of the European Social Fund+ should be used by the regions, used by the countries of the European South, really go to support training and training, in particular support the long-term unemployed, and also support poverty, which is hitting the European Union, and too many actions should be taken to strengthen the social state. Measures and funds which the Member States, and in particular the countries of the European South which have been hit by the Memorandums, should make the best use of.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, I voted in favour of the report on the new European Social Fund +, as it aims to address key social challenges. Tackling child poverty, youth unemployment and the existing mismatch between education systems and the labour market must be key priorities. Otherwise, the European Union will continue to face strong economic and social pressures that threaten the well-being of our citizens. I believe that overcoming inequalities must start from an early age, and that is why I welcome the allocation of 5% of the European Social Fund + to the implementation of a European Child Guarantee Scheme. Child poverty is a phenomenon that affects almost half of children in Bulgaria who are deprived of access to health, education and care. These statistics sound shocking to a country that has been a member of the European Union since 2007. It is our duty to provide a development perspective for young people to stop the depopulation of the regions.

name: Andrejs Mamikins (S&D).
text: – Mr President, it is a big asset of this report that the Member States can flexibly channel the money into the most urgent matters, be it the labour market, working conditions, social protection, education or health protection. However, it is crucial that the Commission carries out oversight of how and on what this money is spent. I say this because some countries, such as Latvia, have very specific issues. In Latvia the Russian-speaking minority, accounting for 24% of the population, is not allowed to pursue higher education in the Russian language, and according to the new school reform, our children will not be able to study in their native language from September 2019. The youth unemployment rate in Latvia reached almost 11% in December 2018. This is a clear sign that our young people simply cannot take an academic or professional path due to a very restrictive and discriminatory language policy. We should stop it.

name: Rory Palmer (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the last time I checked there was not a shortage of food in the European Union. The shelves of our supermarkets and our markets tend to be well stocked, but there is a food poverty emergency across this Europe, in every Member State. We are seeing queues growing all the time at food banks and emergency food poverty projects, many of them now funded by European Social Fund (ESF) monies.  One thing we can do to prevent that food poverty emergency becoming even worse in my own Member State would be to rule out right now a no-deal Brexit because it will not be the millionaires on the back benches of the Conservative Party in the House of Commons that will pay the highest price of a no-deal Brexit, it will be the people queuing at food banks who will pay the highest costs of the economic catastrophe that ‘no deal’ will bring about, the higher food prices that will lead to higher queues at our food banks. That is unacceptable. That’s one reason why ‘no deal’ must be taken off the table immediately.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, we could not agree with the proposal to reduce investment in the European Social Fund of almost €7 billion and our proposal, the Proposal of the European Parliament, goes exactly in the opposite direction: a jump from the previous 96 to the new €106 billion.  This instrument is extremely important for new knowledge in the European Union, for new skills, for digital transformation, for preparing for new jobs, especially in relation to youth employment, and on the other hand for social solidarity or improving living conditions for people with disabilities, involving marginalised groups in everyday social life and, in particular, eradicating poverty, especially if it is related to child poverty. That is why we are asking for more resources and more activities focused on new knowledge and social solidarity.

name: Deirdre Clune (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I welcome Parliament’s proposal today to strengthen the Fund for the next period of funding up to 2027. The European Social Fund pulls together a series of funds: the Youth Employment Initiative, the focusing on those that are most disadvantaged, the EU health programme and the European social initiative. It focuses on unemployment, improving the employability of individuals, addressing poverty issues and focusing on social exclusion with a particular emphasis on young people and on children. So the value of this Fund – it is targeted directly at individuals, enabling them in developing skills for a modern economic era where we have automation, as we have spoken of already, and globalisation, and it will equip them with lifelong learning, which is becoming very important, and training.  I welcome this report. I think it’s very important that we would continue to support the ESF+, the European Social Fund Plus, as it benefits citizens directly in their communities.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, I welcome this proposal from the European Commission on the European Social Fund Plus for the period 2021-2027.  This is not just about employment and social inclusion, but this social fund remains part of cohesion policy and will include a European Youth Initiative and a number of other programmes that will continue to be part of cohesion policy. As it is now €106 billion, I think that is enough money that entails 27% of all cohesion policy at the moment.  I think it is good that the way these funds will be simplified, that there is more flexibility and that existing procedures will be optimised. In any case, this is a good step forward and I supported the European Social Fund plus with today's vote.

name: Nicola Caputo (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I voted in favour of the European Commission's proposal on the European Social Fund Plus, for the period 2021-2027.  A fund that will continue to promote employment and social inclusion, but which also aims to make progress in terms of strengthening the European social dimension. Support for young people must be maintained as the main objective. The youth unemployment rate is too high, especially in some areas. The European Social Fund Plus must implement tailor-made measures, in line with national youth guarantee schemes, paying particular attention to inactive young people, who are further away from the labour market.  The European Social Fund Plus should be used to improve the functioning of labour markets by supporting the modernisation of public employment services and by improving counselling and guidance services for workers.  Finally, given that the social disparities that exist in Europe are causing increasing concern, the European Social Fund Plus needs to allocate a large part of its budget for action to combat poverty and greater social inclusion.

name: Rosa D'Amato
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the extremely disappointing vote on the two amendments we tabled on the unbundling of national cofinancing from the calculation of the deficit, the consolidated text as voted in the Committee on Regional Development is satisfactory, so I voted in favour.  Despite the welcome effort to simplify the mixed architecture of territorial cooperation programmes, the Commission's proposal for a new regulation contained a number of critical issues, on which we have successfully intervened, both in the amending phase and in the negotiation phase, the result of which is reflected in the consolidated text as voted in the Committee on Regional Development.  Firstly, the report adopted has brought cross-border maritime programmes under the first axis. The change of architecture proposed by the Commission, which provided for only component two, transnational, for maritime cooperation programmes, was not only not functional to the needs of the regions, but was also not supported by sufficient elements, to introduce a radical change and thus undermine those maritime cooperation programmes, which are so important and strategic for Italy and other countries.  In terms of resources, the report provides for a total of EUR 11 billion, 10 billion of which will go to the first four components and about one billion to the new instrument for interregional investment in innovation.  Finally, the EU co-financing threshold has been raised to 80 %, raising pre-financing rates and programming levels 2014-2020 and thus giving regional and local authorities the liquidity they need to start projects on the ground.  It is also welcomed that all interreg components should contribute to the Sustainable Development Goals that small projects and people to people should be maintained and strengthened and that the new pilot component Number 5 should also focus on creating links between the least developed and the most developed regions, increasing the capacity to create those regional innovation ecosystems , which are therefore dedicated to bridging the gap between regions, both within states and from a transnational perspective.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, the Regional Development Fund, as we know, supports the regions and, of course, the Interreg programme has proved very important in strengthening cross-border relations and strengthening the economic relations of the member states that are adjacent. At the same time, however, proximity can sometimes also be negative for some economies. Because we have states such as Bulgaria where there is low taxation and this has negative consequences for the prefecture of Evros, Drama and Serres, which are adjacent to Bulgaria, and this creates, one might say, a tax dumping. That is why Interreg must now be used to support those economies which are subject to unfair competition from neighbourhood countries and to help countries such as Greece now, in order to support economies, to support businesses, which are subject to unfair competition due to its proximity to Bulgaria, which is actually doing a tax dumping with very cheap and low VAT. , but also income tax.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, European territorial cooperation programmes are extremely important for strengthening European solidarity and unity. In particular, the first component, cross-border cooperation, and that is why I am pleased that we have accepted in Parliament to increase the amount for cross-border cooperation and that this allocation within the four components is nevertheless more on the side of cross-border cooperation than the Proposal of the European Commission.  We invest a total of 11 billion euros in these programmes. This is a significant amount that must be used efficiently and in as simple a way as possible. That is why I am pleased that a large number of amendments I have proposed regarding the simplification of the implementation procedure have entered the final text and that in the future we will still have lower administrative investments and burdens on the implementation side of these programmes, which the beneficiaries most often put into practice.  Likewise, the last component, innovation, is extremely important and I hope that we will be able to increase the overall envelope by 0.3% so that we can invest as much as we can in innovation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, my interest in this topic stems from the fact that I was shadow rapporteur for the opinion of the Foreign Affairs Committee on this topic.  In particular, I would like to thank those who have worked on the Regional Development Committee and who have contributed greatly to making this topic important in a way that we expect to simplify procedures, to make it easier to come up with funds, that of course there are controls, but that they are not multifaceted. That's the basic reason.  We know why Interreg was founded in the first place, that countries that share a border, whether on land or at sea, would achieve better cooperation. What this proposal says, these are small projects, from citizens to citizens, which is very important and I really welcome that and I hope that this report will also contribute to the fact that there is more flexibility, to better use, to reducing administrative barriers and that these projects will really benefit our citizens. The amount of €11 billion is not negligible, so I welcome the initiative and, of course, parliament which has corrected with its amendments that basic report.

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, with the report voted, we are giving a clear signal to the European Commission and the industry that, as regards the authorization and even use of plant protection products, things cannot remain as they are today. Full transparency must be required during the approval procedure. Should we also have a case similar to Dwayne Johnson - the American gardener who has cancer - to make that change happen? We need a more serious financial resource for the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA) and more resources to development of new non-chemical plant protection methods. Some of the current preparations pose a risk to beneficial pollinators, such as bees. Thus, in addition to endangering their health, we also threaten the biodiversity and livelihoods of beekeepers. Serious efforts are also needed to combat illegal imports of pesticides, as well as other preparations from third countries. More control of the Bulgarian CHECKPOINTs, such as an external border of the EU, is clearly urgent. Unauthorised preparations can pose a direct risk to the health of European citizens, but also indirect to many economic sectors.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I am very pleased to have participated as a substitute member in the work of the PEST Committee in recent months, pleased with the contribution we have made as the GUE/NGL Group to the definition of this report and also pleased with today's vote, which undoubtedly takes a step towards transparency following the worrying issue, as I also pointed out in efsa's Glyphosate report.  We would have liked to have seen an even more in line with the Stop Glyphosate campaign, but I believe that we have taken a step forward today. I would remind you that glyphosate is a non-selective herbicide, which has the same effect on all plants, even when it is used in different dosages, which does not disperse and does not decay easily. And I also want to mention an issue that concerns my land, the Puglia region because in Salento a large amount of glyphosate has been found in the soil, also following the Martina decree, which also obliges the use of pesticides in Salento, preferring the choice of chemical ones. There is still a long way to go, but today we have certainly taken a step forward.

name: Eleonora Evi (EFDD).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I too am pleased with the result of the vote on this important report on the procedures for authoring pesticides, so that Europe finally responds to the demands of millions of European citizens that toxic and dangerous products, not only for health, but also for the environment, for biodiversity, should finally be banned and, above all, that we should be able to have public and independent and, above all, transparent scientific assessments. That is the objective, the way forward, to ensure that scandals such as the Monsanto Papers and the authorisation of glyphosate no longer take place.  This Europe must put the health of its citizens and the protection of the environment and our territories at the centre.

name: Sylvie Goddyn (EFDD).
text: Mr President, this report on how pesticides are allowed in the European Union follows the serious failures of the European Food Safety Authority (EFSA). The glyphosate re-evaluation procedure and the "Monsanto papers" have shown that the system is fallible but, more importantly, probably corruptible. After nine months of special committee in the European Parliament, we are coming up with a very timid text. It only responds to the margin of the challenge of protecting the health of Europeans from pesticides. Nevertheless, I note the presence of some progress that will be decisive in the development of a thorough reform of the pesticide licensing processes. I have therefore voted in favour of this report, bearing in mind that we will have to, in one way or another, force EFSA to be more transparent in order to avoid conflicts of interest.

name: Emmanuel Maurel (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, we have just voted on recommendations to improve the effectiveness of systems for detecting and banning dangerous plant protection products. That is good, and everyone welcomes it, except that at the same time, the press reveals that one of the institutes working for the European Food Safety Authority had simply copied and pasted a large part of the reports of Monsanto, which is the manufacturer of glyphosate, which everyone here points out is dangerous.  We are in the face of a scandal and we cannot let that happen. We have to point the finger at those responsible. Parliament must hold both the Commissioner and the Director of the European Food Safety Agency to account, of course. If not, what is our credibility?  I think we should be proud to move towards better control and banning certain dangerous substances, but we must also know how to punish those responsible for such acts.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this report, it is necessary to tighten the rules on the authorisation of pesticides in Europe. It is good that we have quality in this way and we will have good uniform legislation for 28, 27 states in the future. I supported some of the amendments that brought even more vigorous regulation. I regret that, for example, an amendment to limit the testing of pesticides on animals has not passed. I supported this proposal. But i think the report is of good quality and the new legislation will certainly be better than the current one. So I am pleased that the proposal has passed and I consider the tightening of the authorisation procedure for the placing on the market of new pesticides to be extremely important, significant, and I think this part is the greatest benefit of the new legislation.

name: Dubravka Šuica (PPE).
text: – Dear Chairman, concerns about the excessive use of glyphosate have resulted in the establishment of an ad hoc Committee against pesticide use. I believe that the one-year work of this Committee was of very high quality, 30 members worked intensively on this, and this is one of the few reports that the ideologically opposing parties, right and left, have come very close to. So one of the few reports where we almost voted today. I think we're heading in the right direction.  What's important is that there are two stages of approval. One is at European level, when it comes to active substances, and the other is at national level, when it comes to the use of plant protection products. I think it's very good, that it's gradual and we're headed in the right direction because first of all, nevertheless, we have to take care of people's health here. When we talk about the future of the European Union, then health is number 1.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I supported this draft report. I think it is important to behave in a truly responsible and sustainable way. For example, not only in Europe and in other localities, and especially in the Czech Republic, glyphosate and other substances in agriculture are actually used excessively and these substances also act as non-selective. They are truly universal, destroying everything green. I think that alternatives to the use of these substances are now more affordable and we should bring as much transparency as possible to our decision-making.  I myself have to admit that, when I was still on the AGRI Committee, I was misled by just one study, which was not transparent and can actually be described as plagiarism, so it is good that we are moving in this direction by tightening the criteria and making the most possible transparency. That is why I supported this non-legislative report and hope that this environmental approach will win over more European Union policies.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the topical debate (Rule 153a) on Comprehensive European education, research and remembrance of the totalitarian past (2019/2500(RSP)).

name: Андрей Ковачев
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, Commissioner, Madam Minister, this year will mark 30 years since the fall of the communist regime in Eastern Europe. When this Parliament adopted the resolution on European conscience and totalitarianism 10 years ago, we launched the debate on forming a common reading on the history of Europe with condemnation of all totalitarian regimes of the twentieth century. By putting up a sign of equality between the suffering caused by both fascism and national socialism and communism. By rethinking them and learning from the tragic events of the history of the Western European peoples, as well as from the history of the peoples of Eastern Europe.  Lessons to be learned to promote democracy, the european unity we need today, the rule of law, respect for human dignity and freedom. At the same time, lessons have been learned to prevent the rise of hatred, xenophobia, the sowing of authoritarian or totalitarian ideas in European societies. Ten years later, my personal assessment is that for various reasons this debate did not take place. During this period, the European Union faced new challenges that it would surely have responded to more successfully if it had learned lessons from history. I think Europe today needs a restart of the debate. Right now, we're not doing enough to deal with the resurrection of the spirits of the past. Nationalism and populism are reinforced by a lack of memory and understanding of our history, the role of European integration in overcoming the deep wounds of totalitarian regimes in Europe. Singly enough to look at some countries where, frustrated by the precarious economic present and social inequality, young people support extremist far-right or far-left parties to see how great the danger of repeating the tragic mistakes of the past is. That is why it is so important to convey memory so that young Europeans do not become victims of political players who offer easy solutions to very complex societal problems. When we do not pass on the memory of past events, we allow young generations to be misled with propaganda and disinformation campaigns, both for national socialism and for communist regimes, who still enjoy nostalgia for not knowing about the scale and duration of their crimes. What this leads to is what we see very clearly in Russia and in other countries where there are worrying trends for an increase in nostalgia for Stalinism. There are different policies that individual Member States of the European Union implement, but one of them is universal and can be a model anywhere. And that's education. Through education, subsequent generations of Europeans, whether in Western, Central, Eastern, Northern or Southern Europe, need to get an idea of totalitarian regimes in the twentieth century and know that millions have been sacrificed for the freedom, democracy, human rights they have today. To know that freedom is not a given, and as Ronald Reagan used to say, is always a generation away from extinction and must be defended. Yesterday in this chamber we solemnly celebrated the 20th anniversary of the introduction of the euro, but it is worth remembering that the European Union is not only a common market and currency, but above all a guarantor of freedom, peace, democracy and respect for human rights on our continent. The European Union is a response to the horrors of totalitarianism, which oppressed and limited at the cost of millions of innocent victims, destruction and immeasurable suffering. Today, as we face the challenges of protecting our value system, we must, more than ever, aware of the threats of a lack of historical memory. Let us, with the help of education, preserve this unique project for the next generations of Europeans, instead of allowing them to fall victim to ignorance and manipulations that stubbornly plant nostalgia for bygone times of totalitarian regimes.

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, the topic of our debate today touches on the very core of our Union and what it stands for. The authoritarian and totalitarian regimes across Europe in the last century remain a dark chapter in our continent’s history. Our Union is based on the common values and the general principles of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights. Its aim is to uphold and promote these values, which, as we are all well aware, have been increasingly challenged in recent years. Fortunately, younger generations have not suffered under totalitarian regimes, yet there is now a risk that we are taking these common values and principles for granted. Our common values have enabled the longest period of peace in Europe. They remain a cornerstone of our democratic societies and they need to be safeguarded and constantly nurtured. Today we face a number of challenges that put our open societies at risk, be it through xenophobia, divisive nationalism, discrimination, disinformation or violent radicalisation, to name just a few. If we are fully to understand the present, an awareness and understanding of the past is crucial. A lack of knowledge about the origins of the Union and about the way in which it works increases the risk of discrimination. It also prevents citizens from developing informed opinions on the actions that the Union takes. On the other hand, knowledge about the diversity, heritage and traditions within the Union and its Member States promotes mutual respect, understanding and cooperation, which in turn can strengthen a common sense of belonging. We know that education can play a crucial role in promoting our common values and in promoting a better understanding of the Union and of each other. We are also all well aware that the Union’s competence in the field of education is limited and that Member States remain fully responsible for their education systems and for the design of their curricula. However, at a time when Europe is looking to the future and seeking to re-engage its citizens, especially young people, around an agenda of shared values, we believe it is important to create a sense of belonging among Europeans. In this spirit, the Member States have therefore made a number of commitments, as evidenced in various political statements, be they Council conclusions or recommendations, which provide a strong basis for cooperation in this area. At the Gothenburg Summit in November 2017, the EU heads of state and government chose education and culture as the first subject to be addressed under the new Leaders’ Agenda, underlining their resolution to do more in these areas. The Gothenburg discussions were followed by the conclusions of the European Council of December 2017, which highlighted how education and cultures are key to building inclusive and cohesive societies. In May 2018, the Council adopted a recommendation on promoting common values, inclusive education and the European dimension of teaching. This recommendation was a follow-up to the Paris Declaration of 2015, in which education ministers stressed the importance of the role that education can play in this respect. The commitments of the Paris Declaration are as relevant today as they were then. In addition to our efforts in this area at national level, we need to make the best use of the Union’s instruments and programmes, such as Erasmus+, Horizon, Creative Europe, Europe for Citizens and the European Solidarity Corps, the support initiatives that serve to promote our common values. We need to provide our young people with the skills and competencies to become active, informed and responsible citizens. Media literacy and critical thinking are crucial skills in today’s society. Our young people need to develop the critical analysis and understanding needed to cope with the ever—growing volume of information. They need to be aware of the need to identify correctly, and use, reliable sources of information and of the risk of disinformation. Finally, it is of the utmost importance to promote and encourage tolerance, mutual understanding and intercultural dialogue in order to secure a better future. The role of educational staff and their continuing professional development plays a key role in this respect. It is important to learn how to address difficult or sensitive topics or controversial issues and not to leave them unaddressed. Teachers need support in their new role in an ever more diverse classroom. This subject is closely tied in with the priorities of our Presidency. As our Prime Minister outlined yesterday, one of our main pillars is the Europe of common values. We aim to stimulate the solidarity and cohesion of the European Union by promoting policies on combating discrimination, ensuring equal chances and equal treatment, and by increasing the involvement of citizens, particularly young people, in the European debate. To conclude, I can assure you that this issue will remain high on the Council’s political agenda. Thank you for your attention.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, thank you very much for having put this important and very timely debate on the agenda. Learning about our history and analysing the complex forces at play between and within our societies is the basis for understanding the world we are living in today. Knowing about our past is also critical for building the future of our continent and our countries.  Let us not forget that the original underlying idea of the European integration project – ensuring that its dark history does not repeat itself and preserving our freedoms, shared values and ways of life – needs to be defended every day. Commemorating and teaching that past, as well as cultivating the memory of troubled times, are key to shaping a common future. It is important to include all totalitarian regimes – be they fascist, communist or others – as we do on the Europe-wide day of remembrance for the victims of these regimes, on 23 August each year.  The Commission supports remembrance, research and education in the field of totalitarianism in a variety of ways. Preserving the memory of Europe’s totalitarian past is one of the core themes of the current Europe for Citizens programme, which supports activities that encourage reflection on European cultural diversity and on common values. Funds are available for initiatives that reflect on the causes behind the rise of totalitarian regimes in Europe’s modern history and commemorate the victims of their crimes. Furthermore, Europe for Citizens is the Union’s main tool to support initiatives that raise awareness of and educate about the Holocaust. Each year the Commission invests EUR 3.5 million in these projects. Several operational grants support Holocaust memorials and education sites. Remembering the Holocaust needs to remain a priority. In that context, the EU has recently acquired permanent international partner status with the International Holocaust Remembrance Alliance. The Commission is also supporting the largest-ever EU-funded research initiative on the Holocaust, with EUR 8 million, through the Horizon 2020 project. It is called European Holocaust Research Infrastructure. Further, in the field of research, in 2015 and 2017 the Commission published calls under the Horizon 2020 programme to support research on cultural opposition in the former socialist countries and on improving mutual understanding among Europeans by working through troubled past. Take, for example, the project COURAGE which stands for - Cultural Opposition – Understanding the Cultural Heritage of Dissent in the Former Socialist Countries. This project has created the first digital database highlighting various forms of cultural opposition in former socialist countries. The project concluded that education and research on cultural heritage are crucial to support open pluralistic democracies. In the field of education, the Union supports and complements national policies aimed at better understanding our history and shared values. The current Erasmus+ programme has so far supported some 30 projects dealing with history and totalitarianism in the EU. These projects gave pupils and students the chance to learn about the past in a direct way and make changes in their own lives as a desired result. Last year, the Commission put forward a Council recommendation on promoting common values, inclusive education and the European dimension of teaching. Member States agreed on it after only several months; this was a real milestone. Never before has the EU said so clearly how important it is to promote our common values, to create a sense of belonging, to teach about the functioning values and origins of the EU, and, most importantly, learn about the complex cultural and historical experiences in our Member States.  The Commission strongly believes that education is also the most effective means of preventing antisemitism. This is why the Commission is co-funding a study entitled the Holocaust in Contemporary Education, a joint initiative with UNESCO.  Finally, we can raise awareness and understanding through our cultural heritage, and I am proud that the European heritage label has been awarded to sites of historical significance. Sites such as Poland’s historic Gdańsk shipyard or the Sighet memorial in Romania. Let me reassure you that the Commission will continue to promote remembrance of totalitarian regimes, whatever their ideological basis. Understanding our past is crucial if we are to live together and to build a better future for our continent.

name: Sandra Kalniete
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, the last century taught us a harsh lesson in how dangerous and unpredictable authoritarian regimes and dictatorships are. That’s why totalitarian crimes must not be repeated. We need education, research and remembrance to build immunity and resilience in our societies against every temptation of undemocratic solutions. Europeans need this knowledge in order to clearly recognise and resist nationalists, populists and radicals on both the left and the right and to prevent them from hijacking and denigrating our democratic values and brainwashing our open societies. The European Union was constructed against the backdrop of trauma brought about by National Socialism and Communism. Also, they defied ideology. They originated as groups of populists who used manipulation to grab power in order to build the most brutal regimes that claimed the lives of millions. The historical experience of Western Europe was Nazism, whereas Central and Eastern European countries have experienced both Communism and Nazism. These authoritarian regimes are our common legacy, and Europe must be able to speak in one language about this double legacy.  To this end, the Union should provide a framework and sufficient financial funding for comprehensive research into Europe’s totalitarianism – both totalitarianisms – as well as educational programmes and cultural projects. We also need the full opening up of historical archives to verify the historical lies.  We have to see the clear link between populism, extremism, autocracy and dictatorship around the world. Moreover, we have to act in response to mass violations of human rights be it in Russia, China, Iran or in jihadism or Islamism.

name: Petra Kammerevert
text: Mr President, I would like to make a mifful son, mr President, I would like to make a ido to the S&D Group. Mr President, I would like to thank the In the 20th century in particular, Europe has a history of aberrations, of crimes of war and injustice, but also of success: with the founding of the European Union, the fall of the Iron Curtain and the deepening of European integration. Democracy needs memory. Only those who are aware of the past can shape the future. The creation of the European Union and the common defence of the fundamental values of an open, liberal and pluralistic society are the lessons we have learned from the darkest chapter in European history of the 20th century. Looking into the past helps to find solutions for the present and the future by recognizing mistakes, making oneself aware of how this happened, and also by admitting guilt, even for actions that one is not responsible for. Willy Brandt's kneeling in Warsaw is the most notable example of such an admission of guilt. However, I warn against pursuing history politics with a culture of remembrance. This is not possible. History is always long, complicated, diverse and, above all, contradictory, even in its narrative itself. Culture of remembrance never claims to be absolute truth. There are historical facts that cannot be denied and discussed away. But a culture of remembrance that does not clarify contradictions and would try to tell events from only one perspective is pointless. Nothing like this unites. Remembrance culture succeeds whenever it clarifies breaks and acknowledges that classifications of black, white, winners, losers, heroes, perpetrators or victims often do not work like this and questions of guilt and complicity are not so easy to answer. A culture of remembrance succeeds when the doubt remains with oneself. In this respect, culture of remembrance also helps against populism. It urges us to review our own position. Thirty years after the fall of the Iron Curtain, we should remember that those who claimed absolute truth for themselves have fallen. Totalitarianism and populism have one thing in common: they do not demand a culture of remembrance, but stories of history from the point of view of the supposed victor. We should make this difference clear. That is what we should teach our children so that they are prepared.

name: Branislav Škripek
text: for the ECR Group – Thank you, Mr President, I will try to keep my time. A large proportion of us Members sitting in this Chamber of the European Parliament have experienced for themselves what it means to be a totalitarian regime that has ruled much of Europe for 40 years. I am the child of socialism, where our communist ideology-led government imagined how we would build a blissful socialism. There is now a man in front of you who, under the violent influence of this ideology, had to make promises as a child when I was a sparker, then a pioneer, then a unionist, that I would always build and defend the socialist homeland. But, it wasn't really what I really wanted. As a man from Czechoslovakia, where we were dogmatically taught that communism and socialism, the thesis of Marx, Engels, Lenin are the best that may be that God does not exist, and they prohibited him from speaking at all about his existence, and the government preached that the spread of the teachings of Jesus Christ was a bad thing. I therefore really consider it important that we educate our young people even in the dark part of our history. History needs to serve as a memento of the match precisely so that it does not happen again. The heroes of our time, whom I want to remind, serve us as role models for today. In Slovakia there is such a resistance warrior, soldier Jozef Gabčík, who served in the exiled Czechoslovak Army during the Second World War and, together with Ján Kubiš, carried out the assassination of a representative of Nazi totalitarianism, the Reich Protector Heidrich, but when we defeated her, the Communist one who wanted to build a common good in the Eastern Bloc began to rule. However, I think that this has failed and we thank you for today's freedom.

name: María Teresa Giménez Barbat
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. –Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, our Union was born from the smoldering ashes of left- and right-wing totalitarianism, but also as a refuge and hope in front of them. I would like to recall a reflection by Vaclav Havel, President, on how similar the roots of the totalitarian system are, on the irresistible tendency of ideologies to become independent from reality and life. In a totalitarian reality, ideology replaces reason, and truth is simply identified with power. If Europe's memory falters, if citizens do not understand their past, including the great traditions of reason, the end of the continent's division under the Treaties will not become a reality. This common history should encourage all research initiatives, all educational plans to prevent totalitarian dementia. Because the fight against totalitarianism, which the classics simply called tyranny, is a common struggle for the Union, for freedoms and democracy, precious but fragile goods, such as human memory, which need attention and persevering care. It is vitally important to preserve the memory of totalitarianism, but we must do so from a perspective of European history, from a common European history, so as not to encourage excessive national particularism, so as not to give wings to nationalism and to, in short, to live up to the truth. Yes, truth exists, and it must be our most transcendental and luminous goal and a great inspiration to all.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. – Mr President, it is very important to remind, especially to the younger generation, of the indescribable tragedies brought to humanity by totalitarian regimes of the 20th century. In my Homeland of Lithuania, we lost about 800 000 inhabitants due to the Soviet occupation, about 300 000 were imprisoned in lagers and condemned to famine and cold in Siberia. One in three of these innocent people, including children and women, died in terrible conditions. However, these scrabbling communist crimes are not yet properly condemned, and we will feel the consequences of this and we are all already feeling it. Russia has long promoted the cult of Stalinism, and the Soviet regime is glorified everywhere, from souvenirs to television shows, even obvious things like stalin and Hitler's deal to share Eastern Europe and the occupation of the Baltic states.

name: Νικόλαος Χουντής
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL Group. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in my view, the debate we are having today is disorienting and does not address the modern problems and challenges of youth and education. Nowadays, the sensitive education sector, with its attack, is in danger of not being able to perform its historical and social role. The European Union's neoliberal policies have led to the dismantling and fragmentation of education by suggesting privatisation as a panacea based on market imperatives. Public spending cuts and underfunding have discredited education systems and degraded their quality. Today's debate is directly linked to this quality, content and contribution of education, but in the name of the theory, as developed, of both extremes, it is trying to disorient, rewrite history and justify, in my view, the measures taken in some countries against communist and left-wing parties. Ladies and gentlemen, what historical lesson does Germany's refusal to repay the occupation loan it took from Greece, repay and compensate the victims of the Nazi occupation? What is the historical lesson we are giving and the restoration of historical memory? Ladies and gentlemen, these days, these hours, education in the Greek reality is under a new attack of austerity, by the government, of cutting costs and altering degrees. These disastrous designs do not serve the needs of either education or our societies. The struggle of students and teachers currently facing authoritarian violence points the way to universal education and teachers with dignity and labour rights.

name: Nathan Gill
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, I know that those who fail to learn from our history are doomed to repeat it. I believe strongly in education, but know that education can be and is used to further propaganda. I am concerned that the EU will use this as a way to further propagandise its existence and further make patriotic citizens of nation-states into villains. I know the often-used term populist. Let us not forget that the opposite of populist is un-populist. Why have you made speaking up for the populace somehow a bad thing, always when they say what you do not want to hear? I am also very concerned about the oft-repeated line that the EU has been the source of 75 years of peace in Europe. Communication, cooperation and learning off each other often have helped but do not write out the role of NATO, of the Americans, of the UN, and yes, of nuclear weapons, the threat of which have made war impossible. If you must dabble in education, please trust the Member States to decide what is best for their children. Trust in national education systems and keep political motivation out of education.

name: Marie-Christine Arnautu
text: on behalf of the ENF group. Mr President, teaching the history of totalitarianism is essential, and it is not the visceral anti-communist that I am who will tell you otherwise. But it is not for the European Parliament to deal with education, especially when millions of Europeans, who suffer from poverty, insecurity and migratory submersion, never see their problems solved. That elected officials want to influence research and teaching does not bode well for historical truth. It is precisely the history of totalitarianism that teaches us. However, this is already the case in many European countries. The current trend in soft totalitarianism in the European Union is expressed through guilt, oukases, banishments, propaganda in schools, police and judicial persecution against movements resistant to Euroglobalism, as in Italy, Greece, Belgium, Germany, or in France against the National Rally or the yellow vests. History must aim to extract future generations from the current self-righteous European totalitarianism and the king market, and thus to preserve them from the looming One, Islamist totalitarianism.

name: Κωνσταντίνος Παπαδάκης (NI).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, you are talking about totalitarianism. Your obvious goal: to equate communism with the monster of fascism, the genuine child of capitalist barbarism, the one you all defend. The historical truth, the red flag in the Reichstag, is a silent witness to who exterminated Nazism, who is now nourishing the far right, nationalism and fascists. This is evidenced by what is happening today in Poland, Hungary, the Baltic countries with the persecution and bans of communist parties at the same time that honours are awarded to Nazi collaborators with the support of the European Union. No matter how many institutions, lies in textbooks and expensive campaigns, no matter how much you fund, history is written and written by the people in their fight against the rotten exploitative system. The achievements of socialism in education, health and the eradication of unemployment are historic. The European Union and capitalism are not one way. The peoples can, with their own power in their own countries, fight for the Europe of socialism.

name: Sabine Verheyen (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Totalitarianism is very much against fundamental rights. No freedom of expression, no freedom of travel, exclusion, oppression, fear, atrocities, surveillance state – that is what distinguishes life in totalitarian regimes. This has been part of Europe's history for many years and, thank God, has been overcome in the European Union in the future. In order to prevent this from happening again in any way in the future, this part of our history must not be forgotten. We must keep alive the memory of National Socialism, fascism, but also of the totalitarian communist regimes, and this warning must remain in people's consciousness. Therefore, the processing and processing of all totalitarian systems and their impact on people's lives must be an important part of the European education system and in school education, so that a culture of remembrance can be created. The scientific reappraisal of history at universities is also of particular importance. We have a responsibility to future generations so that this never happens again, so that totalitarianism never has room again in Europe.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that the European democratic and solidarian project will not be developed unless it is based on knowledge and awareness of common European history.  A story based on the 'never again' totalitarianism, Nazism and Communism, as well as the Holocaust, and which focused on the dignity of the human person, freedom and solidarity.  Faced with the new risks of democratic involution, nationalism, racism, but also revisionism and denialism, it is necessary that, in the construction of a European educational area, greater account be taken of the need, in historical research and also in shared methodology, for the teaching of common history, through the promotion of common studies, critical comparisons, not least in order to truly reunite Europe.  I believe that a new methodology must also be developed for European civic education and that, of course, in the freedom of the different systems, we can arrive at the need for lessons from a shared nucleus of European history, which will highlight the common values that have been the basis of the integration process.  It is not enough, however, as we know, to be caught or have memory to be risk-free. We know that if there is also no value education, a practice of European citizenship, an increase in critical thinking, it will be very difficult for culture to be accompanied by conscience, and we must know that it is precisely not enough just to cultivate memory, but a democratic conscience born of that 'never again' that we spoke at the beginning of the experience of the European project.  There are some interesting examples, but also negative examples in Europe, in the education systems. For example, there are some countries that have found it very difficult to insert the history of the Shoah into their history books and others, such as, for example, I am sorry the Czech Republic, in recent days has decided not to remember Jan Palach anymore or in Hungary you no longer want to remember a heroic Imre Nagy. These revisionisms are not good for the creation of a common European consciousness, while there are some very positive experiences that I do not say, and that ... (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Jordi Solé (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr. President. In the age of fake news and post-truth, the way to rearm ourselves as a society is through quality education and free and pluralistic media. It will be the well-trained and well-informed citizens who will be able to stand up to those who seek to distort history, such as the leader of the Spanish People's Party, Pablo Casado, when he says that the Spaniards did not colonize, but that what they were doing was having a bigger Spain. Out of respect for the victims it is essential to react to these kinds of insults to memory. We must work on historical memory to give voice to those who were unable to participate in the construction of the official discourse, to recognize the forgotten part of the denied history, to restore justice and repair those who suffered injustice. And we must do so, not only with the memory of the atrocities of totalitarianism, but also with that of all regimes that have based their power on the systematic violation of fundamental rights.

name: Miguel Urbán Crespo (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr. President. Spain is an exception in Europe. It's an exception for impunity. Only in Spain do we have monuments that make apology of fascist dictatorships, as was Franco's. Only in Spain do we have associations that make subsidised apology of fascism, associations dedicated to genocides and murderers. In Spain alone we have thousands of corpses in the unsushume ditches. We are the second country in the world, after Cambodia, with the most missing. Only in Spain is the principle of universal justice suspended, because the exhortations of Argentine justice to interrogate suspected criminals of humanity for possible prosecution are being rejected. Throughout this parliamentary term we have addressed Commissioner Timmermans to receive the victims, the relatives of the victims, and he has refused. If the European Commission continues to refuse to receive victims of Francoism, it will be complicit in impunity.

name: Marcus Pretzell (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. When it comes to the memory of the socialist and National Socialist dictatorships of the last century, I am sure we all agree that this must find its place in the history books and in education. But when it comes to talking about common values, it becomes more difficult. Because in family policy, or even on the question of the relationship between the nation state and the EU, we have the debates on these very values. It is good that we are having these debates and that they can be conducted openly, with an open result. It is not only a question of valueing community, but also of the individual. It is not just a question of the European dimension, as has been said here, but it is certainly not about the one truth. They are totalitarian regimes that speak of "the" truth. Truth must be fought over. It is the task of providing education, but it is not the task of educating state institutions. This is a classic sign of totalitarian regimes. The European Union should not even begin with this.

name: Alain Lamassoure (PPE).
text: Mr President, I congratulate our colleague Andrey Kovatchev for taking the initiative in this debate. The teaching of history, of course, is not a Community competence and should not become one, but the Union cannot lose interest in the reappearance, almost everywhere in Europe, of hate speech in public debate.  In two generations, Europe has gone from the damnation of the recurrent war to almost perpetual peace. It's a miracle. This miracle was only possible thanks to the construction of Europe because, year after year, it has reconciled our peoples by mobilizing them, no longer against each other, but around a common project.  Now, here or there, we are training a new generation of nationalists with our children. We are finally wary of fake news, let's beware of fake history, the one that played such a dramatic role in the tragedies of the twentieth century. Yes, a thousand times yes to the national narrative, no to the national novel.

name: Krystyna Łybacka (S&D).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Totalitarianism is a civilization of violence, it is contempt for freedom of thought and belief. Is it enough memory in the fight against totalitarianism? Is it enough for us only to remember the martyrdom of nations and the heroism of individuals? Not. We need more, especially since modern totalitarianism operates under the cover of democracy. Such hidden totalitarianism is very dangerous, because it sleeps the mind.  Therefore, our task is to educate a generation of young people who are able to critically and reflexively understand the world, their own humanity, can interact with others on the basis of tolerance and respect for others. This education is the best, most effective element in the fight against hatred, with intolerance and with totalitarianism. Let us not allow the true words of Indira Gandhi, who herself has been the victim of hatred, to be true to us. She said, "History is the best teacher, but it has very bad students.". We can't be them.

name: Indrek Tarand (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, I think John Donne’s words, also immortalised by Ernest Hemingway – ‘don’t ask for whom the bell tolls; it tolls for you’ – should be in front of our eyes while debating today. Indeed, totalitarianism can come in different colours: left, right, Fascist, Nazis, Bolshevik, Trotskyist, whatsoever. But the important thing is that we need to recognise it and deal with it when it’s a little seed, not just a grown-up blossoming tree. As usual, I’m a little bit ahead of my time. A month ago I published a book by a great Estonian author who knows how to recognise a totalitarianist. His name was Enn Sarv. He was a prisoner in Le Struthof because he was an enemy of das Reich and later he was in the gulag because he was an enemy of the Soviet people. He taught me a lot and I hope I have taught you a bit in this one minute.

name: Eleonora Forenza (GUE/NGL).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I do not have time here to respond to certain revisionism, which I have heard in some speeches.  On the other hand, the Same Day of the European Union is celebrated on 9 May, forgetting that this is also the day of the Red Army's victory over Nazi fascism, and I say this by strongly rejecting any authoritarian idea of socialism of Communism.  I just want to say that I am proud to have contributed to the adoption, in this House, of a resolution banning all neo-fascist organisations, of having contributed with a denunciation to the arrest of more than 25 neo-fascists in Bari.  I would like to say, however, that today, as Hannah Arendt teaches us, we must go back to the origins of totalitarianism, to the process of dehumanisation that we are also retracing in Italy and also in Europe. When 49 people leave themselves at sea, without considering them people, when you publish the video of the arrest of a person, as in the case of Cesare Battisti, we are faced with that dehumanization ... (The President withdrew the floor from the Speaker)

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, it is necessary to teach about history, about totalitarianism, and it is not easy at all. Therefore, I would like to remind you of the Czech project Memory of the Nation, which is carried out by Post Bellum. This organization collects testimonies and passes them on to pupils in schools and society as a whole. Witness testimony is a very effective method that we should support, because we know that teachers play a key role, they need to be supported and given as much information as possible. This is to be the case, for example, with the Jan Amos Prize for Teachers on the European Union. This pilot project has been supported by the European Parliament and should be implemented this year. It is our contribution and support for teachers to encourage and inform pupils. And also the House of European History, which is in the european parliament's geography. We have one specific contribution to this. On March 20, a film about student Jan Palach, which has already been mentioned here, will be screened here. Today it's exactly 50 years since his human torch was set on fire.

name: Liliana Rodrigues (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, the good intention I believe i have presided over the suggestion of this debate must leave aside the temptation to want to know who had or has the worst dictatorships: if the left, if the right. A dictatorship is a dictatorship, period. There is no ideological inquination in this respect. There are no dictatorships in Europe, but some of our places are in the throes of unliberal democracies, the way it is of a language used to numb people and their sense of alertness. We have seen hate speech and that should be enough to fill us and all those who died fighting totalitarianism. Therefore, particularly for education, we can refuse what T.S. Eliot called temporal provincialism, referring to those who ignored and ignored the lessons and wisdom of history. Portugal knows what I'm talking about.

name: Tunne Kelam (PPE).
text: – Mr President, 10 years ago this Parliament concluded that Europe will not be really united unless it is able to reunite its history, to recognise Communism and Nazism as a common horrible legacy. This November, we’re going to mark 30 years since the demolition of the Berlin Wall. However, a mental Berlin Wall still divides us. The victims of Communism still belong to the second category. They lack an internationally binding commitment to ‘never again’, and all European public awareness of what happened in the eastern part of Europe after World War II is still alarmingly superficial and inadequate. The European Parliament also insisted on what should be done, and I would like to recall some points: public debate on the nature of totalitarian systems; updating European history textbooks – I think the Commission can coordinate this job – and marking 23 August as a common day of remembrance of all victims of totalitarian systems.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the European Union was founded as a peace project following the atrocities resulting from totalitarianism and dangerous nationalism. Last year’s European Year of Cultural Heritage promoted positive intercultural dialogue and involved more than six million people taking part in nearly 12 000 events organised across 37 countries. We must continue to celebrate our diversity and common bonds, working in formal and informal education across all age ranges, teaching our difficult history as well as extraordinary achievements. I wish to state that there are still many difficult moments from our past which must be recognised and taught in schools, for example the genocide against Roma, and the shocking Holodomor, or terror famine, in Ukraine which caused the death of 7.5 million people. Now more than ever in times of political instability, we must bring together the people of Europe to learn the mistakes of the past and work together. As Ms Merkel said, when the generation that survived the war is no longer with us... (The President cut off the speaker)

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE).
text: – Mr President, one month ago I was personally faced with a situation where the remembrance of the totalitarian past in Europe seemed to be forgotten. I, together with other MEPs from 13 countries, wrote a public letter to Amazon CEO Jeff Bezos asking him to withdraw the selling of Soviet symbols, the hammer and sickle, on memorabilia. I was surprised about the reactions of some of my fellow MEPs. Some of them didn’t see what the issue is about, the others weren’t aware about the horrors of the Soviet regime. Let me remind you why the Soviet symbols cannot be a fashionable detail or just a kitsch souvenir. Horrific crimes were committed under the Soviet symbols of the hammer and sickle, millions killed, tortured, exiled. The total number of victims of the Soviet regime is estimated at over 60 million. The rest of the world knew very little of these crimes as they happened behind the Iron Curtain. Our attitude towards symbols of the Soviet regime should be no less serious than towards Nazi symbols. Both totalitarian regimes, Nazi and Soviet, systematically abused human rights, suppressed freedom and democracy in Europe. (Applause)

name: Момчил Неков (S&D).
text: – Mr President, historical memory of the totalitarian past is a topic that must be approached delicately and from the necessary distance of time, especially as regards the time of communism in countries of the former Eastern Bloc, such as Bulgaria. The memories of this period of Bulgarian history are still alive and I believe that when communism is studied in school by today's generation, then the historical reading should be objective, not ideological and politicized. In the new version of the Bulgarian history books, communism is described as the darkest period in our history, presented as worse than the era of Turkish slavery. The reality, however, is different. Research shows that a significant proportion of Bulgarians would prefer to live in communist times. I'il tell you why. Because the Bulgarians in the period of transition and after it actually live worse and barely make ends meet. Because over the past ten years Borisov's policy has further exacerbated inequalities in society. I wonder why the government, instead of pre-electionly dividing the nation into communists and anti-communists and attempting to change history, do not focus "..." (the President takes away the speaker's word)

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I cannot resist speaking in my own language, because I also want to commemorate the sacrifice of Jan Palach, whose anniversary we are remembering today. Fifty years since the self-immolation of a student of the Faculty of Philosophy Jan Palach.  As I listened to the debate, I realized how strongly and symbolically this information resonates here today precisely in the context of totalitarianism, with censorship, and I cannot remember the moment when my mother, when I was about 15 years old, I think it was whispered, told me who Jan Palach was and what he did in 1969. I remember her telling me very accurately, "Don't say that name anywhere, but remember the name." And then January 1989 came and this name was us Czechs chanting on Wenceslas Square and I realized then that the sacrifice that Jan Palach made was self-immolation, such an agonizing and ousting death that he chose, that the sacrifice was not in vain and that he had done his important work in Czech society. And it should continue to do so not only in Czech society, but throughout Europe. I think that today we should recognize these contexts, recognize that totalitarianism brings censorship, brings bending of the backs, repression, emigration and distortion of morality. These are all fruits that we may still be harvesting today, and against which we must do everything.  With regard to education, I think that no one, as we are here, nor the European Union, of which I am a representative, wants today's education system to tell children the only possible truths allowed. It's a sign of totalitarianism. We want schools to give objective information so that they do not shy away from the subject of modern history and, above all, to teach the younger generation to work with information to lead it to critical thinking. Because believing that only our education system, our schools will ensure that we know our modern history, that's a very naïve idea. Today we are in an era of the Internet, in an era when, as many have discovered, we are being attacked by disinformation waves. That is why it is so important not only to pass on information to young people, but to teach them to work with information, to teach them critical thinking and to let them work with the information they receive from different sources.  I think that this is not only a task for the European Union, but above all, as has also been said here, for the Member States, on which I personally tend to rely really sincerely, that it will not allow totalitarianism to dominate not only education, but also our societies.

name: Předsedající. –
text: I must say that I am personally surprised and sorry that those colleagues who have just expressed this concern about The European Union's propaganda in the curricula have not had enough time to hear the Commissioner's response.

name: Melania Ciot
text: President-in-Office of the Council. – Mr President, I would like to thank honourable Members for this important and enriching debate. I believe that we have a wide consensus regarding the importance of education in building a Europe for the future, based on common values, mutual understanding of our diverse traditions and shared awareness of the history of Europe, including totalitarianism. Parliament can be sure that the Council will keep this issue high on its political agenda in the future. Thank you very much, once again, for your attention.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. Written statements (Rule 162)

name: Andrea Bocskor (PPE)
text: Writing. – According to the European Parliament resolution against totalitarianism adopted in 2009, reconciliation is not possible without processing the past and learning the truth. This means adapting and supplementing the history textbooks and curricula used in European schools in order to make young generations aware of the heinous crimes committed by authoritarian regimes. The document recalled the Day of Remembrance for the Victims of Totalitarian Regimes and called on member states to examine how the commemoration should take place in the light of the history and specificities of their own countries. I think it is important to keep the memory of millions of victims alive, because that is what warns us of the dangers of totalitarianism, while at the same time strengthening solidarity and understanding among the citizens of a united Europe.  The European Union should be given the appropriate framework and the appropriate resources for research into Totalitarian regimes in Europe, as well as for appropriate education programmes and cultural projects in order to have an objective and comprehensive understanding of the totalitarian past. Only in this way can the future generation, the younger generations, learn about our common past and thus become builders of a common European future.

name: Dominique Bilde (ENF)
text: In writing. "The darkest hours of our history" is the European Union's lifeline in the face of the growing rejection of its peoples. This almost obsessive evocation of the atrocities that marked the 20th century from the Holocaust to Stalinism has since the turn of the 2000s become the raison d'être of a Union unable to establish its legitimacy on a genuine popular consensus. It is therefore not insignificant that, as the protest escalates, the Commission is multiplying the commemorations, bringing the millennia-old history of our continent back to the only tragedy of mortal totalitarianism, of which the European construction would be the antidote. Let us be clear: the memory of millions of victims of Nazism and Communism is a compelling requirement. However, its diversion for political purposes is eminently questionable. For one of the lessons we must learn from totalitarian experience is that history belongs to historians and not to ideologues.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR)
text: in writing. – Almost all Member States have experienced totalitarian regimes. However, few place the emphasis on studying their crimes. Hope, however, comes from civil society. Since 1998, the Romanian Civic Academy Foundation has been organizing a summer school dedicated to students between the ages of 15 and 18 to study communist-era crimes in Sighetul Marmatii, at the site of the old communist prison. This year marks the 80th anniversary of the signing of the Ribbentrop-Molotov Pact and the 30th anniversary of the fall of the Berlin Wall, the 30th anniversary of The liberation of Europe from totalitarian terror. The Sighet Programme is a worthy example to follow throughout the Union, so that the memory of those who died for our freedom will always remain alive.

name: Ivari Padar (S&D)
text: Writing. – It is often the case that we celebrate the achievements of the past and try to suppress painful memories. The power of totalitarian regimes in Europe is one such painful memory. But remembering painful memories will help us move forward and ensure that authoritarian forces do not return to power. My country, Estonia, has suffered from the communism of the Soviet Union, and it is therefore particularly important for me and my countrymen to address both fascist and communist regimes in remembering the past of totalitarian regimes and teaching history. There must be no room for Stalinist nostalgia in the Western cultural space, because we would not approve of the longing for the fascist past. Education plays a key role here, and that is why the European Union must contribute both to teaching the past of totalitarian regimes and to its academic research. The modernisation of school history textbooks also requires coordination between the European Union. Educating our citizens at this moment is particularly important, as all populist movements continue to gather support across Europe.

name: João Pimenta Lopes (GUE/NGL)
text: in writing. – Attempts to rewrite history continue shamefully. They feed the falsification of the past, criminalizing communism, equating it with Nazi-fascism, hypocritically whitening those who tried to enslave a part of the European peoples and promoted a terrifying war of extermination. They want to erase the decisive contribution of the Communists and the Soviet Union to the defeat of Nazi-fascism, their role in the advances in the living conditions of workers, their contribution to the liberation of the peoples from the colonial yoke after World War II. No attempt to rewrite history will erase this legacy. The historical and universal impact and significance of the October Revolution, even after the disappearance of the USSR, is further evidenced in the time in which we live.  A time that highlights the exploitative, oppressive, aggressive and predatory nature of the capitalist system and the European Union, permanently confronted with the rights and aspirations of workers and peoples and which is responsible for the growing problems and dangers that humanity faces.

name: President. –
text: The next item is the debate on the report by Josep-Maria Terricabras, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the situation of fundamental rights in the European Union in 2017 (2018/2103(INI)) (A8—0466/2018).

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I also address myself to the Commissioner and the colleagues who played the role of shadows for the annual Report on the situation of fundamental rights in the EU in 2017. This report had to be relatively brief, which it is. When you consider all fundamental rights in the whole of Europe during one year, it is clear that you are tempted to speak about a tremendous amount of things.  We have avoided this and have focused on six main topics. Some of them necessarily extended, all of them of undeniable relevance and of major concern: the rule of law, migration, women’s rights, media freedom, freedom of expression and assembly, racism, xenophobia, discrimination, hate speech and other forms of intolerance, the role and mandate of the European Union Agency for Fundamental Rights (FRA).  We agreed from the very beginning on the criteria under which we had to work on it. Our main political and moral criterion is the common view that we didn’t want to produce a completely neutral analysis of fundamental rights in Europe, but our aim was to make a joint reflection on the values of the Union, not just to defend them but also to suggest ways and steps to improve the Charter. Allow me a personal remark. No one thinks that the Charter will be stronger and more vivid if we maintain Article 51, which should be interpreted in a wider way to avoid that we have to advance at a good speed but with the handbrake on.  I am convinced that we have produced a good report. I will highlight just a few aspects. First, as for the rule of law, we stress that the EU’s ineffectiveness in ending the breaches of the values referred to in Article 2 is undermining both trust among the Member States and the credibility of the European Union.  Migration is still a major concern. In 2017, 650 000 first-time asylum seekers applied for international protection in the Member States. More than 1 000 refugees have drowned in the Mediterranean Sea. Humanitarian aid has been criminalised. States have not been able to undo the knot of the Dublin Regulation.  Women’s rights are clearly defended in the text, now when in some countries and among certain people they are attacked or dismissed.  Media freedom, freedom of expression and assembly that in the past counted among the fundamental rights for free men and women have now to be restored, even in places and countries where one would not expect them to be under threat. Artists or social leaders are also the victims, now and then. Racism, xenophobia, discrimination, hate speech and many forms of intolerance are reducing equality and freedom among human beings. We have tried to show that there are many forms of intolerance and discrimination, that our life can only be built up if it benefits from a rich soil of justice and a good atmosphere of freedom. As a final point, we mentioned the Agency for Fundamental Rights, FRA, based in Vienna, which is doing an excellent job and has never before appeared in our annual reports. FRA should be active, not only in giving support when asked to do so but it should also be proactive in discovering and denouncing cases where human rights are at stake or have been abolished. The FRA needs a new mandate. Our 21 pages are, in my opinion, a text which is at once simple, clear and forceful, thanks to the shadow colleagues and to the advisers who decisively contributed to this satisfactory result.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I greet you warmly! I have one request for a time regime. At 5 p.m., we start voting. If I consider that this deadline is in jeopardy, please do not be angry, but I will intervene radically.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank Parliament for its constant focus on strengthening fundamental rights in the EU. In short, I will start with the rule of law, which is crucial for the very functioning of the EU.
