The Commission has, over the past years, been committed to upholding the rule of law in all Member States with a sound rule of law policy and it closely monitors the situation in Member States. The rule of law has never been so high on our European agenda as it is today. The Commission has proposed a regulation on protecting the Union’s budget in the event of generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law in the Member States. The Commission also intends to present an initiative on further strengthening its rule of law framework, taking due account of the work of Parliament, including the resolution on democracy, the rule of law and a fundamental rights mechanism that was adopted in 2016 and the discussion that followed. Following the actions of the Government of Poland, we have initiated the Article 7 procedure. In September last year, Parliament decided to initiate the same procedure following the actions of the Hungarian Government. These are unprecedented steps. The Commission is also using infringement proceedings to address values—related violations of EU law by Member States. We also use other instruments, including audits and investigations related to the use of EU funds as well as measures through the European Semester to monitor justice reforms in Member States. Overall, the EU is encouraging Member States to improve the independence, quality and efficiency of their justice system. National judges are also EU judges. They are, together with the Court of Justice, the guardians and the ordinary court of the EU legal order, particularly through their role in the preliminary ruling procedure. Effective justice systems are also essential in maintaining mutual trust between Member States and their judicial authorities. This has been underlined by the recent case law of the Court of Justice, which stressed that mutual trust is founded on the premise that the national courts meet the requirements of effective judicial protection. After all, as the Court of Justice has recently phrased it prominently, effective judicial review is of the essence to the rule of law, one of the values upon which the European Union is founded. With regard to the challenges still faced by women, I would like to stress that women’s rights were at the heart of the Commission’s work in 2017 with the year of actions and a dedicated colloquium. Of course, as you are right to mention, one of the main achievements is the Istanbul Convention and we hope that the EU too will accede to the Istanbul Convention soon. I will use the concluding remarks to say a few words about media freedom and civil society, because I am out of time.

name: Tomáš Zdechovský (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I do not know if, speaking of such an important matter as human rights, why were there no invitations to this issue by representatives of the Council, that is, the Romanian Presidency? Can you please explain this to me, or are fundamental human rights not important to the Romanian Presidency?

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Thank you very much for this remark. I would like to point out that you are proposing that Romania be considered a special case and Romania has the usual Presidency, so this attention will be given. Proposals will certainly also be forwarded to the Council and the Romanian State will respond if necessary.

name: Barbara Kudrycka
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Today's report tackles the most serious challenges facing the European Union: violations of the rule of law, discrimination and hate speech. That is a good thing, because the violation of the tripartite power, the politicisation of courts and prosecutors, unprecedented scheduing in the state media and the lack of response of the authorities to acts of aggression and hatred against political opponents lead to an atmosphere conducive to acts of terror. The victim of such an act of terror was The President of Gdańsk Pawel Adamowicz, a victim of institutionalized hatred that we have been dealing with in Poland for three years.  Today's report is therefore an appeal to the whole of a free Europe to restore the most important values in public life: the rule of law, tolerance and respect for human dignity. Only if this is done, the death of Paweł Adamowicz will not be in vain.  It is good that the rule of law and other fundamental values of the European Union are described in such a fair manner in the report, because neither national sovereignty nor the principle of subsidiarity can justify a systemic breach of those values. It is also good that the amendment pointing to the poor effectiveness of Article 7 and calling on the Council to determine as soon as possible whether there is a clear risk of a serious breach of the values contained in the Treaties for Polish and Hungary has been maintained. I would like to commend Frank Engel here for reaching good compromises from the perspective of our political group, which is why I am in favour of the report on behalf of the EPP.

name: Sylvie Guillaume
text: On behalf of the Group of S and D- Mr President, this annual report on whether or not to respect fundamental rights in the Union may seem routine, but it is not. As rapporteur for the Socialists and Democrats, I can say that 2017 has been a pivotal year for many rights, and what we are talking about today is crucial. I would like to point out some of the principles and rights that have been undermined, on which collective firmness has been required in the negotiations because, in my opinion, they are non-negotiable. The rule of law: in several Member States, reforms contrary to the rule of law and democracy are taken - threats to the independence of the judiciary, the good health of NGOs, corruption, and media nibbling. The report lists these borderline, or sometimes frankly illegal, policies and urges states to change course. The Council and the Commission must continue the current Article 7 assessments and sanction countries, if necessary. Women's rights: In 2017, harassment and sexual assault have received high profile, thanks in part to the Me Too movement. As we know, women's rights are never taken for granted. Beyond economic equality in education and the fight against violence, it is time for Member States to ensure equitable access to family planning, modern contraception and safe and legal abortion, which is not always the case today. Every woman in Europe must have the right to decide what she does or does not do with her body safely. Despite opposition from some on the right on this point, my group is fighting for the report to retain this imperative. Migration: while arrivals have been decreasing since 2017 and Parliament has already adopted its position, Member States are still refusing to organise themselves at European level. We therefore call on them once again to agree on the reform of the Dublin Regulation. There are so many other important themes in this report, including the fight against discrimination of all kinds - homophobia, racism, anti-Semitism, etc. - and the importance of guaranteeing the rights of European and British citizens in the face of Brexit. These remarks and suggestions are, of course, messages to the Member States, to the Commission and to Parliament. They must be heard. And I take five seconds to wish a wonderful birthday to my daughter who, at that very minute, is 18 years old. Happy birthday, she's looking at me.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: Greetings to the daughter. Indeed, as you have a young mom, this and a young daughter.

name: Marek Jurek
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by We are talking about the state of fundamental rights in 2017. That same year in Prien am Chiemsee, Bavaria, a young Afghan Christian convert, a woman who was a refugee, was murdered in an act of anti-Christian hatred by an asylum seeker. At the time, Sweden rejected the possibility of granting asylum to another Christian convert, a young Iranian actress.  In France, on average, christian temples and cemeteries were insulted every ten hours in the same year. In Germany it was not so bad, because statistically taking, there were similar acts every three days. In the same year, the notorious FEMEN desecrated a manger in St. Peter's Square in Rome. Despite all these examples, and despite the calls made during the negotiations, and despite the fact that this report on fundamental rights contains new forms of prejudice: aporophobia, transphobia, the report deliberately ignores anti-Christian hatred. Despite requests to make this grim phenomenon that accompanies our lives, to state. Silence about anti-Christian hatred is in itself an act of anti-Christian contempt, and unfortunately this report is also a form of agreement on such acts.

name: Louis Michel
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. Mr President, again this year the European Parliament is reporting on the situation of fundamental rights in the Union. Once again, Parliament calls for action against unacceptable abuses and unacceptable violations of treaty values in some Member States. This call is all the more urgent today in the run-up to the European elections.  We actually have a choice, this is not new, between two Europes: a democratic and liberal Europe, where fundamental and universal values continue to underpin European integration and protect citizens, as has been the case since the end of the war; or a Europe that is at odds with history, and which considers that the principles of the rule of law and the protection of minorities are, in essence, cumbersome details which hinder the increasingly disturbing rise of authoritarian temptations or selective moralities. I just heard it from a colleague a few moments ago. Women and politicians must choose their side and assume it in front of the voters. To this end, I cannot help but stress that it is now urgent that the leaders of the Member States clearly stand in favour of the establishment of a monitoring mechanism, as has long been called for by Sophia in 't Veld and the European Parliament, which would also involve the Council and which must analyse and report annually on the respect of fundamental rights in each country of the Union. Until we have this visible evidence of the shortcomings in our Member States, there will still be an important tool missing from this report on fundamental rights.  (The speaker agreed to answer a "blue card" question (Article 162, paragraph 8, of the internal regulation))

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI)
text: 'blue card' question. Mr Michel, my question will be very brief. You are a very eminent Belgian politician. Do you not find it any wonder that in your country, Belgium, one of the main opposition parties, the Vlaams Blok, was virtually banned by the courts a few years ago, without any protest in the ranks of this Parliament?

name: Louis Michel (ALDE)
text: answer 'blue card'. I do not find it shocking that a party is prohibited when it is indisputably illegal or has totally unconstitutional behaviour. It is as simple as that, Mr Gollnisch.  I know that the Vlaams Belang - because it is no longer the Vlaams Blok today - has extremely close kinship with your party, so I do not think you are really in the best position to judge the attitude and the way Belgium behaves towards a party that is really recognised as being fascinating.

name: Ana Miranda
text: verts/ALE Group. – Mr. President. First of all, I would like to congratulate Mr Josep Maria Terricabras on this report, which brings to light what we call rights and freedoms on paper; but we ask this Parliament not to be left alone on paper, but to be the analysis of reality. In 2017, visiting refugee camps, we were able to see directly how the situation of migrants, refugees, people who have been fleeing for life was. It was also a bleak year for the deaths of the Mediterranean, Commissioner, as you also said. A bleak year, a year that will remain in European historical memory. But it was also a very tough year for women's rights, for sexual and reproductive rights, including the right to abortion, even if it bothered that part of the Eurochamber. And, of course, it was a negative year for the freedom of the media and for freedom of expression and assembly, especially because of the concentration of means and the abuse of power that occurs in some of them. And finally, President, discrimination, racism, xenophobia and hate speech are precisely the basis of what we have seen and what is happening, and the threat of what may be the next Eurochamber, from parties like Mrs Le Pen's to the Vox party.

name: Marie-Christine Vergiat
text: on behalf of the GUE/NGL group. Mr President, I would first like to thank our rapporteur and all the shadow rapporteurs. This five-chapter thematic structure highlights what the declines in rights are most evident about, starting with the rule of law on which any political construction is based - or should be based on any political construction. Failures in this area should be punished. Without the rule of law, no respect for rights, and democracy is in danger. I am dreaming of the Commission's effective reactions in this area as in economic and budgetary matters. We're a long way from that. Fundamentals include the separation of powers, the independence of the judiciary, but also freedom of expression, freedom of expression, media rights, women's rights, and hate speech. It is not surprising that gangrene spreads to all minorities, whatever they may be, and that migrants become scapegoats, if it is the politicians, including governments, who set the wrong example? We have seen this with the surreal debate around the Marrakesh Pact, with which we have reached heights of bad faith, including on the part of some governments, questioning a text they had adopted unanimously in July 2018. A society judges itself in the way it treats its most vulnerable members. I fear that the judgment of history is quite ruthless towards those who govern us today.

name: Laura Ferrara
text: Mr President, president, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, the European Union and its Member States are – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, in dealing with the situation on fundamental rights every year, we regularly come across critical issues relating to respect for those values, such as human dignity, equality before the law, freedom, the prohibition of all discrimination, which should form the basis of any democratic and law-based society.  In this report too, to mention some of the essential issues dealt with, phenomena that are very present in several Member States are highlighted. We are talking about racism, xenophobia, serious and widespread acts of violence against women, migrants and minorities, attacks on the rule of law and freedom of expression and the media. We are talking about the scourge of corruption, which has always been a threat to the equal enjoyment of citizens' rights and to resources allocated to public services.  I have already strongly supported the need in the past to establish a European monitoring mechanism to prevent and combat violations of the Fundamental Rights of the European Union. I would have welcomed a greater focus on the problem of increasing poverty and material deprivation, which would require the promotion and implementation of national minimum income schemes, so that decent living conditions, as well as an improvement in the level of social inclusion and in the labour market, are ensured for all people with insufficient income, as well as an improvement in the level of social inclusion and in the labour market, in order to promote access to goods and services and a better quality of life.  The Union's political action in the economic and financial field should give priority to the protection of fundamental rights over market interests and austerity policies, at the expense of citizens. The failure of this approach has been evident and has led to malaise and a disregarded demand for greater listening and participation on the part of people, who should be placed at the centre of the European Union's policies and decisions, on their well-being, respect for their personal, civil, political, economic and social rights.

name: Auke Zijlstra
text: on behalf of the ENF Group. Mr President, political violence in Germany and Poland on Monday led to a call by the President of the ENF Group to talk less and listen to each other more. That call was received in this room with no more than a scornful smile. I find that worrisome.  Violence against politicians is not only physical violence, but also legal violence and administrative exclusion. And this Parliament is not free of that. With the elections coming up, I fear the exclusion and demonisation of large groups of voters and their representatives simply because they threaten the current order.  You can be a democrat and still want to leave the European Union. Members of this House must ask themselves whether their political opinion justifies everything, including exclusion from the other. Are we not destroying the fundamental rights that we are supposed to cherish?

name: Bruno Gollnisch (NI).
text: Mr President, fundamental rights are under threat in Europe, but not at all in the way described in the report. It is the accumulation of laws that restrict, for example, freedom of expression, memorial laws or others. Criticism of immigration, as can be seen here, is considered racist and xenophobic. I want to prove what Mr Michel just said. They were parliamentarians, a political movement that legitimately ran for office, peacefully, whose members were regularly elected. But it is enough for Mr Michel to repeat these Members as holding hate speech and unconstitutional, and he arrogates the right, with the majority of this House, to suppress their rights. The defence of the traditional family is equated with gender stereotypes or homophobia. The legitimate questioning of contemporary history is equated with denialism. There are several hundred political prisoners in Germany, including lawyer Horst Mahler, who recently had an amputee 83, and Ursula Haverbeck, who was jailed at the age of 90 for a misdemeanour. What hypocrisy reigns in this chamber!

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE).
text: – Mr President, from the whole report, I particularly appreciate the first part, which emphasises the rule of law. In fact, the European Union has nothing but law, no legislation. He doesn't have his own police, customs officers or troops. Therefore, insisting on respect for law and values such as the rule of law is an existential matter for the Union. Unfortunately, however, the report completely ignores the manifestations of militant secularism in Europe. The manifestations of intolerance and discrimination against Christians in Europe are already so intense that, among other things, a research institute has been established in Austria dedicated only to this phenomenon. In doing so, it is all illogical, our system of fundamental rights is based only on respect for an individual who has Christian roots. Without these roots, the whole system threatens to degenerate. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – Dear colleague, I agree with what you have said. We need a security of respect for citizens' rights in the European Union. Because you mentioned Austria, I want to ask you on time: what do you think of Austria discriminating against children and mothers who are not Austrian citizens but who work and contribute to Austria's GDP?

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I, my dear colleague, was talking about something completely different, I was talking about discrimination against Christians in Europe. Of course, I do not like any discrimination that is also illegal and harms some people in the European Union. (The speaker agreed to answer the question posed by raising the Blue Card (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Sophia in ‘t Veld (ALDE)
text: blue-card question. – Colleague, I just heard you speak of militant atheists, I’m not really sure what that is and how they are making the lives of Christian people in Europe impossible, but okay.  But you said that the European Union would collapse if it was no longer founded on its Christian roots, but isn’t what we all have in common, the enlightenment and the rule of law, isn’t that the basis for our community? I mean I respect your Christian roots, but if you do not respect the fact that other people are atheists, then how can we live together?

name: Pavel Svoboda (PPE)
text: answer to the question posed by raising the blue card. – I respect everyone's beliefs, I just point out that respect for an individual, which is the foundation of human rights, if it is cut off from Christian roots and is not interpreted in their spirit, necessarily leads to degeneration, and it is already happening.

name: Dietmar Köster (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which Fundamental rights are the permanent and enforceable rights of the individual citizen. They are a constituting for the European understanding of the rule of law, the separation of powers and democracy. Only an inclusive society is a humane society. In the European Union, however, minorities are often deprived of their fundamental rights. For example, Roma are still racially discriminated against, and I am outraged that more than 70 years after the end of the Shoah, anti-Semitism is on the rise again in Europe today. For me, the definition of anti-Semitism of the International Alliance for Holocaust Remembrance, which Parliament approved in 2017, applies in full. Similarly, people are discriminated against on the basis of their sexual orientation or gender identity, and they are denied full legal recognition. The implementation of the EU Charter of Fundamental Rights is at the heart of EU policy, because the degree of humanity of a society is measured by the position of minorities in it.

name: Helga Stevens (ECR).
text: Mr President, despite justified criticism of violence against women, the LGBTI community and journalists, the N-VA will not vote in favour. However, these issues are important to us, we also take it up for people with disabilities and we support, for example, the EU mechanism for the rule of law.  But this report lacks all the nuance. In this way, insufficient distinctions are made between illegal and legal migration. Family reunification, and therefore follow-up migration, is also hailed as an integration-enhancing measure. The report also expects too much benefit from EU asylum legislation to tackle the migration crisis. But these EU rules do not allow us to pursue a strict national migration policy.  This resolution is a potpourri of very different themes. We prefer to judge each file individually on its merits, which we did and will continue to do.  Moreover, I do not read anything in this report about the shame of the political prisoners in Spain. How the hell is that possible? Shame on you!

name: Nathalie Griesbeck (ALDE).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, 2017 has been a dark year for fundamental rights, and particularly for freedom of expression. Very often, all too often, in this chamber, we have been silent to honour the memory and determination of those who have disappeared while working as journalists. It is these actors of democracy who have been threatened for their role as whistleblowers, murdered because they touched too closely on issues of anti-corruption, money laundering and tax evasion. Have we learned from these threats against freedom of expression and freedom of information? At present, when disturbing anti-media rhetoric is developing in our political arenas, at a time when harassment, intimidation and assaults against human rights defenders are becoming commonplace, it is worth recalling Beaumarchais, who said: "Without the freedom to blame, there is no flattering praise". That is why I strongly support this report, which highlights the disproportionate pressures that have been made in 2017 on these fundamental rights.

name: Terry Reintke (Verts/ALE).
text: – Mr President, let’s look around in Europe. Everywhere people go to the streets they are waving EU flags, be it in Bucharest, be it in Warsaw, be it in Vienna or in Berlin. They are waving EU flags because they are addressing us, because the rule of law and fundamental rights are under attack in many Member States in the European Union and they want to see action from our side. Article 7 has proven to be a powerful tool but at the same time, in implementation, to be very impractical from time to time. That is why we need additional instruments in order to uphold the rule of law and fundamental rights of our citizens – for example, an expert group constantly monitoring developments when it comes to the state of the rule of law, to have constant debates about exactly that and if there are breaches, to have a sanction mechanism so that we can do something about that. The European Parliament is the only directly elected institution of the European citizens and the fight for fundamental rights and the rule of law has to be at the core of this Chamber. This is not a nationally bound fight and this is not a partisan fight. It is the fundament of democracy and European unity for all of us, so let’s do this together.

name: Michał Marusik (ENF).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by In fact, fundamental rights as natural rights are only three: the right to life, freedom and property. I would like to draw attention to one detail, which is kind of small, but serious, concerning property. The property is, namely, earnings. Man has the natural right to have full, free disposal of all the fruits of his work. This element of ownership, which is income, is widespread and brutally raped, and lawmakers see it as the right state. Commonly practiced tax confiscation of property is immoral and should be combated by law and legally protected. It also has a pragmatic aspect: punishing people for the usefulness of behaviour and at the same time rewarding people for the uselessness of behaviour destroys human preventability, responsibility, diligence, and thus destroys Europe's productivity. The European Union is not lost, because it is a parasite consuming these goods taken away, but the breadwinner is lost, the whole of Europe is lost. Let us take fundamental rights seriously!

name: Λάμπρος Φουντούλης (NI).
text: Mr President, this report, in addition to the many interritorialities it mentions, also contains an extremely dangerous proposal. I read it to you verbatim: 'prevention of any erosion of the rule of law, which is not the unconditional application of laws, but the democratic acceptance of the inclusion of laws'. On the contrary, the foundation of the rule of law is precisely the tax-free application of the laws. Who sets out the conditions under which the laws will apply? I hope that the author of the report does not consider that the European institutions or non-governmental organisations have such power. Moreover, much is said about the rights of illegal immigrants and minorities. First of all, let's make it clear that immigration is not a human right. On the contrary, states have the right to decide whether anyone can cross their borders. Further, with the case of minorities, I am opposed to any practice of positive discrimination. Minority members must have the same rights and obligations as other citizens of the Member States, nothing more. Finally, let me remind you that this House has never condemned even one of the hundreds of attacks on nationalists. As the father of a child murdered by terrorists on the left, I am entitled to call you hypocrites.

name: Milan Zver (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I usually commend the rapporteur for the report, but I cannot do so this time. The report represents the erosion of the fundamental concept of human rights, virtually excludes fundamental human rights, and it is absolute that even trying to make illegal migration, which are the work of smugglers, a fundamental human right. According to the report, the European Union is a place of discrimination, racism, xenophobia, hate speech, violence against women, against migrants, even writing: the darkest side of Europe. This is not fair to the European Union, which is, however, a place of freedom, equality, solidarity, where the quality of life is highest, where dignity is the most cherished value. Why did you not consult your colleagues more in the preparation of the report and create a greater degree of compromise, why could there be a vote? Therefore, since this report is not comprehensive, it is biased, asymmetrical, uneductive, and I will not be able to support it as a result.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The annual report on the state of fundamental rights in the European Union is always a highlight for the LIBE Committee. The Charter of Fundamental Rights is a compass for our work, and it is important to know whether fundamental rights are being respected, what the situation is in individual Member States and how it all develops over time. The rapporteur, Josep-Maria Terricabras, has set himself the task of covering these requirements more systematically than before. He has undoubtedly succeeded in doing so. Congratulations! He is also right to point out the role of the Fundamental Rights Agency. Their expertise should be used much more intensively, not only when it comes to preparing the annual fundamental rights report, but also as an expert body and in the development of legislative projects. Our group is happy to take up this suggestion.  It is desirable that the Agency should also be able to act on its own initiative in this context. However, this also requires adequate financial and human resources.

name: Monica Macovei (ECR).
text: – Mr President, in the Azerbaijani dictatorship, journalists risk their lives and freedom to write and speak freely. Azerbaijani journalist Mehman Huseynov was sentenced to two years in prison for defamation in March 2017 after publishing photographs of high-end property by officials. Mehman is on hunger strike. He was joined by other political prisoners, prisoners of conscience. In December 2018, Azerbaijani police accused him of other offences - we do not know whether real or invented - and have begun investigations against Mehman, and he is now transferred to police custody, where he is still on hunger strike today. That is why I call on the High Representative for Foreign Affairs, Federica Mogherini, to react harshly, as she did on her first arrest. Freedom and life are non-negotiable and I demand The immediate release of Mehman.

name: Sophia in 't Veld (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, I think some of the interventions in this debate demonstrate very clearly how necessary this debate is and how much more we need to invest in the European Union as a community of values. I just heard my PPE colleagues say: well, why didn’t you compromise a little bit more? Because we do not compromise on human rights. We do not compromise on certain basic principles, like equality, and when you say everything’s fine in the European Union, no violence against women – ask women how many women encounter violence and harassment in their daily life. It also shows how we need to protect LGBTI rights. Recently in my country we found out that over 200 Christian ministers have signed up to the so—called Nashville declaration, which is profoundly homophobic and transphobic. I’d be really interested to know who else in this House is aware of the declaration and has signed up to it. So I will wholeheartedly support this report, including recital 7 and paragraph 23 which is about the fundamental right of women to decide on their very own bodies. There is no right more basic than that.

name: Λευτέρης Χριστοφόρου (PPE).
text: Mr President, the European Union is a Union of principles and values and must be non-negotiable and unyielding in the implementation of fundamental human rights, not only for its Member States but also for countries that want to join the European Union. For us it is unacceptable and inconceivable that countries wishing to join the European Union, which also receive pre-accession aid, i.e. are rewarded every year, such as Turkey, for totally violating the rule of law, the principles and values of the European Union, international laws and conventions, violating all human rights and being rewarded through the European Union by offering them funding. , programmes and pre-accession assistance. If European citizens are asked if they want countries such as Turkey and Albania that violate the human rights of the Greek minority in the North Continent, if they want to fund those countries that violate principles and values, the response of European citizens will be 'no'. Finally, the European Union must give the message that it is incompatible with them and measures and sanctions must be imposed to make every thing we are discussing today aware of.

name: Stefano Maullu (ECR).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, this report touches on human rights and does so in the wrong way.  It does so especially when it comes to immigration, by introducing two principles that foment and create the conditions for illegality, it does so when it says that non-refoulement is a solution, that is to say, all those who try to get to Europe should be welcomed, and then do so in a clear way, when it says that NGOs must be supported and do meritorious work.  This runs counter to the harsh reality of what is happening in the Mediterranean, of what has created a real epochal problem in recent years, particularly for Italy, but also for the rest of Europe. A Europe that, despite keeping its voice up, the flag of human rights, has forgeted, has forgeted Africa and North Africa. The many words, the many announcements, on this great billionaire plan for North Africa, turned out to be empty, useless because not a single euro was invested. I believe that this report lacks reality and, above all, lacks pragmatism. That is why I shall be voting against it.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, of course, I agree with the accent on the rule of law and respect for the separation of powers and the independence of the judiciary in the Member States. It is a fact that some countries in the European Union have a big problem with this at the moment. I also agree with the report's finding that Article 7 should only be used after all other means have been fail, that is, only as a last resort. At the same time, I have some substantive reservations about this report.  First of all, I do not agree with the unilateral assessment of the activities of non-profit organisations in the Mediterranean. Helping people is right, but this must not serve as a motivating factor for smugglers and irregular migration. Surely it is necessary to remember the most vulnerable, which are women and children. It is not always easy, for example on the Greek islands, and we, especially these days, should volunteer to help Greece in this difficult winter.  I strongly disagree with the report's recommendation on the ratification of the Istanbul Convention on sexual and reproductive health and sex education. It's a purely national matter. The European Union should protect the right to life and not promote abortion.

name: Anna Záborská (PPE)
text: – Thank you, Mr President. As every year, when adopting this annual report, I could reiterate that this is the Parliament of the European Union and that this Union is based on the European Treaties, which give its institutions no right to promote abortion. Nor do they give it the right to restrict Member States from accession or accession to international conventions such as the so-called Istanbul Convention. Instead, I'll offer statistics. The English version of the text contains 34 references to 'gender', 31 references to 'gender' and three references to the so-called 'right to abortion'. At the same time, however, it makes only one single point about freedom of conscience, which, together with the right to consebody, is guaranteed by the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union.  The text tabled promotes one very narrow view of the world, which I and my constituents reject. I will therefore vote against its adoption.

name: José Inácio Faria (PPE).
text: – Mr President, this report by Mr Terricabras, which I congratulate on his work, shows us that in 2017, eight years after the entry into force of the European Charter of Fundamental Rights, enormous dissonances remained in the Union between the legislative framework, which is the most advanced in the world, and the practical implementation of its principles.  Harassment and violence against women and girls, racism, homophobia, religious intolerance and discrimination against minorities, people with disabilities and the elderly remain serious. Intolerance against migrants and asylum seekers is growing, and in some Member States free and independent journalism is threatened by weakening separation of powers and political corruption. And the question is: With what authority can we condemn human rights violations in third countries in this House if we do not do so even more firmly in relation to those perpetrated in the Member States and do we not have the political courage to bring to the final punitive consequences the procedures provided for in the Treaties? We're a community of law. Ignoring this fact and forgetting that the European project is the heir to a humanist ethic is tantamount to destroying it.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank Mr Terricabras and my fellow shadow rapporteurs for their work.  2017 was a year in which too many critical issues emerged, respecting fundamental rights, including gender equality, children's rights and respect for the rule of law. I therefore believe it is important for the report to reaffirm the principle that children should never be detained because of their status as migrants and to call on the Member States to put in place reception and inclusion measures that take account of their specific vulnerability.  The recommendations on combating gender-based violence and the call to the Member States, full ratification and full implementation of the Istanbul Convention are also significant. It is also important to call for respect in the Member States for the independence of the judiciary which, as the Court of Justice has also confirmed, is an essential element of the rule of law and an essential prerequisite for maintaining mutual trust in the area of freedom, security and justice.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, reading this report, it appears that a human being who is not a woman, migrant or a member of a minority has no human rights or cannot be threatened. We must finally reject the leftist narrative that human rights are reserved only for some.  The rapporteur forgets of the millions of people in Europe who do not have a roof over their heads, who are in debt bondage or have their families thrown out on the street. He also didn't think of schoolchildren living in poverty whose parents couldn't afford them a snack.  The right to home and dignity are fundamental rights that this home often forgets, while promoting fundamental rights that are not, such as the right to abortion or the right to cross the border illegally.  Let us finally start looking at human beings equally, devoting ourselves to all and defending the human rights of all citizens with the same fervor.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, despite the fact that the European Union is based among other values and on respect for fundamental rights, many of its states are violating these rights. One could say that this is the dark side of the moon. However, the European Union is largely responsible for this situation, because it selectively addresses these violations. For example, while it tolerates some states violating fundamental rights with impunity, it punishes some other states. While it is, and rightly so, cut for freedom of justice, it nevertheless tolerates the imprisonment of Catalan MPs for political expediency and did not react when this principle was violated in Greece in order to prosecute the leader and deputies of Greece's third-in-power political party, Golden Dawn. It defends freedom of speech but at the same time criminalises the expression of the opposite view by describing it as racist, xenophobic and homophobic. The European Union must therefore get rid of this hypocrisy.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me just shortly react to what we just heard because I strongly reject what we heard about the selective approach. I don’t know which EU you spoke about. I speak about the EU which applies equal treatment as regards the Member States and we apply and recognise very strongly the principle of equality in front of the law for everybody and fundamental rights for everybody without any exceptions, so I had to react to this. Let me conclude in this very topical and important debate by also stressing the important role of the Fundamental Rights Agency. I think that the debate showed that the catalogue of the current dangerous trends and new dangerous developments is rather low and that there is a job to do in the field of protection of the fundamental rights of people in the EU. We have not spoken too much about the shrinking space of civil society. We didn’t touch too much upon freedom of expression and media freedom and pluralism, which needs to be upheld. So I think that there will be a space for future debates on these very important topics. We have not spoken about the new trend, which is hatred, and the problematic situation on the internet and in social media where the EU is doing a lot to protect people who are endangered on the internet. So thank you very much and I am looking forward to further continuation of the discussion about these very important themes.

name: Josep-Maria Terricabras
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I would like to thank my colleagues for their comments and for their support. With your report, we will send the message that the promotion and safeguarding of human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights can make Europe unique and a worthy political project. It is only by placing the wellbeing of the people at the core of the European Union’s policies and decisions that Europe will re-engage with its citizens.  This is why, although the Charter sets out the basic rights that must be respected, we must continue to denounce and address the breaches and violations of their provisions. It is our responsibility to protect the weakest and confront the powerful.

name: Przewodniczący. –
text: I close the debate. The vote will take place at the end of the debates. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Tibor Szanyi (S&D)
text: Writing. – The report faithfully reflects the shortcomings of fundamental rights in the Member States of the Union, and it is to be welcomed in particular that the new issues of centre of gravity include the topicality of the treatment of migrants and violence against women (#MeToo). I can only add to the rather depressing picture that since 2017 the situation has only worsened, especially in some eastern Member States.  Unfortunately, the undemocratic functioning of the Orban government has degraded my country, Hungary, into a kind of "veterinary horse" of violations within the EU, as regards the dismantling of the foundations of democracy and the situation of European values and fundamental rights. In particular, with regard to the independence of the judiciary, freedom of the press and anti-foreignerism, they reflect the political situation in Hungary that we discussed and condemned in the EP last September in connection with the Sargentini report. However, the weakness and lack of consequence of these important and accurate annual fundamental rights reports is increasingly being questioned and is now questioning the credibility of the EU and the EP. The report also refers to the slowness of the procedure under Article 7 and the inconsistenty of infringement procedures, which makes the community almost inconsistent with Orban's unscrupulous policies.  In my opinion, it cannot be maintained that even in the case of specific serious infringements, criticism is only about 'individual Member States'. I therefore reiterate here that the EU's legal instruments should be complemented as soon as possible by objective automatism, including sanctions, to monitor the rule of law.

name: Jarosław Wałęsa (PPE)
text: I would like to write to the Commission. – The European Union is a union of values and certain principles. Respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities, have fundamental and immediate consequences for political, social, cultural and economic life in Europe. Fundamental rights apply to all. Respecting them is essential to ensure that the EU is a place where people can grow, enjoy the freedoms granted to them and live without experiencing any discrimination.  At a time when we are confronting extremism, radicalism and division, violations of the rule of law, increasing discrimination and hate speech, promoting, strengthening and defending justice, EU rights and values is becoming more important than ever. It is therefore necessary to restore the most important values in public life, such as the rule of law, tolerance and respect for human dignity. Promoting democracy and fundamental rights through healthy public debate and a dynamic civil society is crucial. Because only a free and dynamic civil society can become a key element for integration and a healthy democratic society.

name: La Présidente. –
text: The agenda calls Voting Time. (For voting results and other details about them: see minutes)

name: José Manuel Fernandes
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, pursuant to Rule 59(4) I request that the matter be referred back to committee for interinstitutional negotiations.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Lara Comi's report on behalf of the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection on the implementation of Directive 2011/7/EU on combating late payments in commercial transactions (2018/2056(INI)) (A8-0456/2018).

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, let me start this debate on late payments, which is an extremely important topic. Late payment is really an issue which has a strong impact on our businesses. Let me very briefly recall the history of the file, because it started in 1995 with the Commission’s recommendation on payment periods in commercial transactions. It stated that payment delays were really a danger to the survival of our European businesses. In 2000, the first Late Payment Directive concluded that the situation had not improved – on the contrary – so in 2011 the revised Directive laid down stronger rules to combat late payments both by public authorities and businesses. In 2016, the Commission’s Report on the implementation of the Directive noted a reduction in average late payment delays. So can we say that late payments are a problem of the past? Of course not. Let me remind you that, today, only one in four businesses in the EU pays within the period agreed in the contract. Putting it another way, 60% of European businesses are regularly paid late, and this is really dangerous. Over half of those businesses suffer payment delays of more than 90 days.  For a small company, the probability of going bankrupt increases after six days of non-payment. And that is why late payments still account for 25% of insolvencies in the EU. And, of course, as everywhere in the economy, late payments are especially harmful to smaller companies – to SMEs – which rely on regular streams of liquidity to run their daily operations. Is this all or partly the Directive’s fault? I really do not think so. I fully share the rapporteur’s position that the Directive remains the most appropriate instrument to combat late payment. Under this Commission, we have strictly enforced the Directive so, on the one hand, we have opened an active dialogue with the Member States – provided guidance, provided an exchange of best practices – but, on the other hand, we have not hesitated to take more formal and stringent steps. As for today, we have six ongoing infringement cases in the European Union.  I believe that it is still too soon for the revision of the Directive. The point is that late payment is a very complex problem that cannot be solved through legislation alone. I rather think that any change to either hard or soft law should be preceded by a profound change in the business culture and this is what we should focus on. Evidence shows that late payments are intentional. It is widely known that businesses practice late payments to suppliers. It is the cheapest and the cost-free form of borrowing, but is it really cost-free for all of us, for the economy in its real effects? Of course not. Payment delays cascade down from one supplier to the next. In most cases, late payments are also avoidable as in the case of delays in public contracts. Let me focus a little bit more on this issue.  Lengthy administrative procedures result in extending the payment deadlines artificially and, again, this is especially damaging to smaller companies who are more dependent on contracts with public authorities. In fact I have to tell you that I find late payments by public authorities even more inexcusable than those by private businesses, because we should remember that these are the same public authorities who have very limited tolerance for late payments in the other direction, so from businesses to the tax authorities. Again, this is very dangerous. The report describes the fear factor affecting smaller businesses – fear that prevents businesses from using the rights the Directive has granted. Fear forces businesses to accept unfair payment conditions from larger counterparts and this is the case for 70% of small and medium enterprises. So, abuse becomes habit, and habit becomes a culture. I firmly believe in the freedom of negotiations, but this freedom should not be abused to the disadvantage of the creditor. The report lays down a thorough roadmap for building a more responsible payment culture and also strikes the right balance between combating late payments and defending contractual freedoms. It also calls for more transparency of payment practices, stronger enforcement policies and more education on financial matters, again especially for SMEs.  I am also pleased to see that the report takes into account several conclusions of the Commission’s own Implementation Report from 2016. I believe that more can be achieved now by leading by example and it can be done much more effectively.  The Directive calls for a decisive shift towards a culture of prompt payment, and this should be, in my view, our ultimate aim. Prompt payment speeds up the flow of money in the economy. It ultimately benefits everyone in society. So again, I want to applaud the report for the strong message in recognising and rewarding prompt payment practices. Before concluding, I want to say one word on the very hard work of the rapporteur, Ms Comi, and of course the shadow rapporteurs. It was a huge effort in a short time. The result is a very thorough, very balanced and inspirational report, and I also want to thank President Tajani and my predecessor for adopting and starting to implement the Directive. I am looking forward to the debate and, of course, I want to call on you to accept the report.

name: Lara Comi
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, First of all, I apologise because I understood that the debate was starting at 6 p.m., so I apologise to you, to my fellow Members and, above all, to the Commissioner.  I would really like to thank my fellow Members who have worked with me on this report because, as has been said, it is an important and very sensitive and useful issue, not least for the survival of our European businesses.  The first question I asked ourselves and asked ourselves together is: how do you measure the state of health of a company? Certainly when there is a good balance between an economic aspect and a financial and capital aspect and when a company is able to invest and be able to expand, create jobs and also generate benefits in that economy that is both national and international.  Today, however, many European companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, which are the industrial fabric at European level, are forced to face many obstacles in order to cope with the crisis. Obstacles such as the delay in payments, in commercial transactions, by another company or, above all, and this is the real problem, on the part of the public administration. In Europe, six out of ten companies are paid late, compared to what is stipulad in the contract.  We considered some cases: 62% of cases with financial difficulties concerning their debtors, 48% of intentional late payments, 45% of administrative inefficiencies and 19% of disputes.  But the real problem with aggravating the situation is often when one passively accepts longer payment periods, because there is a dominant position of some companies over others. Think that, if everything were properly applied in payments, we could really avoid cases that we have also seen in the news in Italy but also in other realities, where entrepreneurs take their own lives, where entrepreneurs are so desperate and go bankrupt but for unpaid debts, not for unpaid debts, and this also leads to job losses and relocations.  Starting with the directive that the Commissioner mentioned in 2011, which did not achieve the objective we set ourselves in all the Member States, we have decided to introduce, in this proposal, a greater effort to pay within thirty days, as had also been established, and greater transparency with regard to late payment behaviour.  We must help, value businesses and entrepreneurs and also the public administration that pays in good standing, with a so-called white list, promote those who are good and capable, provide entrepreneurs with adequate training in credit management and invoices and considering that thousands of start-ups and SMEs fail every year due to late payment by the public administration , it is necessary to provide mandatory and adequate forms of tax compensation, including compensation and other forms of support, such as factoring, which unfortunately is not yet active in my country.  We also need to promote best practices such as the Spanish one that we have also introduced into the document and the project, precisely because when a local authority is unable to pay, the State intervenes.  All of these, I think, are very good solutions, also linked to the issue of public procurement. It is good to exclude contractors who do not comply with future contracts if subcontractors are not paid on time by the main contractor, because this means that best practice ultimately says who is wrong pays, but to all effects and also to the consequences.  Member States are invited to set up mediation services at national level. I believe that if everyone paid properly, we would save EUR 158 million in financial costs. We can do that, we have to do it and thank you all, because we have managed to achieve a very good result.  (The Speaker agreed to answer a blue card question (Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Cristian Dan Preda (PPE)
text: question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. –In fact, I wanted to intervene to ask why the Presidency Romanian of the Council is not here. Mrs Comi addressed the Member States earlier. I have also noticed that even in the previous debate of the Terricabras report, where it was about the rule of law and fundamental rights, the Presidency Romanian was not present. I have the impression that they did not understand that they had to participate, on behalf of the Council, in these debates, and it is absolutely regrettable. I'd like to know what's going on.

name: Lara Comi (PPE)
text: Answer to a blue card question. I will go into more detail on the reason why they are not present, but there is no justification for not being here, and it seems to me to be a great lack of respect for our entrepreneurs and european citizens for their non-presence.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: I note that many presidencies repeatedly fail to be there, and I do not think that is too good. However, I do not think it is too good to note this only in one presidency and not for everyone. That is why colleagues should take the same measure.

name: Andreas Schwab
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur. Madam President, you have known me for a long time, and you know that we have repeatedly lamented – and I personally too – the absence of the Presidency of the Council. That is why I believe that the point misses the point. A few years ago, we did indeed have a major problem in Europe. Late payments between Northern And Southern Europe vary up to 180 days. This shows that we have particular regional difficulties, and Mrs Comi's report has taken particular account of these difficulties. We have seen that we have really achieved something by amending the late payments directive, which we adopted in the last parliamentary term: late payments have decreased. But late payments are, of course, always a problem that must be seen in the context of economic development. That is why we must make it clear once again – and Mrs Comi's report makes it very clear – that small and medium-sized enterprises suffer particularly from late payment, and that is why the report's demands in this direction are of real importance. Secondly, there must, of course, also be exceptions to strict rules for small and medium-sized enterprises, because if companies want to agree on something different among themselves, then there must be room for this, because freedom of contract applies in the European Union. Thirdly, we must also be careful not to create different late payments rules for each sector, but that it is clear – as with passenger rights – that late payments are not allowed in the European Union. There is a minimum payment target, and everyone must respect that. In this sense, I believe that the report sends out the right signal.

name: Maria Grapini
text: on behalf of the S&D group – Madam President, Commissioner, dear colleagues, first of all, I want to say that, as rapporteur for the political group, the whole debate on this report has been in a very fair atmosphere. Political ambitions and hubris were not taken into account here. Thank you to Mrs Lara Comi, who led the negotiation very well. Commissioner, you also mentioned that, in fact, the directive, which was a first step in 2011 and adopted in 2013, did not achieve the goal that we hoped for – namely to cut payment delays. Because I am also a co-chair of the SME Intergroup, where, in fact, this report has been debated, I want to tell you that, regardless of the Member State, everyone has raised the same issue: the issue of SMEs. I am in a shortage of business-to-business negotiation power and this is where we need to intervene. Also, in relation to the State – our rapporteur said – I also say that there should be compensation, that the SME should not receive the money from the authorities because, yes, I agree with the Commissioner: we need to improve the entrepreneurial culture. The problem is what we do with the culture of public, central or local governments, which do not pay and which creates a chain of nonpayments. Cash flow, liquidity are affected and I am glad that we have been able to negotiate and have in this report and that 'white list', which has been talked about before, to be transparent. But we must have secure levers so as not to lead to the bankruptcy of many small and medium-sized enterprises. That is why I believe that the directive needs to be amended. (The speaker agreed to answer a question put in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure))

name: Paul Rübig (PPE)
text: Question about the procedure of the "blue card". I would like to ask Mrs Grapini whether it would not be possible for the European Union to make the delay in payment transparent.  We have a great many European Union programmes, and I note that many small and medium-sized enterprises here have to wait a very long time for liquidity to be restored. Could we not make a mapping in the European institutions to ensure that we, as the European Union, also comply with this late payment directive?

name: Maria Grapini (S&D)
text: answer to a question asked in accordance with the 'blue card' procedure. – First of all, I want to say that Mr Rübig is very active in the SME Intergroup and is a supporter of SMEs. Yes, I agree! This is what we must do, and I hope, Commissioner, that you take into account the indirect proposal made by my colleague, Mr Rübig, because there are delays on the part of the European institutions and obviously the Member States, after which, in turn, delay payments to SMEs. I agree and hope that this proposal can be included in the Commission's programme.

name: Richard Sulík
text: for the ECR Group - Madam President, thank you very much. Contract freedom is one extremely important principle between companies and in the functioning of the economy. It is these activities that undermine contractual freedom. Because comisa or even Parliament enters into relationships between private contractors, private buyers, because politicians think they know much better and would like to regulate something. We'll do our best if we don't get involved in this at all.  Yes, there are companies that pay late. Come on, just don't let those companies be delivered. Each supplier must protect his claims himself. They must not be protected by the Commission, because it simply will not work.  Therefore, if the Commissioner thinks that late payments really need to be addressed, please let her start with the European Commission itself, which has had major shortfalls in paying on time not long. Or all the Eu funds that go. It goes from beech to beech money. There are also late payments in the Europarlament. Please take a nice look at this, but don't assemble in the private sector. He can do his best without you. Thank you very much.

name: Jasenko Selimovic
text: on behalf of the ALDE Group. – Madam President, the entire European economy, especially small and medium-sized companies, is negatively affected by late payments. The EU has taken some action against this – we have this directive and liquidity flow in businesses has increased – but we still have a way to go. According to the figures provided by the Commission, more than half of Member States, and more than half of Member States’ companies, are still not paying and respecting the 30—day limit imposed by the law. Even worse, many of these small companies are not asking for compensation because they are afraid of becoming the enemy of somebody to whom they owe money. Our report puts forward measures that will improve this. We are encouraging Member States to introduce even stricter payment terms. We are calling for the introduction of mandatory information – as was talked about just five seconds ago – on payment behaviour, such as databases and registers for both the public and private sectors. We are urging Member States to set the national and regional free and confidential mediation services so that these businesses can go to somebody else and ask them to fight their cause instead of them.  To finish, we are advising Member States to take all necessary steps in order to ensure that the public authorities pay their suppliers in due time, because this is happening sometimes for economic reasons and sometimes for political reasons as well. By doing this, Member States will increase the liquidity flow in businesses and help to fulfil their obligations, and we will manage to make the business climate in Europe better than it is today.

name: Igor Šoltes
text: Mr President, commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, i would like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent work. – Madam President, it is therefore a subject that is extremely important for the economy in the European Union and also for payment discipline. As we have seen in the past and every day, late payments in commercial transactions are unfortunately the reality facing many European companies. And here, in fact, none of the European countries is particularly safe. In particular, small and medium-sized enterprises are particularly at stake, which most often receive this delay in payments. This, of course, has very serious consequences. We have heard of cases where small medium-sized enterprises have gone bankrupt, when whole families have suffered as a result. And it is that, of course, we can and must leave a lot of things to the market itself, but we certainly need to put in place a regulation that will protect the weaker from the abuse of the stronger. And these late payments are just one form of so-called illicit trade practices, which unfortunately too often occurs at every turn. And non-payment or late payment is only one of these elements, apart of, of course, the return of unsued goods, the mi mishandling of small suppliers, and I think that, as the European Union, we have a duty to provide for mechanisms that will protect weaker in this part. However, in addition to this mediation, which colleagues have already mentioned, I would like to mention one thing: there is also a public sector among the large defaulting payers or late payers. And there are, of course, no excuses that we cannot act on this part. I think we have huge reserves here, and of course, the countries themselves can do the most, it is just a shame that the public sector also often contributes to this late payment delay.

name: Jiří Maštálka
text: on the part of the GUE/NGL Group. – Madam President, thousands of SMEs go bankrupt every year across the European Union while waiting for their invoices to be reimbursed. Late payments in Europe cause many cases of insolvency, leading to social difficulties and job losses. The 2011 Directive on the procedure against late payment in commercial transactions was intended to improve the situation for companies. I thank the rapporteur for mapping and showing in detail the situation surrounding the implementation of this directive. It turns out that there are still a number of problems and obstacles, such as a lack of awareness of the existence of this legal instrument. I would also like to say that there is only a small percentage of SMEs that have experienced positive effects on late payments from debtors thanks to this directive.  Ladies and gentlemen, we have much to improve. I do not agree with my colleague Sulík not to get involved in this matter, because there is no worse enemy for medium and small businesses than the Tax Office and its apparatus, which always plays a power play. I therefore fully support the rapporteur and her proposals for a number of measures that could lead to improved enforcement of the Late Payment Directive. The aim must be to set a level playing field for all companies. As this is the case, Madam President – please – for my probably last speech in this Parliament, I want to thank everyone I have been able to work with in 17 years, starting with the Bureau and ending with interpreters.

name: Róża Gräfin von Thun und Hohenstein (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab I always stress that, overnight, we see how positively our lives have changed, thanks to the fact that we are all in the European Union. But every day we observe and discover that we could, that we need to do more and more. We have achieved a lot: the elimination of geoblocking, the elimination of roaming – these are spectacular huge successes. We have managed to do this, and we are all, all citizens of the European Union. Today we are looking at the situation of entrepreneurs in the European Union and we have a report on the implementation of the directive on so-called late payments. Many small businesses have a problem due to unpaid payments. The spectre of bankruptcy due to delays is facing many entrepreneurs who are still sufficiently worried about intricate regulations, e.g. tax or low liquidity. That is why we are checking whether the law adopted in this parliamentary term is working as it should. And what turns out? It doesn't work. The report rightly points out points where the application of the rules could be much better. However, this matter – let us remember – is the responsibility of the Member States and they are responsible for the proper implementation and enforcement of EU rules. It is important to call for greater transparency, e.g. with regard to payment behaviour. This solution could encourage sluggd debtors to pay their debts more speedily. Both when we adopted this directive and today we have to balance all the reasons. The objectives of regulation, such as increasing employment, protecting the creditor or economic growth, are very important in this case. Entrepreneurs – last sentence, Madam President – entrepreneurs, especially small and medium-sized ones, are a flywheel for us, and pacta sunt servanda we have to work anyway.

name: Nicola Danti (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, it must be acknowledged that the 2011 directive on late payments has certainly had a positive effect in recent years, at least to reduce the average period of winding-up times for companies.  However, we also know that 95 % of Europe's small and medium-sized enterprises still do not receive compensation for services on time and sometimes, on the contrary, this delay leads to bankruptcies for many companies. I therefore believe that this report, which Parliament will adopt tomorrow, seeks to propose improvements to eradicate this scourge. In particular, I would like to highlight three points: firstly, to introduce faster repayment and recovery procedures for companies with claims against public administrations.  Secondly, to promote the establishment of free and accessible mediation services to support small and medium-sized enterprises, which often do not have the appropriate financial means to deal with lengthy legal disputes.  My third point is that it should be made compulsory to publish information on public and private bodies that pay at the right time. I believe, Madam President, that the certainty of payment times is a very important challenge that we have and can also appear difficult, given the not very brilliant results of recent years. However, this is the background to the competitiveness of our European system of European companies, and I believe that it is right to guarantee an environment in which payments are on time and which is an environment in which they can carry out their activities well.

name: Anneleen Van Bossuyt (ECR).
text: – Mr President, late payments are often a noose around the necks of small businesses. In order to grow, to innovate, to recruit, they desperately need their hard-earned pennies. A late invoice often deprives them of the oxygen that is crucial for them to survive.  I therefore urge the Commission and the Member States to stand up for our small and medium-sized enterprises, which are ultimately the backbone of our economy. The loopholes in the legislation that give defaulters free rein must be closed. Two out of three Belgian companies accept a longer payment period than those they actually consider comfortable. That's why my party submitted a bill at the national level in 2017 to set the maximum payment period. From Europe, too, we now need a strong signal not to allow late payments.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab We are debating an extremely important issue. It is important, because it is a disaster – a disaster in payments. As the Commissioner rightly pointed out, these are, on the one hand, the cheapest loans – the cheapest, of course, for those who take them, but extremely costly for those who give them or to whom they are received.  But I wanted to talk about a different topic on this occasion, which is why I came forward. We can have some satisfaction ourselves. We started our term in the European Parliament by drawing attention to our own late payments, for example through programmes such as Erasmus+, Creative Europe, Europe for Citizens. After four years, we can say that at least the Commission has improved efficiency in commitments and payments. This allows us to talk more strongly, with a stronger mandate, about these backlogs, about those commitments that are on the part of economic operators.

name: John Howarth (S&D).
text: – Madam President, I would like to express my thanks to the rapporteur and the Commissioner. Those of us who have run small businesses understand that it isn’t a lack of profitability that sends a business under, it’s a lack of cash, and thousands suffer from this in the EU every year. Last year I hosted an event with the Federation of Small Businesses from the UK on the need to improve the enforcement of the Late Payment Directive, and I’m pleased to see that this report proposes exactly that. Linking procurement rules with the terms of the directive – a particularly important measure after the collapse of Carillion last year – is exactly the kind of initiative we need. Automatic accrual of interest for the public sector: the public sector should lead by example and should pay on time. Mandatory reporting requirements for larger firms has been a positive step in the UK, and other Member States should replicate this. These are all important steps. The Commission should now launch a new public consultation as the next step to strengthening the Late Payment Directive.

name: Caterina Chinnici (S&D).
text: Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, despite the 2011 directive against late payment in commercial transactions, European companies, especially small and medium-sized enterprises, continue to be too late in collecting claims and not just with regard to the public administration.  In Italy, but not only in my country, the economic fabric is mainly made up of small and medium-sized enterprises which tend to accept longer payment periods by larger companies, for fear of damaging trade relations.  More incisive measures must therefore be developed to discourage what are in fact becoming unfair practices, taking into account the specificity of each production sector, on the model of the directive on unfair practices in the agri-food chain, aimed at protecting small producers in a sector characterised by serious imbalances in bargaining power.  It is essential that the Commission and the Member States develop awareness-raising campaigns on compliance with payment times and legal remedies against delays, and this also applies to claims against the public administration.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Madam President, delays in trade, i.e. non-payment on time on the part of private companies, poses a huge problem for the private sector itself and, of course, it is a process that can lead to bankruptcies. But the biggest problem is that the State owes, because it is the State that requires taxpayers to pay and, when they do not pay or have difficulty paying taxes – such as the poor Greeks – then the state makes foreclosures. He's confiscating the accounts, he's confiscating their property. But in this state, the Greek State currently owes, with December 2018 data, one billion euros to the private sector. Do you know why he owes it? Because he keeps the money in order to pay the lenders, to create the famous primary surplus. The Commission is aware of this, but prefers that lenders should be paid by the Greek State rather than that the Greek State should pay private companies.

name: Elżbieta Bieńkowska
text: Member of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to thank all of the Members for this debate, but I especially want to thank you for again putting the late payment issue into the spotlight. It was a good debate and I believe that voting tomorrow will also be positive for this very good report. I want to remind you that we have been dealing with this issue in the EU since 1995 and there is still a lot of work to be done, especially in the area of changing the culture, as I said. Every business and every public institution must understand that this is in their own interest, that prompt payments really are in their own benefit. Since some of you have asked, I also want to underline that of course EU institutions – just like each and every European institution and business and public institution in Europe – have the same obligation under this directive. So let me tell you that the European Commission has introduced a zero tolerance rule for any late payments in the EU institutions. So this is something new and I hope it will give good results in the future. Thank you very much for this and let me say that, of course, the work on late payments is not yet finished. (Applause)

name: Lara Comi
text: Rapporteur. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, Commissioner, I would like to thank all my fellow Members who have spoken because it has been a very constructive dialogue, but constructive work for businesses and citizens.  I would just like to make two very brief comments on it: the first, when a State does not comply with the late payment directive, goes into breach. Be ware that this method of infringement leads to penalties and therefore to an additional payment, which then affects the citizens, and this is a problem, because you pay twice as much, that is, the State does not pay you and in addition you also have to pay for the infringement. So you have to find another method.  The other thing that President Tajani mentioned before you was that, for example for Italy, it was possible to exceed 3 % to pay off the debts of the public administration. Of course, this must not be the rule, but austerity, as Mr Juncker rightly pointed out yesterday, is not achieved, and so there is no excuse, in this case for Italy, for not paying public administration debts to businesses. I think that this can also be used for other states. Thank you very much and we trust in tomorrow's vote.

name: Die Präsidentin. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 January 2019. Written declarations (Article 162)

name: Lidia Joanna Geringer de Oedenberg (S&D)
text: in writing. – Late payments remain one of the problems of the European Single Market. In Europe, six out of ten businesses receive payments after the deadline set in a contract.
