Yesterday, the Commissioner said that InvestEU is being directed much more policy-driven, as it has just been discussed here in questions. You have to report on that. I would like to know a little more about Jaspers, as well as your changing role in opinions and, of course, Mrs Gräβle is right: those governance aspects, you really need to do something about that.

name: Seán Kelly (PPE).
text: – Madam President, we don’t see Mr Hoyer around these parts too often, nor should we because it’s not his place of work, but it’s good to have him here today and to listen to and to exchange discussions and views with him. Also, it’s an opportunity for us to compliment the good work that the European Investment Bank (EIB) has done in boosting investment and especially in helping to lead to growth and prosperity. Over 60 years, EUR 1.1 trillion in 160 countries is pretty impressive. Above all, I think the role you have played in helping to get us out of the recession in the last number of years is very significant. And I think also you opened an office of the Bank in Dublin two years ago, with Mr Cormac Murphy at the helm, and I want to compliment him on the good work he is doing and indeed the cooperation he and Commissioner Katainen have given me when I’ve held several seminars around my constituency regarding the European Fund for Strategic Investments (EFSI). These have been a huge success, as you pointed out. I am pleased that I was a rapporteur for his successor for the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy. We voted overwhelmingly today to continue on in that vein in InvestEU. I think that, as other speakers have said, we especially want to see more emphasis being put on supporting SMEs. I agree with the rapporteur when they said that we should have in particular more advisory capacities for SMEs so they can see the opportunities.  So, overall, a good job has been done. I welcome also what you said about Brexit, but I do hope that the Member States will show the same generosity in filling the gap left by the United Kingdom regarding our general budget.

name: Bogdan Andrzej Zdrojewski (PPE).
text: – Madam President, i voted in favour of the report by Mrs Schwab Four main points. Firstly, it seems that the EFSI is working, which is something to be enjoyed. It seems – secondly – that the leverage set up for this programme is unfortunately not quite there, but I would remind you that it was designed extremely optimistically. Thirdly, geographical disparities are weakening, which we note with satisfaction, but unfortunately very slowly. Fourthly, it is important that we take space technologies into account more and more dynamically than before in space investment projects.  What is important? Planning is, of course, important. Please do not take this as a malice, just attention, because the speech was interesting, but the President has exceeded his time limit by 312%, and In turn, Commissioner Katainen has used his time only 69%. For us in the European Parliament, it is important to represent high precision and high discipline.

name: Stanislav Polčák (PPE).
text: – Madam President, I am aware of the position of the European Investment Bank, which is primarily about investing in strategic investments in sustainable growth and, of course, in strengthening jobs. This is important for our SMEs, of course for regions that are disadvantaged. From this point of view, I, too, want to promote the value of that balance, or territorial cohesion, and if we are talking about SMEs here, we should also tell each other truthfully that, according to the annual report, 40% of investments by the European Investment Bank went towards SMEs, so in this respect, I think, the objective has been achieved. Rather, I would call for some precautions within those loans that are granted. I understand that the aim is also to increase the efficiency of the loans granted, but in the context of volatile financial markets, the precautionary aspect, which has not been fully mentioned here, is also important in my opinion.

name: Jyrki Katainen
text: Vice-President of the Commission. – Madam President, I would like to praise the work that Member Kelly has done in his constituency. I know he’s not the only one who has done the same, but I wanted to raise his work as an example because it is exactly what we need. We need to tell our citizens – our companies – what is available, how they can benefit from the European Investment Bank and what EFSI can offer, because otherwise there is a risk that people don’t know.  EU institutions and even our financial instruments are not as simple to understand as a normal bank loan from a local bank and that’s why we have to spread the word.  The reason why some Member States have benefited more than others and some regions have benefited more than others, for instance from EFSI, is mostly because there have been active politicians or public authorities which have told citizens and companies what is available. My second point is just to thank Members for a substantial, civilised and rather consensual discussion on this issue. It’s a good basis to continue cooperation. (Applause)

name: Werner Hoyer
text: President of the European Investment Bank. – Madam President, I am now in a little bit of a dilemma. I’ve just been criticised for overdrawing my time account and I have roughly 20 questions that deserve precise answers, so please forgive me if I don’t address them all, but I promise again that you will get the answers in an appropriate way and as soon as possible.  A few general remarks.  The question of regional distribution begins to touch my nerves, because I think that everybody who has a feeling that his or her own country has maybe one per mil less than their neighbour is complaining about regional distribution. I told you the facts and figures about EFSI projects. In general, for all EIB projects the GDP-based distribution of the lending shows Greece number 1, Cyprus number 2, Portugal number 3, Croatia number 4 and Poland number 5. Is that so wrong? I think this is exactly the priority setting that you’re expecting from us. So I think we are making real progress on that question.  Second issue, I just wanted to throw into the debate the word infrastructure, as I heard it several times. The European Union has a significant problem with infrastructure, the quality of the infrastructure. We are not investing enough in the maintenance of our infrastructures, which leads to a structural degradation of the quality. We need to address this issue. It is much more sexy to build new things than to maintain old ones, but this is an issue we have to address. A very interesting question that somebody raised about start-ups. We have a serious problem here in corporate financing in Europe in general, but in start-up financing in particular. The fact is that roughly 75% of all corporate financing in Europe is via banks and not via capital markets. In the US it’s exactly the other way round, and this is the reason why sometimes, when an intelligent inventor develops something new, opens a market, develops a new product, then he or she might be very, very successful in the start-up phase but then comes growth financing and for growth financing we don’t have enough instruments.  I would love to see EIB activities developing further in this field because I hate seeing sometimes the most promising products leaving Europe and then being developed with huge money in other continents.  By the way, we measure the employment effects of our activities as precisely as we can, so maybe we can give you a couple of figures afterwards. But I just saw that, for instance, our analysis shows that in 2018 the number of SMEs supported was 285 000 and the number of jobs maintained in SMEs and midcaps was 3.9 million. We probably need to publish these figures more loudly and with more self-esteem. Financing, well long-term financing.  Ladies and gentlemen, some of you want to see us as a commercial bank and some want to see us as a political instrument. We are both. We need to perform in several areas like a commercial bank because we are refinancing completely on the capital markets. We must have the trust and the confidence of the investors, otherwise they don’t give us 60, 70, 80 billion per year in EIB bond purchases. On the other hand, we serve a public goal. Our objectives are set by you and the Council and the Commission, and that means that we have to reconcile the role of a public institution with commercial behaviour and expertise on the markets, and I think we are quite successful in doing that. On the question of transparency, Ms Gräßle, I share your view and I think we are making progress, but we still can get better. But there are two small issues I would like to address.  Number one, please bear in mind that the EIB is a very lean institution. We have 3 500 people in the Bank. It sounds a lot, but we are doing twice the volume of the World Bank with this, and eight times the volume of the European Bank for Reconstruction and Development. The World Bank has 18 000 people and the EBRD in London 2 500 people. So we are a lean institution. Sometimes we are criticised for not being represented visually with official offices in all Member States of the European Union. Yes, we try to be as efficient as possible. Please take this as a serious effort to be visible and available everywhere, but at a cost reduction or a containment strategy that we pursue.  And the last word, Ms Gräßle, on gender. Well, you run into open doors with me and whenever a Member State comes with a new proposal for the management committee and the Member State proposes a lady I will embrace that immediately. Spain has just done so and I’m very grateful for that, but we could definitely have more. But this is not in the hands of the management of the Bank. This is exclusively in the hands of the Member States. When it comes to our top managerial personnel we have made progress in the seven years that I am at the Bank now from 18% to 26% in the top positions. So we are moving in the right direction, but it cannot come overnight because you need a couple of years of career at the Bank in order to get there, but I promise you I’ll have that in view in each and every personnel decision we take as long as we don’t discriminate against the other gender. (Applause)

name: President. –
text: Thank you very much, President Hoyer, I would like to point out that I am not sure that Mr Zdrojewski wanted you to speak less. Maybe he wanted Vice-President Katainen to speak more, so it’s a great privilege for us to have you here.

name: Georgi Pirinski
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, first, of course, I would like to thank all those who commended the report. I would like to point out that this is a report by the whole committee and I take certain credit in the name of the committee for what President Hoyer has highlighted – the steps in the direction of greater transparency and greater accountability. I believe that this is an example of the usefulness of these types of discussions on this type of the report. So I think we can be satisfied from that point of view.  I also would like to return to the geographical aspect. What the President has told us are figures which also show increased awareness and movement towards a better distribution. At the same time, you will agree that a proportion of 80-10 is anything but a sustainable balance and clearly, here, there is a challenge to be met.  I would also finally like to mention that the type of discussion we have had, the fact that the President has been as outgoing as possible – and a bit excited at the end, if I may say – is a good sign of commitment for further progress.

name: President. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 January 2019.

name: Puhemies.
text: – The next item is the report by Eider Gardiazabal Rubial and Petri Sarvamaa, on behalf of the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control, on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the protection of the Union budget in situations, where there are general deficiencies in the rule of law in the Member States (COM(2018)0324 – C8-0178/2018 – 2018/0136(COD)) (A8-0469/2018).

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, Commissioner, on the other day I was asked by a journalist if he believed that this regulation was necessary and my answer was very clear: yes, no doubt.  In this mandate we have discussed several times about violations of rights in the European Union and we have also seen how existing instruments are slow and ineffective.  The European Union is a community based on common values that we must defend and respect as citizens and as Member States of the Union. This is not an a la carte Europe, in which we can keep the rights and not the duties.  When a State wants to join the Union, it has to meet a number of requirements in economic, political, fiscal, judicial matters... These requirements are many and very strict, and so it takes years for candidate countries to enter—if they succeed." And, once inside, what happens? Once we've passed that test, can we do whatever we want? Obviously not. This review has to be continuous, and if deficiencies are found, they must be corrected, and if not, an effective and proportionate system of sanctions must be established.  I must confess that I would have preferred direct sanctions, but I understand that the Treaty, in these cases, does not provide for it. So I think the Commission has made a very clever proposal, using the tools at its disposal, in this case the European budget.  But, as I said in the Committee on Budgets, I believe that the European Commission has also missed a golden opportunity, because if we put together the two ideas I have just developed — that is, respect for the values of the European Union, but also the protection of the budget — we fall short if we only stick to the rule of law. Because the values we are talking about are the values enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on Union: respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, human rights, solidarity, justice, tolerance... All of those are in Article 2. Those are the ones that define our Union and those are the ones we have to protect.  But we also need to protect the European budget, and there is no greater attack on public accounts, solidarity and European values than evasion, fraud and unfair tax competition. And that is why it seemed to me essential that this was also one of the values, of the criteria to be controlled, examined and sanctioned, if necessary. We cannot speak of equality, of justice, of solidarity if we look the other way at fiscal injustice.  In our meetings preparing Parliament's position, in addition to discussing — as you know perfectly well — the subject-matter of the Rules of Procedure, we have also discussed and negotiated fundamentally three aspects.  One: the protection of final beneficiaries. In imposing sanctions through the European budget, we need to be very scrupulous about the mechanisms and make sure that these sanctions go directly to the offenders and not to the final beneficiaries. And that is why I believe that with the amendments made — thanks to the Commission's technical services we have been able to work on this — the safety net we have defined is much more guaranteeing for the final beneficiaries.  The second aspect on which we have also worked is the panel of experts, because decision-making under this Regulation is going to be a very sensitive issue. The European Commission must have at its disposal all the information possible in order to be able to make a reasoned, objective decision and, above all, away from any partisan temptation, and this is the objective of establishing a panel of experts: that they can advise the European Commission on this task.  And finally, the role of the European Parliament. In the Commission's proposal, our role was mere observer and this is not acceptable, because we are talking about values, but a budget, and, in the budget, this House is also a budgetary authority, as is the Council, and we must therefore have a say.  I end, Madam President, with a sentence you said this morning, during the debate, the President of the Government, Pedro Sánchez: it is time to defend and protect the values that make our project a unique project.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: Rapporteur. – Madam President, democracy is never self—evident. Never. This we should keep in mind. One of the most crucial things, if not the most crucial thing to sustain democracy in any state is the rule of law. Once the rule of law is questioned, the path to the keys of Pandora’s Box is open to all, because, my dear colleagues, democracy is never perfect.  Democracy, through elections, can produce governments and leaders who are tempted to take that walk to Pandora’s Box and see if they can control it. On their way, they might tamper with the judicial system of the state, or they could find it handy to influence the media so that journalists would not see it in their best interest to criticise those in power. Or maybe these political leaders would like to introduce laws that make it more and more difficult for civic organisations to go about their activities, to express their ideas and worries. In doing all this, these governments and their leaders would clearly be undermining the rule of law, which is the central pillar of democracy. This, unfortunately, is nothing but a factual description of what is going on inside the European Union today. If we want to safeguard democracy itself, we need to safeguard the rule of law.  It has been painfully clear for years already that the presently available legal mechanisms in the Union do not stop governments on this dangerous path, and this is why we have this extremely important regulation in front of us. We need a mechanism that will introduce concrete consequences for the Member States in question, and that is why the Commission wisely followed the will of this Parliament – Parliament’s Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF) resolution – and proposed a budgetary law for co—decision.  According to the Commission proposal and our final report, in order for the Union to protect its financial interests from the risk of financial loss caused by generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law, the Union should be able to impose appropriate measures that include restricting, reducing or even suspending access to EU funding in a manner proportionate to the nature, gravity and scope of the deficiencies.  Let me finally underline the five things that are most crucial to understand about this legislative report. One: the legal basis for this proposal is in financial regulation, not in Article 7. This is about protecting the EU’s budget – taxpayers’ money. Two: we want to write a law that is the same for all Member States. The rule of law could be in jeopardy in any Member State. Three: we want to protect the final beneficiaries of EU funds – researchers, civic organisations and ordinary citizens must not suffer due to the freezing or cutting of funds. Four: we are talking about generalised deficiencies as regards the rule of law. There would have to be clear and widespread undermining of the rule of law before the budgetary consequences could be launched. And finally, five: our report puts Parliament on an equal footing with the Council, through a co—decision procedure of a transfer to a budgetary reserve.  With these words, I sincerely hope that every Member of this Chamber takes a close look at this report. When you do, I trust that you will consider it of the utmost importance to support this proposal and give us a strong mandate for the trilogues, since nothing in today’s Europe is as important as the rule of law. Last, but certainly not least, let me wholeheartedly thank and praise my co-rapporteur, Ms Gardiazabal Rubial, for her excellent work on this report.

name: Judith Sargentini
text: Rapporteur LIBE. Mr President, I am honoured to be replaced today by my green colleague Josep-Maria Terricabras. He is actually rapporteur for the opinion of the LIBE Committee and I am convinced with him that this proposal is necessary. We need a new tool in our toolbox to keep Member States in the classroom. It is our job to protect European citizens from governments that violate the rights of those individual citizens. Making European subsidies dependent on respect for the rule of law and civil rights is, in my view, such a new tool in that toolbox that we need in order to properly support the Union.  I see European governments – and yes, I am thinking of Hungary, of course – getting away with self-enrichment and with old-fashioned agitprop. We can't stand by and watch. The LIBE Committee therefore proposed that the test on civil rights should be strengthened in the proposal. These citizens' rights are enshrined in the European Convention on Human Rights. They are not just part of the rule of law, no, they are very proud of it. I would therefore ask you to support the libe rapporteur's amendment, Amendment 72. This report will be even better.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Madam President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would like to begin by thanking all the committed Members of the Commission, the rapporteurs Mrs Gardiazabal Rubial and Mr Sarvamaa, but also you, Mrs Sargentini, for the very, very knowledgeable and thorough, good consideration of our proposal, which you want to accept in principle but want to improve further. For that ours, my thanks and respect. The Commission's proposal for a regulation on the protection of the Union's budget in the event of general shortcomings in the rule of law is about developing an instrument for the next budgetary framework, and therefore for the budgetary policy of the future, in order to protect Europe and its budget in the best possible way, and hence our citizens and taxpayers, from abuse, corruption, deficiencies, fraud and infidelity. Strong support from Parliament is crucial for further discussions with the Council. We should have had the instrument for a long time. The fact that we are now proposing it is a purely logical approach. Because if our budget programmes, where we promote projects, where we process and approve applications, where we provide money, can also lead to disputes with partners, with beneficiaries, with Member States, regions, municipalities and disputes, we must be able to rely in every Member State on the courts being independent, being obliged to the rule of law, and being free of instructions. that the rule of law applies fully everywhere. Member States already have to demonstrate that their rules and procedures for the use of EU funds are effective and that there is sufficient protection against abuse or fraud. With this proposal, we are strengthening our instruments and we are increasing our authority as the European Union. For there is no mechanism in any Member State to protect the money of our citizens and taxpayers in the event of general shortcomings in the rule of law. The focus on protecting the EU's financial interests is important to me. In my opinion, the current definition of the scope of our proposal ensures a meaningful balance, it serves to protect the Union's budget and other existing EU mechanisms, such as Article 7 of our Treaty. It is not a question of sanctions, it is about protecting European funds and, therefore, about the economic and correctness of the implementation of the budget at European level. We propose a transparent and objective mechanism. All possible measures under this new procedure must always be proportionate to the nature and severity of the rule of law deficit. In other words, cuts in funds or cancellations of funds must always be related to the abuse, to the rule of law deficit. It has been mentioned that the citizen, the beneficiary, the student, the researcher, the promoter of social projects must not be the stupid one. That is why the citizens and the project should get what the project and the citizens can expect. Burden-sharing is at the expense of our civil society, our students, our scientists, our beneficiaries as a whole. If the Commission has reason to believe that there is a rule of law deficit and could therefore affect the financial interests of the European Union and its citizens, then we will initiate a procedure that could lead to the adoption of appropriate remedial measures. We have to take into account: decisions of the Court of Justice, reports from the Court of Auditors, conclusions of relevant competent organisations. Before we take a decision, we will and must consult the Member State concerned and give it the opportunity to give a comprehensive opinion. And the fact that Parliament wants to be involved here alongside the Council on an equal footing, that it wants to be part of the decision-making process, I think is more than obvious, I think is consistent, and I also support that. Nevertheless, the decision-making process must be immediate, rapid and efficient, constitutional and unbureaucratic. In addition, we, as the Commission, have to account for every measure, for every step, before you, Parliament, the House. At this stage, after the exchange with the Council and Parliament has reached the report to be debated here today, we should discuss in depth the following issues for the forthcoming discussions between the Council and Parliament: the link between the shortcomings and the protection of the Union's financial interests. The demarcation between this proposal and the instrument and other mechanisms, such as Article 7 of our Treaty, remains clear and must be be clear. There must be no grey area between different instruments and possibilities for action. To this end, we have used the expert advice of our legal services and will continue to ensure that the whole thing really clearly describes which instrument can be used in which case. In the Council, some Member States are calling for the list of possible shortcomings to be specified, extended or even comprehensiveand, and thus exhaustive, drawn up. This would create legal certainty. I think that is true. We are ready to expand the list. However, it must remain open in order to allow the mechanism to be applied, even in unforeseeable cases, and thus to give Europe every opportunity to respond appropriately to any situation that may arise in the future. An indicative time limit is discussed within which the Commission must act after receiving a reply from the Member State concerned, i.e. a reasonable and limited period of time. We think this is obvious, but I think that thoroughness over speed applies here. In the case of complex issues, it is more important to me that the Commission should be able to examine it fully, and therefore the deadline must not be too short, but should only begin after the Member State has been consulted and its opinion has been delivered. They want to see the sources of information on which the Commission builds its work more precisely. I think this too is quite obvious. The list of case-law to which the Commission can refer and the sources of information that we use can be clarified and defined in concrete terms, as requested by Parliament. I also think that the question of how to further strengthen the protection of the final beneficiary is worth discussing. The rule of law mechanism that you are discussing today and which is in good hands with you is an important building block of our Commission proposal for the next Multiannual Financial Framework 2021-2027. If you agree with it, it should and will make an important contribution to the sound and regularity of the financial management, thereby strengthening the protection of taxpayers' money and thus of citizens and taxpayers accordingly. We are thus filling a gap in European law. I would ask you to fill the gap in the best possible way and, in the course of our deliberations this year, to take a decision that can be an important complementary basis for the financial management of the future and the next decade. Thank you very much for your dedicated and knowledgeable cooperation!

name: Искра Михайлова
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Regional Development. – Mr President, Commissioner, the Committee on Regional Development, in its adopted opinion on the report under consideration, first of all points out that democracy and the rule of law, respect for fundamental human rights, are key to trusting the European Union. However, any decision to impose appropriate measures in the event of widespread disregard for the rule of law should provide robust post-impact guarantees to ensure that final recipients of European Union funds are not adversely affected. It is necessary that the scope and level of the suspension of commitments imposed be proportionate, respect the equal treatment of Member States and take into account the economic and social conditions in the country concerned and their impact on the economy. Measures laid down in the Generally accepted and Generally applicable Provisions Regulation may also apply to the European Structural and Investment Funds, where the Commission implements the Budget of the European Union under shared management, in the event of widespread disregard for the rule of law. In order to strengthen the protection of end-users of European Union support, the Commission should actively monitor compliance with the legal obligation of public authorities and Member States to continue payments and inform final recipients of their rights in the event of infringements.

name: Helmut Scholz
text: Draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs. Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has On behalf of the Committee on Constitutional Affairs, I stress the importance of protecting the EU budget from general shortcomings in the implementation of the rule of law in a Member State. Yes, there is a link between this and the implementation of the budget in accordance with the principles of sound financial management. The independence and impartiality of the judiciary are essential to ensure respect for the rule of law. That is why, as the AFCO Committee, we have proposed to the leading committees that the obligation of the Member States to cooperate in this direction, irrespective of their concrete implementation and in the interests of financial solidarity between the Member States in legislation, should be clearly guaranteed.  We want the Commission to ensure that the legitimate interests of the final beneficiaries or beneficiaries of the programme or funds, who may be affected by measures taken, are fully safeguarded.  That is why we want to oblige the Commission to carry out procedural assessments of the impact of proposed measures on national budgets.  Last but not least, we believe that the role of the European Parliament in getting more involved in the actual evaluation of the procedure, in addition to information rights, must be strengthened. This whole process must be transparent and proportionate.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has That is eight narrow articles that have been presented. But I have high hopes for these eight narrow articles, because it is the first regulation to deal with fundamental shortcomings in the rule of law in the authorities of the Member States.  I welcome the Commission's proposal and thank colleagues for the report. The regulation starts at the EU's major weakness, namely Member States with corrupt structures. We see a new development in some Member States, namely state corruption. We see government officials using their influence as heads of government to get EU money for themselves or their friends and relatives, and then prevent investigations into it. The regulation should find solutions in this case. An Article 7 procedure would not solve such problems, because that article establishes a general judicial procedure. But we are dealing with selective failures by a few who fill their pockets and silence the police and the judiciary.  That is why, Commissioner, a long-held desire for budgetary control is being fulfilled this evening, namely that something happens when we have the Member States' failure to act in the event of fraud and money laundering with EU funds, because the perpetrators are prominent. That is what it is all about, and there is nothing to gloss over. This regulation does not solve all the problems, but it helps, provided that the Commission finds a way to give life to this regulation. Tax fraud does not really belong here, this is an individual offence, so it would be nice if we could vote it out together tomorrow. It weakens the regulation, it does not strengthen it.

name: Inés Ayala Sender
text: on behalf of the S&D Group – Mr President, I am very grateful, both to Mrs Gardiazábal, and especially to Mr Sarvamaa for the Committee on Budgetary Control, for all the work they have done, which has been arduous and complex. I, the truth is that I would also have preferred direct and political sanctions and in the Council, and not that it reverts us to the Commission and Parliament to carry out a job in which the good name of European funding is finally affected: it is no longer very well known, because what we lacked.  But anyway I believe that Mr Sarvamaa and Mrs Gardiazábal have obtained a good text showing the well-protected part of the funds. Because it is clear that, without independent justice, without independent judges, obviously the financial interests of European funds affecting beneficiaries, citizens cannot be protected. I believe that they have achieved this squareness of the circle, that is, to amend or seek to change the habits of governments through financial punishment, but without reaching the beneficiaries.  As for the committee of experts, I have to say that I just didn't like it very much. I understand this, I understand why it has been done, but I believe that taking decisions out of the field of political decision-makers, in this case Parliament, which already makes its human rights reports within the Union, seems to me to always end up being risky and ends up resulting in a confrontation. But I understand why it's been done and I hope we'll follow it very closely.  In short, I believe that a good text has been achieved, which is difficult and complex, but if we can implement it well and explain it, above all, well, we will get what we have been saying this morning too: that in order to achieve that Europe that protects, which Mr Macron raises, we must start first by protecting it from those who want to erode it. And in this case, this text, I think will do that.

name: Ryszard Czarnecki
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. I have been agreeing with my colleague for years, Mrs Alaya Sender: europe must be protected from those who want to destroy it. The only question is: who wants to destroy Europe? Are those who are causing a wave of Euroscepticism in the Countries of the European Union at the moment, or those who, by interfering with the internal affairs of the Member States, cause a growing revolt of societies? Sometimes on the street – as we see in France and sometimes at the ballot boxes – as we have seen in many European countries from Italy to Austria, the Czech Republic, Poland, Hungary or other countries.  It seems to me that Mr Sarvamaa was right when talking about this pandora's box. Only that we might not be opening this Pandora's box, proposing regulations that can be interpreted very differently. I grant Professor Oettinger's homeland the right to choose a politician as deputy head of the Constitutional Court in Karlsruhe. These are your affairs, if you do, (a word incomprehensible) to be the head of the Constitutional Court. But if we do not want to interfere in your affairs, I ask that you also respect the countries that have been attacked here today, for example, Hungary. They have established democracy through the ballot paper, and we should respect that. However, this is a controversial proposal.

name: Anneli Jäätteenmäki
text: On behalf of the ALDE Group. – Mr President, the rule of law is the cornerstone of democratic countries. If it is not respected, cooperation between all EU Member States and the actions of citizens will become more difficult.  Once new members have joined the EU, member states are committed to certain values and must be respected. It's about mutual trust. However, I would like to point out that this proposal will not solve all the problems, even though it has high expectations, over-expectations. The proposal is about protecting EU money and ensuring that it is spent correctly. This means, therefore, that the shortcomings of the rule of law must be linked to the use of EU money. Otherwise, this will not be possible and will not solve the problems of the rule of law in general.  I am quite sure that it will be difficult to implement this proposal. In Parliament, we have tried to protect the final beneficiaries, as we did in the Commission, of course, but I suspect it will be very difficult to ensure that they end up receiving this money. My group supports this proposal, but I would like to say that, from a legal point of view, this proposal is far from good legislation. This is complex and bureaucratic, and it will be interesting to see how this works in practice.

name: Liadh Ní Riada
text: thar ceann an Ghrúpa GUE/NGL. – A Uachtaráin, caithfidh mé a rá – ag léamh tríd seo – go bhfuil amhras orm, mar tá sé doiléir a dhóthain an rud a thuiscint ar an gcéad dul síos agus cé go bhfuil tú ag caint ar smacht reachta nó riail dlí, tá tú i ndáiríre ag déanamh rud polaiticiúil as agus tá sé deacair mar sin riail amháin a chur i dtreo amháin agus riail eile a chur i dtreo eile. Agus táim buartha mar gheall ar an tionchar a bheidh aige seo ar thíortha éagsúla; abair na tíortha saibhre, an buntáiste a bheidh ann dóibh siúd. Chomh maith leis sin, is dóigh liom go bhfuil tú ag tabhairt teachtaireacht do thíortha áirithe nach bhfuilid freagrach as foinsí airgid a thagann as an Aontas Eorpach.  Táimid, gan amhras, ag rá gur chóir an buiséad a chosaint ach, ag an am gcéanna, níor chóir go mbeadh an méid sin cumhachta ag an gCoimisiún, Coimisiún nach raibh tofa go daonlathach ar an gcéad dul síos, go mbeadh an chumhacht sin acu cinnithe a dhéanamh ar chúrsaí riail dlí i dtíortha éagsúla. Bhí an Coimisiún breá sásta seasamh siar – abair, nuair a fhéachaimid ar thoghcháin cosúil le mar a tharla sa Spáinn nuair a bhí muintir na Catalóine ag iarraidh vóta daonlathach a chaitheamh – bhí sé breá sásta seasamh siar fad is a bhí na daoine sin a bhí ag iarraidh vótáil, go raibh an cac buailte astu.  Mar sin, táim an-bhuartha mar gheall ar cén tslí a n-oibreoidh sé seo amach ar bhonn comhionannais ar fud na dtíortha ar fad. Tá tú ag caint ar chúrsaí trádála: an mbeidh buntáiste ann do thíortha atá ag seinnt an phoirt chéanna leis an gCoimisiún? Mar sin ní dóigh liom go bhfuil go leor soiléireachta anseo. Feicimid é seo in Éirinn, abair, nuair a fheicimid na vulture funds, nuair a fheicimid an tslí go bhfuil cumhacht mar sin tagtha chun tosaigh sa tír agus go bhfuil gnáthphobal chosmhuintir na tíre i gcruachás mar go bhfuil an chumhacht ag bua amach ag deireadh an lae.  Mar sin, ní dóigh liomsa gurb é seo an tslí cheart chun aghaidh a thabhairt air seo. Tá an Chúirt Bhreithiúnais againn cheana féin san Eoraip agus nílidsan chomh tiomanta i dtaobh cúrsaí polaitíochta is atá an Coimisiún. Mar sin, bheinn ag cur ceist ar an gCoimisiún féachaint le hathbhreithniú a dhéanamh air seo ar fad agus an chumhacht a bhaint díobh.

name: Jonathan Arnott
text: on behalf of the EFDD Group. – Mr President, in this debate the big question is: what are the circumstances in which this will be used? If you’re talking about fraud, if you’re talking about abuse of funds and taxpayers’ money being used badly, then that is one thing, and you’d find no one who more strongly opposes money being used fraudulently. However, if we’re talking about situations where the European Union considers that a Member State has acted in a way that it doesn’t like and takes what become, in effect, politicised decisions against a Member State, then that is very much another. It seems to me there that Mr Czarnecki very much has a point. One thing that concerns me about this is the procedure of the Commission acting and then effectively the Council having a month to react to that by qualified majority voting (QMV), otherwise the funds will be suspended. It just seems to me that not so much the burden of proof, but that the direction of it is the wrong way round. You should produce the evidence to prove that something is wrong rather than expecting it to have to be overturned. I fear, Mr President, that this leads in practice to a situation where, in effect, you have the unelected Commission sitting in judgment on the elected governments. I fear that this is a proposal where the decisions to sanction or not to sanction could be based on a whim or on whether a country is popular or unpopular with the European Union itself. But you wouldn’t have the same procedure being used against Poland or Hungary or Spain, so you end up with a situation where, whatever happens, it’s perceived to be politicised. Mr President, if the European Union really wants to prove a commitment to the rule of law, then surely to goodness it would need to emulate the best practices of those who do follow the rule of law, and that seems to me fundamentally lacking in this proposal.

name: Stanisław Żółtek
text: On behalf of the ENF Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by This European Commission proposal is the final step towards taking over the entire power of the Countries of the Union. From today, Commission officials will be able to receive any funding from any country if the country proves any disobedience. It is sufficient for Commission officials to recognise that we love homosexuals, immigrants too little, women's equality, or that our court has delivered a judgment which is not in accordance with the Commission's opinion. But countries still have to pay their contribution to the Union, some of the taxes and the carbon tax, which is expected to increase in the coming years so that it will destroy the energy and energy Polish. From today, EU countries become provinces following the instructions of the European Commission. That is why we founded the Polexit party in Poland in order to get out of this structure that is hostile to us from today. We want the European Union all the time, but that is what Schuman, a community of nations, where there is freedom of movement for people, the movement of goods, services, ideas and just that. However, if the Union turns into an occupier and our country turns into an exploited colony, then we must part. I appeal to the citizens of all the countries of the European Union: register the same parties and joint forces in your countries, or let us restore the Union as it was supposed to be, or let us break it down by leaving it and creating a real Union from scratch.

name: Sophie Montel (NI).
text: Mr President, Article 3 of the Declaration of Human and Citizen Rights of 1789 is very clear: "The principle of all sovereignty lies essentially in the nation. No body, no individual can exercise authority that does not expressly emanate from it." The European Commission is not a body whose authority emanates from any nation. By giving Commissioners the power to sanction Member States who do not respect the so-called values of the European Union, your text in reality violates this fundamental right of peoples to decide sovereignly the policy they wish to see applied at home.  According to the Orbon case law, a country could be deprived of European funds, to which it contributes, for reasons as frivolous as the closure of a university financed by foreign funds or the refusal to open its borders to all the misery of the world. The doctrine of limited sovereignty devised by Soviet leader Brezhnev is all too well remembered. As the European Union recycles this concept today under the guise of democracy and the rule of law, let me hope that it will know the same fate as this USSR, which it seems to want to emulate, so that popular sovereignty lives and democracy lives.

name: Marian-Jean Marinescu (PPE).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I believe that we need this regulation. The European budget must be spent efficiently, following the rules in all respects. If a Member State does not respect one of the fundamental values of the Union, the rule of law, it must be possible to intervene to protect European money. The rapporteurs' proposals remove some of the uncertainties of the Commission's text, but there are still provisions that I believe need to be improved. It is not clearly and in detail identified how the shortcomings of the rule of law affect the protection of the Union's financial interests. It is not clear that the penalties measures are proportionate to the damage to the European budget from the shortcomings of the rule of law are clearly established. There is insufficient guarantees that project beneficiaries will receive their money in the event of a suspension of payments for that State. The procedure for triggering the conditioning mechanism overlaps with the procedure laid down in Article 7 of the Treaty of the Union. I hope that the negotiations with the Council will succeed in removing all the uncertainties in order to draw up a regulation applicable for the benefit of citizens.

name: Isabelle Thomas (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, democracy is too precious, too fragile and too serious to leave it in the hands of governments alone. There is no democracy without the rule of law, as enshrined in the preamble to the European Charter of Fundamental Rights. I quote: the Union 'is based on the principle of democracy and the principle of the rule of law'. It therefore has a duty to guarantee them. However, in recent years, what was thought to be an unacceptable and dangerous drift from another time has emerged. Against freedom of the press, against the independence of the judiciary, against human rights. Unfortunately, they are constantly multiplying in the four corners of Europe. I would add that no Member State is immune. It was therefore urgent for the Union to have an effective tool to put an end to these shortcomings and to crack down on the guilty governments. I would like to thank the Commission for this initiative, but above all my colleagues Mrs Gardiazabal and Mr Sarvamaa, who have done a remarkable job in chiseling this budgetary sanctions mechanism, based on the values of the Union arising from Article 2 and responding to a flaw in our legal system, as Commissioner Oettinger said. However, by obligation to find a legal basis in the current state of the treaties, this mechanism had to be attached to the European Union budget, which makes us particularly vigilant about its application, for two reasons. First of all, we will be vigilant about its implementation to ensure that it effectively punishes governments, not citizens who benefit from European funds, because it would be completely absurd for students, research laboratories, universities, farmers or regions to be victims of the faults committed by their governments. That would be a double punishment. We will also be vigilant to prevent this instrument of defending the rule of law from becoming a tool for budgetary management or, I should say, for managing budget shortages, given the poverty of our budget. I hope that the Commission will not be tempted.

name: Zbigniew Kuźmiuk (ECR).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you for your comments. Speaking in this debate, I would like to point out that, although the rapporteurs are trying hard to propose clear criteria for establishing generalised deficiencies in the rule of law in the Member States, unfortunately the margin of discretion is huge, which risks penalizing disliked governments by Brussels. This serious doubt is also confirmed by the ECA opinion of August 2018, which concluded that the Regulation leaves the Commission a very wide margin of discretion in this procedure.  On this occasion, it should be recalled that the current rules allow for the blocking of funds from the Union budget for non-compliance with the discipline of public finances, and although, for example, France has not complied with the 3 % of GDP criterion for several consecutive years, no restrictions from the Commission of that country have been affected. When asked about the Commission's puzzling meekness, President Juncker said with disarming sincerity: "because it's France...". In this context, it would be irresponsible to entrust the Commission with another instrument for penaling Member States on the basis of criteria of a largely discretionary nature, which is why the Polish delegation in the ECR Group will vote against this report.

name: Nedzhmi Ali (ALDE).
text: – Mr President, in order to protect the Union’s budget and financial interests for the next Multiannual Financial Framework (MFF), we need a new regulation that is not a sanctioning mechanism, but rather a tool to ensure sound financial management. The regulation includes under the term rule of law all the Union’s values enshrined in Article 2 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union and the Copenhagen Criteria for Union membership, including fundamental rights.  A generalised deficiency as regards the rule of law may affect the principles of sound financial management or the protection of the financial interests of the Union. The Commission should establish an advisory panel of independent experts, which would undertake an independent annual assessment of the rule of law situation in all Member States. The Commission, when making its decisions, should take into account the relevant panel’s opinion. In order to strengthen the protection of final recipients or beneficiaries, the regulation proposes additional measures. The Commission shall also ensure that any amount due by government entities or Member States is paid to the beneficiaries.  A positive characteristic of the regulation is that the Parliament is put on an equal footing with the Council in the process of adopting or lifting their respective measures. The Commission submits a proposal to Parliament and the Council to transfer to a budgetary reserve the respective amounts, which would enter into force only if both institutions do not reject it.

name: Miguel Viegas (GUE/NGL).
text: – Mr President, what is intended with this proposal is to make the allocation of funds conditional on member states on the basis of the existence of a rule of law. But the question is: what rule of law are we talking about and who will measure the existence of this rule of law?  Are we going to have the European Union control the institutional functioning of the Member States? This European Union which refused the result of the referendums in Ireland, the Netherlands and France in relation to the European Constitution? This European Union which does not accept the outcome of the referendum in the United Kingdom, where the people spoke freely and democratically for the exit from the European Union? This European Union, which promotes the recapitalisation of the financial system with public funds and then presents the bill to peoples with austerity policies? This European Union, which lets thousands of refugees die in the Mediterranean and criminalises humanitarian associations that want to promote their rescue? This list, which is not exhaustive, expresses well the lack of legitimacy of the European Union to assess the rule of law. The sovereignty of the peoples lies in the ability to be able to decide freely on their future and choose their model of development, even if this model is not that prescribed by the European Union. In a forsawill, we strongly reject this instrument.

name: André Elissen (ENF).
text: Mr President, today we are talking about protecting the Union's budget in the event of fundamental shortcomings in the rule of law in the Member States. As this title shows, a way of punishing countries such as Hungary and Poland has been sought for not slavishly submitting to the EU's power-hungry. The arrogant EU elite demands that its supposedly universal values be adopted by all Member States.  Among other things, we want to make new national tax measures impossible if they could be harmful to the EU. Countries must be obliged to show solidarity, including in the area of taxation. When imposing sanctions, the intention is to set up a panel of experts and let the Commission decide independently. This further erodes the sovereignty of countries. Everything shows that the measures are directly directed against Poland and Hungary. These proud countries are not allowed to dominate again after decades of communist dictatorship. We will vote against it.

name: Claudia Schmidt (PPE).
text: Mr President, representatives of the Commission, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I am a little surprised at the direction in which the discussion is taking place here. One thing is a clear fact: EU funding is not a gift, but an investment. If, in some member states, the fight against fraud in EU funds does not work, then something must be done about it.  For example, 80% of the EU budget – eur 125.6 billion in 2017 – is spent by the countries. That is why they must also ensure that action is taken when there is fraud. Countries such as Poland, for example, received EUR 10.6 billion in 2016, Romania EUR 7.3 billion, Slovakia EUR 2 billion, Hungary EUR 4.5 billion or the Czech Republic EUR 4.6 billion. These countries have a massive catching up to do here. With this proposal, the EU – the Commission – will finally have the right to freeze, reduce or stop funds until the problems in the Member State concerned are resolved.  What is also important is that OLAF's perpetual secrecy will finally be stopped. The subsidies are conditional. Once again, EU funding is not a gift, it is investment. If the behaviour of the recipients does not change, the EU must draw conclusions. After all, anyone who spends European taxpayers' money must also comply with European rules.

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge (S&D).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, how can we ask european citizens to respect the principles and values enshrined in the Treaty on European Union, if the Member States themselves are the first not to fulfil their obligations?  It is also thanks to the example of a shared culture of the rule of law on the part of the institutions that citizens' confidence in the Union can be strengthened and the effective implementation of its policies must be ensured. That is why those generalised shortcomings concerning the rule of law in the Member States that affect the sound financial management of the Union must be strongly combated, in order to guarantee not only the financial interest of the Union, including the effective collection of revenue, but also public confidence in the Union and its institutions.  Finally, I do not understand the reasons behind the amendments to the Commission's proposal. Instead, we must join forces to ensure full respect for and promotion of rights and values, as an essential prerequisite for the legitimacy of the European project, in order to relaunch a Europe that protects its citizens.

name: Ruža Tomašić (ECR).
text: – Dear Chairman, the Union is held together by common interests and fundamental values. And while no one needs specifically explaining that he is doing things in his own interest, the fact is that core values are often left behind in pursuing that interest. And interest must not be superior to values, but aligned with them. It is therefore logical that members who breach contracts by failing to comply with fundamental values should not exercise their interests by using common financial resources. But the theory and practice diverge here. We have witnessed so far very far-stretched interpretations of fundamental values and attempts to discipline members who have a slightly different vision of the Union than those currently leading the way. It's a trip to single-mindedness. What I've seen so far has been enough for me to understand what these mechanisms are for, and that's why I'm not going to support this in a vote.

name: Steeve Briois (ENF).
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, frightened that a majority of Eurosceptic Members will be sitting here next May, the European Commission is trying by all means to strengthen its repressive power.  The last fad in mind is a regulation that proposes to suspend the allocation of EU funds to Member States accused of violating the rule of law. In practical terms, and with your approval, the Commission will now be able to cut off the supplies of any country that does not comply with its whims. The mere refusal to take in migrants or to implement the budgetary purge imposed by the Commission will therefore lead to a suspension of EUROPEAN funds.  This permanent blackmail of European funds is unacceptable because, on the one hand, these funds come precisely from the national contributions of the Member States and, on the other hand, because these Italian, Polish or Hungarian governments, which are so displeasing to the Commission, have been elected by the people. That is why we reject any form of conditionality in the allocation of European funds.

name: Tamás Deutsch (PPE).
text: - Mr President, I would like to thank the European I am amazed to hear the institutional fetishism that is the main objective of the existence of the European Union and the Member States in order to make the rule of law work. Dear Colleagues,  The European Union and, of course, the Member States, are focused on guaranteeing the freedom of European citizens and doing everything possible to improve the well-being of European citizens. This is supported by the guarantee of citizens' freedom and the enhancement of citizens' well-being, which is guaranteed by the intertremity of the institutions, laws and institutions of the rule of law. Of course, there may be phenomena in the functioning of the European Union that threaten the rule of law, but whatever threatens the rule of law, the European Union cannot take a decision when it wants to counter the supposed threats to the rule of law by means that threaten the rule of law.  However, the Commission's proposal is weak, it has deteriorated even further in parliamentary preparation, lacking normativity, the most important idea on which the rule of law is based. It is not possible to clearly explain what violations of the rules are the subject of proceedings which may result in extremely important financial penalties. This proposal is a dismantling or jeopardising of the rule of law, and it cannot be supported.

name: Arndt Kohn (S&D).
text: Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has Why are we once again talking about the rule of law today? Because this is an issue that moves the people of Europe. I am often asked by citizens from my region: why is the EU doing nothing about this? Why are there governments that like to receive funding but, on the other hand, do not abide by the rules and disregard democratic values?  However, a functioning rule of law is essential to ensure the proper use of EU funds. If it does not work, the risk of abuse and fraud increases. It is therefore important that we launch this instrument today. But it is not the recipients, not students or farmers, who should be hit here and suffer from the misconduct of their governments, but the national governments themselves. We Social Democrats are also calling for sanctions for countries that take advantage of unfair tax competition or tax fraud schemes, because billions of euros of these taxes are missing in other countries, hospitals and schools. If we want to be a European family, it can only work if we protect our democratic values and work together, not against each other.

name: Josef Weidenholzer (S&D).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The common budget is the backbone of the Union and it is based on the principle of solidarity. In other words, high-performing Member States are prepared to assume a special responsibility, and the resources available are, as we know, scarce. It is therefore obvious that the use of the funds must be subject to specific criteria. Those who do not comply with common rules cannot at the same time collect billions of dollars in subsidies and render the principle of solidarity absurd. The rule of law is the foundation of the EU and all Member States are obliged to respect principles of legality and to guarantee legal certainty through scrutiny by independent and impartial courts. If a Member State systematically violates these principles, we must be able to respond to them. We therefore support this new mechanism and thank the Commission for this initiative. However, it is also particularly important for us to involve the European Parliament more, because the approval of the budget is one of Parliament's most important prerogatives.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I see that some of the pre-edients are worried about the misuse of this regulation against democracy. Yes, just as the prime ministers of our states abuse their position, their power, then there is undoubtedly a risk at European level. But I believe that the principles of the European Union must be respected and protected, both by the Member States and at European Union level, and if there is a breach of cases in this case, there must be instruments to enforce them. I myself have not supported the activation of Article 7 several times because, in my opinion, this is a very strong, shall we say extreme, political signal that largely stigmatises the government, and by far the country. It turns out that this instrument is not sufficient to protect, for example, the European Union budget, the protection of the rule of law. I think we must try to set up a new safeguard mechanism, it is better than looking helplessly at the theft of the European budget.

name: Maria Gabriela Zoană (S&D).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, I have read this report very carefully, which reminds me of George Orwell's book. The European Union becomes, every day, an Orwellian farm, in which some states are more equal than others. The report talks several times about the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism but, as far as I know, this mechanism has only two Countries in the European Union. I propose to you, Commissioner, Mr President, if you want us to vote on this report tomorrow, before this vote we vote for all the states in the European Union to have the Cooperation and Verification Mechanism. Implement it at home, because otherwise this report will not create equality between states. The principle of protecting the European Union may be a good one, but the procedure worries me very much. Who will, in this context, be the watchdog of democracy in the European Union? By hearing this report, I had the feeling that it conveys to us the fear that the European Commission will be left empty-pocketed – and I give you a simple example: Amendment 12, which says that the Commission, which is based on information received from all relevant sources, is being identified with empty pockets. What do relevant sources mean? I am a lawyer and I know that in such a situation, there must be a very clear wording. Relevant sources mean media, mean organisations, mean colleagues from other benevolent countries? Mr President, we must look very carefully at such regulation.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, Article 7 defines the protection of the rule of law and, of course, the values of the European Union, but Article 7 works within the framework of the same Treaty, that is to say, the application of Article 7 must respect the competences of the European Union. This article will therefore operate in the field where there is competence of the European Union and not outside. Of course, we all want fraud to be hit, and that's a given. However, Article 7 and the mechanism proposed as a political tool for intervention in the internal affairs of the Member States must not be used and a neo-colonial policy must be expressed in substance. There's bilingualism. When the troika and the memorial governments in Greece were violating the rule of law - and we have repeatedly denounced this here in the European Parliament - we have not seen any action taken. On the contrary, we were told that the implementation of the Memorandums, even though it violated fundamental rights, was lawful. We must therefore be careful how this mechanism is implemented.

name: Ivana Maletić (PPE).
text: - Dear Chairman, the protection of human rights, human dignity, EU values, the rule of law, democracy - has no alternative and I cannot agree that this is a matter of protecting the EU's financial interests and budget. This is a matter of protecting the EU as a whole, far beyond the financial interests themselves.  The measures we are taking cannot be linked to the resources used by each Member State, as this would mean that for the same disregard for human rights or the failure of the judiciary, for example, we penalise more in countries that use more EU funds and less in countries that use less EU budget funds.  While fellow rapporteurs have significantly improved the Commission's proposal, which has been quite unenforceable in practice, this regulation still needs to be improved and a single application should be ensured in all Member States regardless of money.

name: Răzvan Popa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the budget of the European Union is extremely important for every citizen of the Member States. This budget supports the economic and social development of the countries that are part of the European Union. I come from a country where European funds have contributed to economic growth, job growth, modernisation of the health system or infrastructure. We all want European money to be best used in the interests of the people, and that is why we have institutions to oversee the use of European money. The European budget shall be protected by the European institutions and the institutions of each Member State. But the introduction of political sanctioning criteria for the granting of European funds is a risky step. It is important to have clearly defined criteria in order to avoid a situation where a Member State can become the victim of political games. The suspension of European funds should be well-founded on objective, fair, fair, fair rules beyond doubt or challenge. However, this is not clear as a result of this proposed Mechanism.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to begin by thanking the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has said. We have received the speeches very carefully, will evaluate them and are interested in the best possible development of our proposal in the further procedure. It is the basis and not the result of your legislation. However, I do see from the majority of the speeches a willingness to follow the Commission's proposal in principle and to make some changes. It must be clear that, when the rule of law is required of Member States, a procedure at European level must be entirely constitutional and must not open the door in any form of arbitrariness or even partisanship. That is why, in the Commission's proposal, we have defined how we must work, how we must maintain objectivity, how we must take into account all the information from third parties and courts, how we need to justify our proposal, how to consult the Member State concerned, how to give it the opportunity to give its opinion. And the Commission is not solely responsible. The Council and Parliament have an important role to play. The Council may also reject the Commission's proposals. A crucial point: if a decision is taken, it is judicial, so the Member State that is affected, should feel unfairly treated, can go to court. That is why, if you follow the proposal, we will certainly receive some groundbreaking court rulings in the coming years, which will then be groundbreaking for future practice. Thank you for your cooperation and I am interested in an intensive timely consultation with the Council and Parliament.

name: Eider Gardiazabal Rubial
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I am done fast because we have been going on a very long day and there are still interventions and debates in this House. But I agree perfectly with what the Commissioner was saying now. I have heard, I have listened carefully to this debate, I fully understand the legitimate doubts raised here by certain speakers and I am sure that both Mr Sarvamaa and myself are committed to continuing to work on this report and to trying to reach an agreement with the Romanian Presidency at this time. So I simply want to take advantage of the little time I have left to thank Mr Sarvamaa very sincerely for his cooperation. We start from a little distant positions , let's put it this way – but I believe that we have managed to produce a good report thanks to their work, but also thanks to the work of the negotiators of the rest of the political groups, both the Committee on Budgetary Control and the Committee on Budgets. And I would also like to thank the work of the European Commission, Commissioner Oettinger and all its services, because they have been very useful in doing our job. So I just hope that what we have negotiated over the last few months will be ratified tomorrow in the vote in this House and that we can start negotiating with the Romanian Presidency now and still improve the text further.

name: Petri Sarvamaa
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, thank you to everyone for their interventions. I listened to them extremely carefully, of course. Let me go in a little bit of an unusual order and do the thanking first and then just say a few final words. So, those that I still have not thanked I thank now, and that is the Commission, of course, the Commissioner and others working on this, all the shadow rapporteurs and especially the secretariats and the very wise people there in both the Committee on Budgets and the Committee on Budgetary Control. Then, not the last thing but the thing before the last is this: I especially want to thank those who were constructive, maybe not straight in endorsing either the proposal or the final report, but constructive and who had some reservations and some ideas for the upcoming trilogues. But the last thing I want to say is that I’m extremely depressed. The reason for that is that this is how politics works; we heard a bundle of people tonight who were very dishonest. They were mostly speaking to their national audiences. I have to say this. And for the last two and a half years we’ve been witnessing the tragic farce of the most severe consequences that politics can have for one great nation and for the whole European Union. And you know what I’m talking about. And this, unfortunately, is what politics is sometimes. So let’s genuinely try to work for a better Europe.
