name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on Sven Ziegold's report, on behalf of the Committee on Economic and Monetary Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Fiscalis programme for cooperation in the field of taxation (COM(2018)0443 - C8-0260/2018 - 2018/0233(COD)) (A8-0421/2018)

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: deputising for the rapporteur. – Mr President, the fight against tax avoidance, tax evasion and financial crime cannot be tackled effectively by each country alone because of its cross-border nature, so increased collaboration and a true European response to tax dodging are necessary. Unfortunately, in the Council, EU governments have been blocking key legislative files that would help ensure fair competition in the common market and make big corporations and rich individuals pay their fair share, from tax transparency in country-by-country reporting, to a common tax base to the digital tax.  Yesterday, the Commission presented the proposal to shift from unanimity to qualified majority and to give this Parliament co—decision powers on tax matters. We think that the Commission has chosen the wrong instrument to achieve their objective. It is doomed to failure to take recourse to the ineffective passerelle clause, which requires unanimity itself, instead of using Article 116. However, it is not the Commission, but the Member States, that are responsible for stalling crucial legislative tax files.  Against this backdrop, I present on behalf of Sven Giegold the report on the Fiscalis programme, which witnesses that Member States are able to overcome their national egoism to the benefit of their citizens. The Fiscalis programme is a success story showing the positive results stemming from cooperation between national tax authorities. Since its inception, the Fiscalis programme has facilitated and enhanced cooperation between tax authorities within the Union. It has helped national tax authorities to accomplish their core task of collecting taxes. So we are happy that the Rapporteur’s draft report received broad support from different political groups. We are glad that the majority in this House acknowledges the need for intensified tax cooperation, an increase of the budget and enhanced transparency of the programme itself.  There is only one amendment tabled for tomorrow’s plenary vote, and we want to use this opportunity to ask for your support for that amendment. The instrument of cross-border joint audits is the latest frontier for enhanced administrative cooperation between tax authorities across the different Member States. Joint audits are particularly useful in the case of transfer price agreements, residency or permanent establishment issues and aggressive tax planning schemes. We therefore urge you to vote in favour of the joint S&D-Greens amendment, which makes joint audits eligible for funding under the Fiscalis programme. We are convinced that this will foster fair taxation to the benefit of all citizens.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. Tonight I am representing my colleague Mr Moscovici, who is in Athens for talks with the Greek Government. I would ask you, Mrs Scott Cato, to greet Mr Giegold and to thank him for his excellent work on this dossier. Our national tax authorities and the European Union continue to suffer from insufficient capacity and inextensive cooperation. Cooperation between Member States can still be developed. This applies within the European Union and also applies to the relations of our tax authorities with third countries. As a result, the efficiency and effectiveness of their work suffers. That is why answers to the questions of how to further curb tax fraud, tax evasion, tax avoidance and avoidance and how to provide answers to digitalisation and new business models remain important. At the same time, we must free our citizens and businesses from unnecessary administrative burdens. These factors constantly bring new tasks for the functioning and performance of national tax authorities. They should be able to concentrate on their core task, tax collection. This feeds the national budget, and indirectly the European budget. That is why we propose to continue the tried and tested Fiscalis programme with the aim of supporting tax policy and tax authorities through operational cooperation measures. A significant part of the support will be the establishment and operation of IT systems and the exchange of tax-related information between Member States and with citizens and our businesses. By creating a framework for measures that support the internal market, promote the competitiveness of the Union and serve to protect the financial and economic interests of the Union and its Member States, the new Fiscalis programme, which is also included in the Commission's proposal in the post-2020 budget framework, aims to help prevent and combat tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance, thereby strengthening tax justice. In addition, the programme has an important further objective: to facilitate and modernise the work of tax administrations. To this end, Fiscalis provides practical tools that could lead to better service and reduced administrative burdens for taxpayers, citizens and businesses. How does Fiscalis intend to achieve this? I would like to mention four main programme components. Firstly, further strengthening cooperation between tax administrations through optimal exchange of experience and best practices. Secondly, a focus on innovation and answers to new tasks, as well as the use of opportunities that may arise from new technologies such as blockchain. Thirdly, optimum coordination and an overview of all IT developments, systems, networks and platforms financed under the programme and, last but not least, investment in the tax authorities themselves, in staff: training, seminars, conferences, training materials. It is precisely these measures that are of great importance and are intended to provide staff in tax administrations with good information and preparation for the EU's tax policies. Fiscalis is not new. The existing programme has already made important improvements in the past and present, providing added value that is also highly valued and recognised by the tax authorities and finance ministers in the Member States. Joint audits, project groups, expert teams – all of this is part of this and is financed from it. We are proposing a total of EUR 270 million for the seven years of the next budgetary framework in order to use this money and this instrument to further strengthen the fight against tax fraud and evasion. All in all, we believe that a modernised Fiscalis programme serves the European interests and those of the Member States. We are pleased that, both in Parliament and in the Council, Mr Giegold has made progress on this dossier in the ECON Committee through thorough work. Thank you for this progress! We are counting on a constructive discussion. And when the honourable Member asked at the beginning why we do not use Article 116 – in what the Commission decided yesterday as a proposal for the majority principle in tax law, on some tax law issues – the answer is: we are guided by the objective or by the consideration: what way, what action could be capable of winning a majority in the Council? And after a thorough Mr Moscovici's view is that Article 116 would be less promising in the Council than the Commission's action. I am sure that my colleagues, Mr Dombrovskis and Mr Moscovici, will be ready to hold direct talks with Mr Giegold and other Members of this House in the coming weeks on how to proceed.

name: Manuel dos Santos
text: draftsman of the opinion of the Committee on Budgets. – Mr President, allow me, first of all, to address the rapporteur's representative, who has done an excellent job. I offer my compliments here and this work has also been valued by the Committee on Budgets with the significant vote on the report on it. Then also to address the Commissioner to thank him for his systematically cooperation with the Committee on Budgets, for the positive cooperation that many praise and which we take great advantage of. I am convinced that, also in relation to this programme, the Commissioner will not fail to develop it, as is the wish and interest of the European Union in the context of the ongoing dialogue he has with Parliament and the Committee on Budgets.  The Fiscalis Program, as you know, aims at cooperation between tax and tax administrations through collaboration and exchange of information. This cooperation can be central to greater effectiveness in the fight against tax evasion and avoidance and money laundering.  Together with my Group, I have tabled some proposals to amend the text from which I would point out these three ideas: the process of selecting external experts should take gender equality into account, in line with the UN's sustainable development objectives, in particular paragraph 5; the Fiscalis Programme should try to exploit synergies with other Union measures in fields related to the Customs Programme, the European Anti-Fraud Programme, the Single Market Programme and structural reform support programmes for better cost-effectiveness; and the increase in total funding of the programme should reach around EUR 300 million in 2018 prices, as a decision of the Committee on Budgets. I think the Commission can make an effort to do so.  The text adopted in committee, which is expected to receive massive support in plenary, then allows us to create a programme that will support the tax authorities of the Member States in pursuing the best tax policies, cooperation between them and the development of European human resources capacities and electronic systems. In this regard, it is important to recall that the European Commission is committed to finding tax commitments between Member States that can progressively translate into the elimination of the current model of unanimity. This rule of unanimity in fiscal policy has been justified historically, but it is now outdated and, when a good consensus can be found on this issue, a firm step will be taken in the development of economic and monetary union. Parliament should support the Commission in this objective.

name: Theodor Dumitru Stolojan
text: on behalf of the PPE Group. – Mr President, I will vote tomorrow for this programme, Fiscalis, because it is the only European programme directly addressed to the tax authorities of the Member States. It is the programme that builds, helps, finances the infrastructure needed for the mutual exchange of information between tax authorities on revenue, taxes. It is also the programme that manages to bring experts from tax authorities and other experts face-to-face in order to promote best methods and practices. I particularly appreciate that this Fiscal programme is also open to the participation of experts from candidate countries, as well as those from other countries. It is absolutely necessary, if we really want to fight against tax evasion, tax evasion, to also ensure that experts from these countries have access to that programme. In the current mandate, the Fiscalis program is running successfully. There were no particular problems. I'll support him.

name: Hugues Bayet
text: On behalf of the Group of S-D. - Mr President, the Fiscalis programme that we will be presenting in the vote will enable the period 2021-2027 to strengthen and facilitate cooperation between Member States in the area of taxation. After the various tax scandals that we have seen in recent years, it is obviously essential to be able to continue to put in place a programme that facilitates the exchange of information between Member States in order to better combat tax evasion.  The budget for this programme will be mainly devoted to improving IT infrastructure, but also to tax cooperation requiring a communications network allowing national administrations to exchange information securely.  As the Commissioner said, as a socialist group, we are proud to have been able to contribute to the establishment of training within administrations in this report, but also the establishment of greater cooperation between tax administrations in the fight against money laundering. Because the fight against tax evasion obviously requires a successful administration that has all the tools in hand in order to put in place real tax justice. Finally, Molly Scott Cato, thank you for conveying to our colleague Sven Giegold our thanks for the excellent work on this issue.

name: Ralph Packet
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, tax is about events, training courses, exchanges for more than thirty European tax authorities. Good cooperation between the European tax authorities is of great importance for the European Union as a whole and for Flanders. You could call Fiscalis a kind of Erasmus for tax inspectors. The current programme runs until 2020 and this proposal runs for a further period until 2027. We support that. But the Commission's proposal increased the budget for the next period by 22%, if we take into account Brexit. Parliament is now adding an additional 11%.  Moreover, the priorities in this text are unilaterally inspired by the left and we do not support this one-sided approach. The enormous focus on third world countries, as in this proposal, is unachievable, and we would have liked to have seen more attention to administrative simplification, rather than all kinds of new reporting and supervision. We hope that this will be improved in the negotiations with the Council.

name: Dariusz Rosati (PPE).
text: – Mr President, one of this Parliament’s main priorities in this mandate, which is now coming to an end, has been the fight against tax fraud, tax evasion and tax avoidance. But what we have noticed during the work of numerous committees – special committees and inquiry committees – is that the cooperation between the national tax services, national tax authorities has not been up to the standard and up to the requirements to make this fight really effective. This is why I welcome this fiscal programme and fiscal report and I would like to congratulate Sven Giegold, who is unfortunately not with us, but also Ms Scott Cato for this important contribution, and I want to say that, without having a technical programme that supports national authorities in exchanging information, sharing good practices and implementing efficient IT technologies, the fight against tax abuses would not be successful. That’s why I very much support this programme and I am also in favour of increasing the financing of this programme to EUR 300 million. I think this is a bare minimum in order to make this programme effective. Remember what kind of benefits we can still get out of this. Billions of euro are being lost due to tax evasion. So this is really not a big price to get this money back to Member States’ coffers. This is certainly a programme that deserves support and I will be in favour in our political group of supporting this programme.

name: Tom Vandenkendelaere (PPE).
text: Mr President, every year we see billions of euros in tax revenues go up in smoke as a case of tax fraud. Profits made in one European Member State are funnelled through not even so difficult constructions to tax havens. Albeit through VAT carousels or other constructions, fraudsters make convenient use of these cross-border systems precisely because they escape the eye of the various national administrations. And the problem is becoming more and more urgent.  Globalisation and digitisation are blurring our borders. Companies easily set up branches on the other side of the world and sell their products worldwide, but our tax authorities still operate on an island. The income of a local SME is very easy to tax and control because they remain within our national borders. But checking the tax returns of multinationals and internet companies is a very different pair of sleeves. Cooperation at European level is therefore really crucial. I am convinced that our tax authorities have more than enough information to get the bad apples out. We must therefore take even more out of their isolation from the various administrations and invest in bridges between these national islands.  As far as I am concerned, the smooth and efficient exchange of information and data is the smartest way to tackle cross-border tax fraud. That is what we can achieve with Fiscalis 2020: more investment in tax administrations leads to less fraud and automatically to more income. No government that I do not think understands the absolute logic of this.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, tax evasion, tax avoidance and tax fraud are, of course, on the agenda, resulting in billions of euros in losses from state coffers. Of course, there are the systems we've seen, the carousel, there's fraud. But the European Union was late because it tolerated and did not go ahead with tax fraud, we saw the Falciani list, we did not see any significant results, it tolerated tax rulings with particular tax regulation in Luxembourg and the Netherlands. We must therefore take concrete decisions and change the legislation. Every multinational has to pay the taxes where it makes the profits. The various legal loopholes must be closed, because this is mainly the case with tax avoidance. And, of course, to implement this programme, to exchange good practices on the part of tax authorities, to take measures to hit fraud, but also to change the legislation. Because the legislation allows the various legal windows to exist and thus avoid tax mainly multinationals using triangular relations.

name: Günther Oettinger
text: Mr. The Commission. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent report and for the way in which it has been I would like to say that there is a broad and high degree of agreement here in this House on the work of the rapporteur, Mr Giegold, and also on the Commission's proposal to continue the Fiscalis programme and to continue to apply it optimally in the future, building on the good past. You mentioned the Commission's budget proposal. We propose an amount of EUR 270 million for the next seven years at current prices. We think that is sufficient. More money can always be used wisely. This is primarily about the procurement and maintenance of ICT, hardware and software, information and communication technologies.  But we definitely want to fight for the amount; it should not be subject to a reduction in order to ensure the best possible continuation of cooperation between tax authorities in order to prevent and combat fraud and evasion at European and national level. Thank you very much for your broad support!

name: Molly Scott Cato
text: Rapporteur. – Mr President, I won’t spend much time discussing Article 116. I do understand the problems with using that process, but I have to say that, as a Parliament that has worked very heavily on tax issues, we are disappointed with the slow progress. We do feel that there’s a breakdown in trust between the citizens we represent and the European institutions if we’re not able to make sure that corporations and wealthy people pay their taxes. We really do need better cooperation between Member States to make sure that happens.  But in the case of this debate, I have rarely received so many plaudits and so much appreciation for so little work, so thank you very much for that at least. I will certainly pass on all your appreciation to Sven. I know he’ll want to thank all his colleagues here for the excellent cooperation that there has been at committee level and the very good support right across the Groups in Parliament here.  We’re hoping that we’ll get that same broad support tomorrow in the vote and that we will be able to enter into interinstitutional negotiations next week, and I will certainly pass on your good wishes back to Sven Giegold.

name: Πρόεδρος. –
text: The next item on the agenda is the debate on the Bodil Valero report, on behalf of the Committee on Civil Liberties, Justice and Home Affairs, on the proposal for a Regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing the Rights and Values Programme (COM(2018)0383 - C8-0234/2018 - 2018/0207(COD)) (A8-0468/2018)

name: Bodil Valero
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by thanking all the shadows, the other rapporteurs, all the organisations I have met, political officials, assistants and the secretariat for their good cooperation. It is an important piece of work that we have done together, and I am glad that this has led to a broad consensus in committee. We are living in a tough time in Europe, where respect for our own principles and rules is rocking. We have governments that legislate or otherwise act against freedom of expression, freedom of the press, minority rights. Governments that believe that democracy is only voting at a certain interval. However, a democracy that does not respect fundamental rights or the rule of law cannot be called a full democracy, and a legally secure society is characterised by independent courts and the rulings of the courts are respected. Equality before the law shall be guaranteed; individuals should not be arbitrarily affected. The other day, the popular mayor Paweł Adamowicz from Gdansk, Poland, was murdered. According to the perpetrator, the attack was revenge against the mayor's former party. But the thing is that the mayor had already been threatened, that he had reported the threats, but that the authority has chosen to close the case. The mayor of Gdansk was known for his welcoming attitude towards refugees and for his support for civil society organisations. In just one year, three journalists who have uncovered widespread corruption cases have been murdered in EU countries – Bulgaria, Slovakia, Malta. In Hungary, Prime Minister Orbán has been accused of restricting free speech, of damaging the independence of the judiciary, of corruption, of restricting academic freedom in the country and of eroding the human rights of minorities. Poland has tabled 13 legislative proposals which the Commission believes risk leading to political governance of the judiciary. The draft law gives, among other things, poland's Minister of Justice the power to appoint and dismiss the country's judges without criteria. Unfortunately, the list is long on examples, which is why we need a strong programme of rights and values. In April 2018, Parliament proposed the creation of a european civil society support programme, just as we support MRI organisations outside the EU's borders. And we therefore welcome the Commission's proposal, but we cannot accept that a completely new area, that is, rights and values, should be embedded in existing programmes and also with a lower budget when the situation is that existing programmes are already underfunded. That is why we are calling for a greatly increased budget and for rights and values to be their own programme, to stand on their own two feet. We are directing a greater share of support to civil society and making it easier to apply for smaller grassroots organisations as well. The aim is to protect and promote democracy and the rule of law, equality and equality, rights, non-discrimination and to strengthen gender mainstreaming, gender mainstreaming, to raise citizens' knowledge of the Union, to promote freedom of expression, diversity, civic engagement and to combat violence and violence against women. Problems should be prevented in the first place, and that is precisely what this programme is all about. It is aimed at all Member States, civil society, municipalities, regions, other institutions. However, we need both carrots and whips to address the problems we face, and that is why we are also proposing that there should be a possibility that in certain specific cases the Commission can go in and transfer other EU funds in the country concerned to the programme when proceedings are initiated against the country in question, and that a percentage of aid should be allocated when we see a rapid and serious deterioration in the compliance of a Member State with the country concerned. our common values. Being an EU member obliges. Article 2 of the Treaty states: "The Union shall be based on the values of respect for human dignity, freedom, democracy, equality, the rule of law and respect for human rights, including the rights of persons belonging to minorities. These values shall be common to the Member States in a society characterised by diversity, non-discrimination, tolerance, justice, solidarity and the principle of equality between men and women.' That is the basis of the new programme.

name: Sylvie Guillaume
text: rapporteur for the opinion of the Committee on Culture and Education. Mr President, the European Union is experiencing a sharp rise in intolerance, nationalist and Eurosceptic movements of all stripes, and also unparalleled misinformation. This calls into question the sense of belonging to a common space and democratic principles. In order to support dialogue between Europeans and to strengthen mutual understanding, it is essential to defend this programme and to see it with a budget that is up to the challenges ahead. I would like to thank the rapporteur and the various shadow rapporteurs for their commitment to defending an ambitious 'Citizens, Equality, Rights and Values' programme. It is in this spirit that the Committee on Culture and Education has supported the doubling of the budget dedicated to active citizenship, i.e. EUR 500 million for the period 2021-2027. These funds will be used for local organisations and citizens' groups working for inclusive and participatory citizenship, with the continuation of memory work and the promotion of a sense of belonging to a common Europe. On the eve of major elections for the future of Europe, this increased support is a symbol.  The Council can count on the determination of the European Parliament to defend strengthened resources for projects that come from the ground, led by citizens, networks of cities or twin cities. All these projects help, I believe, to nurture a Europe that is democratic, civic and conducive to cultural diversity.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, at a time when European societies are confronted with extremism, radicalism and divisions, it is more important than ever to promote, strengthen and defend justice, rights and EU values. For this reason, the Commission has proposed a new Justice, Rights and Values Fund, whose overarching aim is to sustain open, democratic and inclusive societies. The Rights and Values programme is part of the new Fund, together with the Justice programme. With the adoption of the report and the mandate for the future negotiations, Parliament shows once again its strong support for the promotion of rights and values and its commitment to advance the negotiations. I welcome this ambition and support it. The new programme will continue funding key activities, such as the promotion of gender equality, anti—discrimination, the rights of the child, fighting violence against women, anti-racism and other values and priorities. It will continue the successful activities of the Europe for Citizens Programme, in particular town twinning, remembrance activities and civil society projects, allowing citizens a direct engagement with Europe. The new programme should also encourage and facilitate active participation in the construction of a more democratic union, as well as awareness of rights and values.  The Commission shares the views expressed by Parliament on the important role of civil society organisations in promoting and defending rights and values, and this role is recognised at the highest possible level in the general objective. Non-governmental organisations will continue to have a key role in the implementation of the future programme. At the same time, the Rights and Values programme shall also continue to fund a broad range of beneficiaries besides the civil society organisations, for instance, equality bodies, expert networks, public administrations, local and regional authorities, museums, academic stakeholders and so on. An equilibrium is needed to respect the variety of the programme and the policies it serves. The Rights and Values programme is also interlinked to the Justice programme and, more generally, to the rule of law mechanism. The Commission has carefully drafted them in such a way as to clearly define their scope, to develop synergies and to avoid duplications. This is a key point of our future discussion.  I do of course agree that there should be more money. There is never enough money. As you know, the negotiations on the budget had to cope with the fact that there is less money for more priorities. This is the reality. But, at the same time, I want to say that the programmes which I have just mentioned and whose main goals I have described can be combined with the money which should be put into the European Social Fund, where there is money, and there will be money, for social integration, very probably also involving the new Horizon programme, where there will be money for research and data collection related to the values and goals which we have in mind in this discussion. So I believe that, even with less money, we can do more work.

name: Michał Boni
text: On behalf of the PPE Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Commissioner, i would like to thank you very much for The Rights and Values programme has managed to raise three times as much money in parliament's proposal: more than €2 billion. The 'EU values' pillar has been distinguished from €850 million for local and regional organisations. Procedures for the availability of funds without excessive bureaucracy have been simplified, with the possibility of supporting the day-to-day activities of the organisation, while ensuring transparency of the accounts. The creation of contact points in countries has been described in such a way that the principle of impartiality will prevail. This means that governments reluctant to organise citizens' organisations will not have an impact on the award of grants that are so directly from the EU budget. A reserve of 5% of the annual plan has been created to further support NGOs where democracy and the rule of law are being violated, so as to have a democratic dialogue with those who see problems differently. A concrete solution has been found to develop European values: democracy as a process of citizens' participation in decision-making, the rule of law as the foundation of the order of the state, non-discrimination as the basis for social order. This is the way to strengthen civil society. A strong independent civil society is the only response to the threat of state appropriation of society, which goes step by step towards authoritarianism

name: Cécile Kashetu Kyenge
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, investing in the rights and values of the European Union, citizens and equality means investing in cohesion and social justice. , violence against women, extremism, for a plural and inclusive Europe.  Never before have we needed to prevent and combat repeated phenomena of hatred and discrimination, increasingly fuelled by a violent political climate, and to protect victims, especially the most vulnerable. We all know that open, democratic and inclusive societies do not finance themselves. That is why we are proposing a significant increase in the programme's budget, so that civil society organisations can support those activities that contribute to the creation of democratic societies based on the rights of all citizens.  Let us invest in the future of young people, let us give them the tools to understand tolerance and diversity, values that are at the heart of the common European project.

name: Marek Jurek
text: On behalf of the ECR Group. – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by European values, Mr Boni said, are socio-cultural (whatever that means), sexual orientations, the fight against xenophobia, homophobia and other forms of intolerance.
