Amendment 20(11) of this proposal says 'I want to track down hatred towards Muslims', but why does it say nothing about hatred of Christianity, contempt for Europe's religious heritage, or the treaty value of the European Union. We have very serious concerns that this programme creates a powerful instrument for the dream of turning the European Union into one powerful controlled democracy. Illiberal democracy, which Viktor Orban spoke of. Very often we hear a quote from him. This is not just a demand, it is a conformation of what we are discussing here at the moment.

name: Danilo Oscar Lancini
text: Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, i.e. the european Union, we must not Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, the Rights and Values programme has important aims and high-profile objectives, such as the promotion of respect for human dignity, equality, the environment and the rule of law.  Although noble in its idea, the drafting has brought with it all those ambiguities that are proper to the Union that we represent here, contradictions that constantly emerge and which in recent months have risen, as never before, to the forefront of international news.  Looking at the technical detail of the proposal, we find bitterly that the civilised mission of this Europe is being auctioned off to the highest bidder and downgraded to a contract with the NGO on duty. We find that the Equality and Rights programme, like so many others, is not so important, otherwise this Union would have had the care to manage it itself.  The NGOs that would be the first recipients of financial support in recent months have shown all their arrogance. How can we not mention the latest case of Open Arms which, in defiance of international law, has encouraged the trafficking of human beings from the coasts of Libya to Spain. These legal entities have their own interests which do not always correspond to those of the Union and supporting them economically entails a number of moral risks that this Parliament can no longer afford.

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by You have included contradictory values in this directive: freedom and equality cannot be reconciled in a single document, because freedom is contrary to equality. Freedom, because of the natural differences between people in talents, in diligence and attitudes, in values, is causing inequality. Equality can only be achieved in a concentration camp, so decide: you want equality or equality. These are two completely different things.  Do you want freedom, freedom of speech? Just yesterday, you voted to extend sanctions for non-rightful statements in this Parliament, so decide again: do you want freedom of speech or just freedom of expression, freedom of one's own beliefs? Do you want democracy? You discard more blue cards. More and more people here want to eliminate the only element of debate that we have here, which is the opportunity to ask questions, and not to accept blue cards from me within the framework of precisely this democracy that you understand.

name: Barbara Kudrycka (PPE).
text: – (2) Mr President, I would like to begin by Until a few years ago, no one would have thought that the fundamental values of the European Union needed to be up for protection and promotion within the Union. Today, however, when in more countries predatory populism destroys the tridivision of power, the independence of the judiciary and freedom of the media, programmes like this are essential. The Commission's proposal was not ambitious enough. It did not take into account the new challenges to European values. It is therefore right that the LIBE Committee has decided to thoroughly revise the programme. Even a threefold increase in the budget is not an excessive price for such a purpose. The proposed Rights and Values Programme will be a good complement to the instruments supporting the rule of law. Unlike Article 7, which calls for a regression of democracy, the Rights and Values programme works pre-emptively and preventively so that democracy does not fall into that decline. The Rights and Values programme does not act on an ad hoc basis. It is a systemic solution that strengthens society, which is, after all, the surest foundation of democracy. For example, if it were not for the determination of civil society in Poland, the process of retreat from democracy would be much more advanced. Ultimately, the programme should lead to a better understanding of the European Community and our common values.

name: Juan Fernando López Aguilar (S&D).
text: – Mr. President. Commissioner Jourová, they say that the European Union is questioned like never before in its founding values, but it is, above all, questioned by the manifestly anti-European attitudes and behaviours that are spreading throughout Europe. That is why it is so important that this European Parliament takes a position in favour of adopting an instrument that promotes European values through non-governmental organisations, the third sector and civil society which are ready to commit to the ideal and construction of Europe, and that this has budgetary appropriation in the multiannual financial framework 2021-2027. In this way we are sending a very clear message of the European Union's defence commitment, which is consistent with what we heard this morning from the President of the Government of Spain: the need for full-body Europeans to protect Europe. The motto "Europe that protects" was not coined in any way to shield Europe from imaginary or scapegoat enemies such as immigrants or refugees, but, on the contrary, for Europe to be defended and protected from real enemies, which are xenophobia, hate speech spread with lies and insolidarity. And hate speech spread with lies must be answered bluntly by this European instrument, which has the full support of the European Parliament. Of course, he has it from the Socialists and Democrats in the European Parliament.

name: Udo Voigt (NI).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the Bringing together a strong programme of rights and values here in the European Union means, of course, that it will also be put into practice in all the Member States. I would like to cite a recent example here: Horst Mahler, 83 years old, received twelve years in prison on the basis of an expression of opinion, which he expressed, which he has been serving since 2009. In 2015, he had his left foot amputated while in custody. Now in November, the other leg was amputated to the thigh. Until 10 January this year, he spent his rehabilitation in a clinic in Brandenburg. There he suffered from sleep deprivation because the night-time monitor left the door to the patient's room open, which deprived him of sleep.  His complaint led – and this is the current thing that shocks me – that the head of the prison then allowed the post to close the door, but ordered the patient, who was mutilated on both legs, to be handcuffed to the bed when the guard had to leave his post, for example, because of a toilet visit, food intake. I do not mean 'rights and values'.  (The speaker agreed to answer a question on the 'blue card' procedure under Rule 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure)

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI)
text: blue card question. Mr President, since, first of all, I thank you for accepting my question, I wanted to ask you the following question: has this unacceptable and inhumane incident, which offends our culture and humanism, been known to the German people? And, if so, how does he react?

name: Udo Voigt (NI)
text: Answer to a question about the "blue card" procedure. You are silent about it. It is not an isolated case in Germany. A 90-year-old woman, Ursula Haverbeck, was also detained for expressing her rights.  In total, more than 1 000 patriots are imprisoned in Germany for freedom of expression. The media doesn't talk about it. We have a similar situation to that in Greece, where even Members of a party are being detained, even though they are represented in the national parliament. I think that we should stop doing things like this throughout Europe.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Mr Voigt, you do not have to remain silent here, and that is why I think the European Parliament is important. We have freedom at European Union level and thanks to this you can call for justice for the people who need it. I still have to react to my colleague Sośnierz in the beginning, because I did not believe my own ears.  Mr Colleague, you have questioned the principle of equality, but I think you have mainly confused it with uniformity, and that is really something else. Equality, above all, is a principle that comes from Christianity, so if you were a Christian, you would know that equality is something that we must strive for both at national level and at European Union level. And, of course, I agree with the proposal for this Rights and Values programme. The 'citizens and equality' to be added to the title is a proposal from our Committee on Culture, and I also agree that this incorporation should be approved in the same way as an increase in the budget. The current Europe for Citizens programme is not well known in some countries and it is a pity. It's underutilized.  I believe that the new programme will in turn be a new and great source of resources for quality projects, especially for the non-profit sector, and also for municipalities, for what we call twinning between municipalities and cities, which is a very good experience with the use of these projects, so I support. (The speaker agreed to answer the question asked by raising the Blue Card (Article 162(8) of the Rules of Procedure).)

name: Dobromir Sośnierz (NI)
text: question asked by picking up a blue card. "I want to make sure we understand each other well. Do you understand the difference between equality and equality? Equality is the same rights, and equality is substantive equality, that is, the same effects. Equality is contrary to equality, because if one earns more and the other earns less, then equality can only be achieved by taking one and giving to the other, and this is already contrary to freedom and to all traditional European values.

name: Michaela Šojdrová (PPE)
text: answer to the question asked by raising the blue card. – I have listened to you very well, colleague, and I believe that equality before the law and equality in terms of equal rights apply to all. And when it comes to equality and equality, I don't see the difference. I believe that we should strive to ensure that everyone has equal rights, equal opportunities.

name: Julie Ward (S&D).
text: – Mr President, the EU Rights and Values programme is necessary today more than ever. The fundamental values that underpin our European democracy must not be taken for granted. I frequently give my support to grassroots civil society projects funded by the EU. These are needed to ensure that principles such as the rule of law, pluralism and tolerance are not just words, but meaningful accessible values that enhance society and citizenship across Europe. Today, sadly, we see the erosion of civil society in Orbán’s Hungary, where the rule of law is attacked and laws are passed criminalising grassroot support for refugees. Legislation against the judiciary in Poland is equally troubling. Democratic values must be valued and supported, first and foremost, by citizens. I welcome amendments to the report fostering democratic participation as part of European citizenship. Grassroots projects encouraging participation in meaningful European democracy will strengthen the democratic processes that hold the EU together. We must push back against negative and divisive narratives and champion EU rights and values, including in the UK, where Theresa May has vowed to take us out of the Charter of Fundamental Rights if we Brexit. Shame on her for attacking our hard won rights. The EU is a beacon for many around the world who live under oppression, and we must nourish it.

name: Silvia Costa (S&D).
text: – Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, I must thank the rapporteurs for this work, which have done two committees together, or rather three committees, because I believe that in the current European context this programme, which brings together three current programmes, has a precise meaning, and we have wanted a great deal in the Committee on Culture – and I thank Mrs Guillaume for this – that the dimension of citizenship construction should not be lost. , placing this title next to rights, values, equality. Because we believe that this visibility of the specific programme, with dedicated resources, specific actions, very well known, among other things, by students, associations, municipalities, twinning and the many citizenship projects practiced in Europe, must be precisely identified in the context of the new programme, which is a merging programme.  It is important that what was a people's Europe, and which will now find its place in the new programme, should remain linked to two areas of action, that of the memory to be shared, and we have talked about it even earlier, the sharing of a historical approach, with a critical eye, but with an ability to create this basis of common history and the understanding by citizens of the reasons for being , the values and history of European integration. This is against racism, hatred and all the different forms of nationalism and extremism that Europe is going through.  That is why we want the Active Citizenship strand to be visible, for additional resources that we have asked for and we hope that the whole Parliament will defend them and to build citizenship competences, including through formal, non-formal and informal education actions.  But I believe that an opportunity has also been seizing, and I will close, and that is that we also strongly wanted to include the theme of intercultural and interreligious dialogue, because this dimension also builds a common feeling and a prospect of European fraternity.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, EUR 1 billion from the programme will be given to support the values of the Union, EUR 474 million for equality and rights, EUR 500 million for the activities of citizens. All this with the aim of strengthening the citizens themselves. I believe that the best support for citizens is, first of all, to create conditions for work, because that is the only way to have dignity. For work, the European Union has given only EUR 6 billion to the so-called 'Youth Guarantees'. I see that the amount that will be allocated, EUR 2 billion to NGOs, will give many NGOs the opportunity to do the so-called 'party', as they did with the funds allocated to migration. That's why there has to be attention. From then on, I believe that the funds should go to universities, schools, municipalities, the Regions and, of course, be given to tackling hatred against Christians. I should point out that in 2017 there were 556 attacks in Greece, 94% against the Greek Orthodox Church. I therefore consider it to be a serious matter which must be included in this programme so that it is not unilateral.

name: Γεώργιος Επιτήδειος (NI).
text: Mr President, at a time when all the countries of the European Union are suffering from economic problems and their peoples are suffering, the european Union's leadership has decided to create and finance the Rights and Values programme. The report makes proposals to allocate billions of euros to promote and protect democracy, equality, the rule of law and to tackle all forms of violence. One must point out, however, in these enlightened brains of the European Union that democracy, love for equality, values and respect for all kinds of rights are the result of conscience and intellectual culture and not the object of a profit-making enterprise. As an elected representative of the Greek people, I do not think I have the right to tolerate and consent to the implementation of this of wasting European taxpayers' money from the European Union, which has condemned my compatriots to austerity and impoverishment. That is why I will not support the report and I call on those who feel they have a responsibility to those who honoured them with their vote to do the same.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I strongly support this proposal because I believe that there is a need to raise awareness of European values. I know from my own experience in the Czech Republic that the particular emphasis on education, awareness of the European Union among young people is an extremely important thing.  Many young people simply do not have information about what the European Union brings, and then, under the influence of various disinformation campaigns, do not see the European Union as a free voluntary association of countries that profess the values of freedom, democracy and human rights. As part of my work, I go to schools and I have to say that I am sometimes very sad to see the ignorance of some young people about what the European Union entails. So I also welcome the increase in the money for this programme and consider this proposal to be extremely important and beneficial.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, this debate has shown the importance that you place on the promotion of rights and values, and the support for the future rights and values programmes proposed by the Commission. It was a very interesting debate, also at that moment when we heard different interpretations of the word equality. I will confess to you about one moment in my history in this position as Commissioner responsible for fundamental rights in Europe. When I came to the Commission I heard that we have to promote equality. I lived half my life under a regime which imposed equality. Equality in the sense that Ms Šojdrová spoke about – in the sense of uniformity.  I lived in a society where we didn’t see people in wheelchairs. I lived in a society where I don’t remember seeing mentally handicapped people. They were hidden. They were hidden somewhere so that they were not seen because they were not equal, ideal, socialist people. That’s why I had to clarify for myself and with my colleagues that we speak about equality before the law. We speak about the principle that we all have the same rights and obligations and that we also have a duty to protect the weak ones in the sense of fighting against any kind of discrimination. At the same time I find it very important that we are promoting diversity, plurality, dialogue and active citizens. What I mean by dialogue – you know that I’m also responsible for the gender equality agenda, I fight for the ratification of the Istanbul Convention, and there is a very strong rejection from the side of the churches – I invited the churches for a dialogue. I wanted to hear their arguments. I think that this is also our duty, to listen to other opinions and I don’t see anyone here who would like to use this funding for silencing somebody who has a different opinion.  Yes, we have some limits on the freedom of speech. You might say we are silencing some people. Yes, I will always fight for silencing people who call for violence and the killing of people, especially where it is obvious and very well seen, i.e. on the Internet and social media.  That’s why we are pushing for digital companies to delete hate speech which contains this definition, that is to say hate speech which has the potential to incite violence in real life, that they delete it from the networks.  I will never defend the freedom of expression of people who call for killing, and we have started to relativise these things, and this is dangerous. That’s why we need to promote civil society and dialogue so that the people themselves define what’s still okay and what should not be tolerated. It should not be the politicians only who define these things. We need active society.  That’s why I am glad that we have this programme, which I believe will be used as a smart funding programme to promote reasonable good projects to help society to increase tolerance and common understanding – diversity, plurality, dialogue and so on – and I am afraid that we will also have to find other ways of helping society to flourish and democracy to develop as a dialogue of people.  I mentioned the IT sphere. The Internet is also a fantastic instrument for developing democracy and dialogue. I will always be for promoting technologies for the benefit of society, but as we all know this is the sphere which is also abused for fuelling hatred, for increasing intolerance, for attacks against people. At the end of January I will get a report from IT companies which will inform me about something which I call a ‘map of hatred in the EU’. On the list there is the menu of usual suspects. There are minorities. There are, yes, also the churches, the religious people who openly express their religious views, including Christians. There are gays and lesbians, there are journalists, there are politicians, in some countries there are judges, and I think that this is also one of the reasons why we have every day to think about names like Jo Cox, Pavel Adamovich, Daphne Caruana Galizia and Ján Kuciak. How many others will become victims of this increased hatred? I am afraid that if we do not stop it this will go further.  So how to face this new situation? We spoke about funding. I am convinced that if we manage to promote the idea of a digital tax, we should use part of this money for education – not propaganda but education – objective informing about our history, for working with the young generation so that they are able to apply critical thinking to be able to work with the information. I am sure that if we are promoting the technologies on one side we have to use the benefit of it and maybe the future possible own source of the EU, which might be a digital tax, for better education and for better developing the values which we speak about. I think that this is the way we will have to go anyway. (Applause)

name: Bodil Valero
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to begin by congratulating Mr I would like to begin by thanking all those who have spoken on this issue, both those who agree that this is an important programme and those who do not. I would also like to thank the Commission for the good cooperation that we have had throughout this time that we have developed this programme. We have received very good technical help to find solutions to the problems we have seen. I am a little concerned when I first hear – which is very positive – that the Commissioner says: 'Yes, a lot of money is needed for this', but then concludes by saying: 'With less we can do more'. For us, it is important that there is actually a budget for everyone, for the whole programme. Firstly, for the existing programmes – which we also want to raise; we will not be able to agree to the reduction of existing programmes, firstly – on the one hand, properly with the new pillar, the one that deals specifically with rights and values, more closely linked to Article 2. If we try to get everything under the same programme, under the same pillar, we will not have the impact that we hope we will have with this programme. It is extremely important; it is a strong signal from us that we need, on the one hand, a lot of money and, on the other hand, we need to have the new pillar separately, not embedded in the others. When it comes to money, it is also the case that you talked about whether you can take it from maybe other parts or something in the Social Fund and something else. When it comes to issues such as this – rights and values, or social issues – it is often very difficult to add this money, for the Member States to agree to the funds. When it comes to the European Defence Fund, there has been no problem in getting EUR 13 billion. That is a considerable sum that will be borne by taxpayers. However, if we are not prepared to actually invest in what is also part of Europe's own security, our internal security, I find that very strange. We need this money, these funds for the programmes, existing programmes, and for the new pillar. That is my very clear message to the Commissioner, and I hope that we will be able to have good discussions. We will soon begin the trilogy meetings and there are some that I think we will have no problem agreeing on. For example, when it comes to making it easier for organizations to apply for funds, etc. There should be no problem. Then there are some major issues that we need to resolve, but I hope that in good discussion we will be able to do so.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 January 2019. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Kinga Gál (PPE)
text: Writing. – According to the European Parliament's Rights and Values programme adopted today, the European Union would make EUR 850 million available to NGOs operating in Europe that are fighting to achieve an open and inclusive society. For me, this means that civilians who support Brussels through open political engagement would receive extra resources, so that NGOs that openly promote immigration are expected to grow through EU funding. It is unacceptable for the European Commission to organise activities for NGOs that it cannot carry out itself without legal authorisation. Thus, in the future, European taxpayers will also finance the openly pro-immigration pseudo-civils that continue to attack Hungary.

name: Csaba Molnár (S&D)
text: Writing. – The European Parliament is facing a historic moment, as two reports scheduled for a vote tomorrow propose a strengthened defence of the EU's core values, which have been crushed by orban's dictatorships. It is also known in European countries that the Orban government is putting a significant part of EU funds in the pockets of their own oligarchs instead of Hungarian citizens, which the European Parliament now intends to put an end to. The new law aims to make the payment of EU funds linked to compliance with rule of law criteria. The other proposal aims to increase EU funding to NGOs promoting democratic development and the rule of law to EUR 1.9 billion, so that European values are also protected and promoted in member states where the government itself threatens it.  As a Hungarian Member, I believe that it is my duty to draw the attention of my fellow Members to the importance of supporting this report, because the Orban government is one of the governments that makes ngos fighting for democracy and human rights impossible to operate with a law that is in violation of EU law. I trust that tomorrow the European Parliament will stand up for the support of civilians, blocking measures taken by illiberal regimes to trample on democracy and the rule of law.

name: Sirpa Pietikäinen (PPE)
text: Written. – The EU must increase resources to safeguard civil and fundamental rights. The Fundamental Rights and Values Programme provides a good framework for this. Resources for the programme must therefore be increased. It is particularly important to halt cuts in subsidies for the fight against violence against women. According to the Charter of Fundamental Rights of the European Union, 'the Union is founded on the indivisible and universal values of human dignity, freedom, equality and solidarity'. Human and fundamental rights belong to everyone everywhere. However, fundamental rights are respected selectively in the Member States. Some Member States have increasingly bracedly attacked them in recent years. Certain fundamental rights, on the other hand, are being blatantly violated in several Member States of the Union. Over the past couple of years, women's rights have met with particular opposition in some EU countries. One of the concerns has been the attempt to undermine women's already acquired sexual and reproductive health rights. More work needs to be done to defend fundamental rights. The European Union and all Member States must urgently ratify the Istanbul Treaty of the Council of Europe, the most comprehensive international agreement to combat violence against women and domestic violence. Thank you.

name: Presidente. –
text: The next item is the report by Rebecca Harms, on behalf of the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy, on the proposal for a Council regulation establishing the programme of assistance for the nuclear decommissioning of the Ignalina nuclear power plant in Lithuania (Ignalina programme) and repealing Regulation (EU) No Council Regulation (EC) No 1369/2013 (COM(2018)0466 - C8-0394/2018 - 2018/0251(NLE)) (A8-0413/2018).

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, shadow rapporteur, Commissioner, I would like to thank the rapporteur for her excellent work and for the work she has done. I would also like to welcome lithuanian citizens, especially the citizens of Visaginas, in case what we are discussing here in Lithuania – and I assume this is to be welcomed. During my visits to Lithuania – in Visaginas and at the Ignalina nuclear power plant – which I have made time and again over the last 15 years, I realised what a difficult decision this had been to agree to the European Union's recommendation to close down Lithuania in the accession negotiations with the European Union. However, I would also like to say that, to date, I find this decision extremely right and reasonable, because the safety deficiencies inherent in these Soviet RBMK reactors – the graphite-moderated reactors – were not well managed, unlike by decommissioning. As correct as this decommissioning decision has been for me, it was also right that the decision to close it off prematurely, which was initiated by pressure from Brussels, was linked to the European Union's commitment not to pass on the burden of decommissioning to Lithuania – to the small country of Lithuania – that these largest RBMK reactors ever built. , under pressure from Moscow on what the Lithuanians say was occupied territory at the time. Today we are talking about the reliability of the European Union's promise to bear these burdens of decommissioning. I am very pleased that the majority of the European Parliament has agreed to my proposal to raise the originally proposed sum for the next MFF, the next seven-year budget of the European Union, not to the proposed level, but to EUR 780 million. The aim of this financing is to ensure that the dismantling of block 1 and block 2 of the two reactors can begin in 2026 and 2027 respectively. It is also important in our decision today, which we will vote on tomorrow, that the relationship between Lithuania's own contribution and the participation of the European Union should be anchored at the level it is today. In my opinion, the management of the decommissioning is in very good hands in Ignalina – I have visited the plant regularly. In my opinion, the prerequisites for dealing re-encumbeourfully with the risks of this decommissioning, but also for a responsible and transparent approach to finances, are really guaranteed. Lithuania has now made a full decision to phase out nuclear energy. That, too, should be clear to us. I believe that this must not only be acknowledged, but I believe that the decisions we are taking today on Ignalina and on decommissioning must be combined with a consistent commitment against the construction of the new Ostrowets nuclear power station on the territory of Belarus. Almost within sight of Vilnius, a high-risk construction of a nuclear power plant is being pursued there, in my opinion. It's almost done. The European stress test carried out for Ostrowets has identified risks that we do not know how we will actually get to grips with them. Retrofitting, for example, is hard to imagine in a plant that says it is not designed for earthquake risks in the region. In the context of the decision on reliability in the financing of decommissioning, I also call for reliability in defending Lithuania's security interests against nuclear risks to Belarus.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, let me thank the rapporteur, Ms Harms, for her introductory remarks and the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy (ITRE) for its report, which was adopted on 21 November 2018. The Commission is grateful for the debate today and welcomes the vote on the other decommissioning report which took place earlier today. Let me say a few words on the most important points. The safety of European citizens is of the utmost importance to us all, and the contributions of the Members of this Parliament show your attachment to this principle. It requires the application of the highest safety standards, of transparency on risks and costs, and of the immediate decommissioning of nuclear liabilities so as not to transfer this burden to the next generations. The Ignalina programme is contributing to a substantial decrease in the level of radiological hazard and risk to the general public, as the nuclear fuel is now being transferred out of the reactor and the cooling pools into a safe dry storage facility. Remarkable progress has been achieved in the dismantling of huge installations and the processing of radioactive waste. This would not have been possible without longstanding financial support from the European Union that started already in 2001, and in the pre—accession stage in Lithuania. At that time, the European Union required Lithuania to close its only nuclear power plant – a bigger version of the Chernobyl model – and made a commitment to provide financial assistance to mitigate the consequences. Funding the decommissioning of Ignalina is a matter of solidarity with Lithuania, and the Commission is strongly attached to this principle. By the end of 2020, the Union will have provided nearly EUR 1.9 billion of financial assistance, and the Commission proposal provides for the continuation of appropriate support in the future. Based on the Ignalina detailed decommissioning plan, the Commission proposal makes it possible to start dismantling the nuclear reactor core element. More importantly, and in line with recommendations made by the Court of Auditors, it sets a maximum level of EU co—financing, which will remove uncertainties and increase ownership of the project by the beneficiary. This project is a first—of—a—kind endeavour on an unprecedented scale and will require the involvement of the best and brightest nuclear specialists. This is reflected by the higher priority given to the financing of those activities. It will generate highly relevant experience and know—how that can be of benefit to other projects in the Union and will result in increased levels of safety within the EU. It is in sharing what we know and showing solidarity that the Union brings the highest added value to its citizens.

name: Werner Langen
text: Mr President, i.e. the Group of the European People's Party (Christian Democrats) and European Democrats Mr President, I would like to thank the First of all, I would like to thank the rapporteur. We fought hard in the Committee on Industry, Research and Energy over funding, and in the end we reached an agreement by 61 votes in favour and 2 against. But Lithuania needs help, that is quite clear. As part of the accession negotiations, they had to commit themselves to decommissioning these two nuclear power stations. The Commissioner has just said that 1.9 billion has already been spent. We are now talking about a further EUR 780 million, and the funding gap, particularly with regard to final disposal, has been estimated by the Court of Auditors at a further EUR 1.6 billion. It is therefore a project of more than EUR 5 to 6 billion that the EU must shoulder. We have agreed that we want to help Lithuania, under economically justifiable conditions, of course. But, Commissioner, I have to reprimand the Commission. The Commission has proposed 552 million for the same programme, Lithuania has asked for 780 million. In the end, we agreed on the Lithuanian value because the Commission officials were not able to provide a reasonable calculation of the actual costs. And I remain in this discussion, because in the end the rapporteur and I, as shadow rapporteur, negotiated with Commissioner Oettinger and with the Lithuanian Energy Minister, and a compromise should be worked out before the vote in Parliament. It is not yet available. That is why we will vote in favour of the Harms report, but the outstanding issues remain.

name: Петър Курумбашев
text: on behalf of the S&D Group– Mr President, let me point out that our proposal also includes funding which, instead of the 80% co-financing proposed by the Commission, should be at 86%. Let me express my gratitude, both to the Rapporteur-general, Mrs Harmes, and to Mr Werner Langen, because we have had excellent joint work, both with regard to the dossier for Lithuania and to the dossier for Bulgaria, Slovakia and the European Union Joint Research Centre.  I would like to highlight the proposal for the Joint Research Centre to disseminate in the future the knowledge acquired in the decommissioning process of nuclear facilities. I would also like to note the pain that there was in the societies in these countries when they were adopted – in Bulgaria, Slovakia and Lithuania – and also to note that we want the Commission and the Council to take a serious note of the increased amount we offer from EUR 780 million, as there is certainly one thing that cannot be compromised , namely nuclear safety.

name: Valdemar Tomaševski
text: on behalf of the ECR Group. – Mr President, today we are debating a Council of Europe regulation on increasing funds for the safe closure of the Ignalina nuclear power plant. Tai̶ obvious, and help for Lithuania is essential if we are to maintain the highest security standards. The closure of a nuclear power plant is a particular challenge for Europe's nuclear safety, in particular with regard to the size of the installation and the technical characteristics of the reactors. The Ignalina power plant operates two reactors of the same kind as Chernobyl. The decommissioning programme is approaching the climax of the plant, i.e. the liquidation of graphite reactors. This is an irreversible operation. The lack of sufficient funds would put an end to the dismantling process, which would greatly increase the costs of the whole project and jeopardise Europe's nuclear security. The task of safe and effective closure of this instrument far exceeds Lithuania's financial capabilities. It is also due to the fact that the country incurs additional costs associated with the closure of the power plant, which was the largest employer in the region. As a result, the income of the population in Visaginas has decreased, and the unemployment rate is highest in the country. How to accept that burden on the municipal budget? For its part, the Community has undertaken to support the decommissioning programme and its consequences and therefore specific financial assistance should be approved for Lithuania.

name: Bronis Ropė
text: on behalf of the Verts/ALE Group. - Thank you, Mr President. – (DE) Mr President, Commissioner, honourable colleagues, I would like to thank once again my good colleague from the Greens, Rebecca Harms. It is very fortunate that parliament's report on the financing of ignalina nuclear finance has been entrusted precisely to it, as it is one of the strongest members of the European Parliament on European Union and nuclear energy. In particular, I am pleased that the ITRE Committee did not support the Commission's proposal that the European contribution to the Ignalina programme would decrease and Lithuania would increase. The Accession Treaty does not provide for Lithuania's compulsory financing contribution. Today, the country contributes 14% voluntarily to the closures, which is a huge financial burden for Lithuania. It is also to be welcomed that the ITRE Committee has approved the closure of the Ignalina nuclear power plant by more than two hundred million euro in the amount covered by the Commission's proposal. Increased funding is a necessary assessment of the cost of work based on detailed estimates approved by international experts. In addition, Lithuania still has a duty to solve the region's social and demographic problems in addition to the co-financing of the closure works. As long-time mayor of Ignalina district, I am pleased that the report recalls Lithuania's commitment to pay due attention to the region's unemployment, population income, public service accessibility and other social problems. Finally, I would like to point out to my colleagues that tomorrow's vote on this report is a sign of citizens' trust, which sends an important signal of solidarity to our citizens and shows that the European Union is a responsible, credible partner who delivers on its promises.

name: Antanas Guoga (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I would like to thank the rapporteur for the wonderful job done by the whole team. I think it was very important to come to this conclusion and decision to increase our financing from the reduced amount the Commission unfortunately proposed. The highest rate of support for the EU has been shown by Lithuania. I hope that the Commission considers that and sorts out the financing so that this nasty reactor is closed down. It’s the same type as the Chernobyl one, which blew up. So let’s make sure we have the funding. Let’s make sure that the Commission helps and sorts this out and we can progress, because the people are really expecting it. We have suffered a lot of hardship due of the closure, and the country is ready to finance what it can afford –14% – but I am expecting the Commission to support us here.

name: Zigmantas Balčytis (S&D).
text: – Mr President, mr President, I would like to – (DE) Mr President, I really, myself, very sincerely want to thank the rapporteur for this report, Rebecca Harms, as well as my group colleague and shadow rapporteur, Peter Kouroumbashev, and colleagues of the other groups who have very clearly understood and supported the situation in Lithuania by closing the Ignalina nuclear power plant and securing the European Union's financial commitments in the next financial perspective. The closure of this power plant is not only a concern of Lithuania, but a common burden of responsibility for adequate financing and safe final decommissioning. The Lithuanian people trusted the European Union and its commitments in the fourth protocol of the Accession Treaty, which were approved in a referendum. The Commission's doubts about further financing of the European Union would therefore be contrary to its own commitments. I am pleased that the European Parliament strongly and unanimously supports Lithuania's position and its efforts to safely close down the most technically complex and one of the largest nuclear power plants, not only in Europe, but also in the world.

name: Владимир Уручев (PPE).
text: – Mr President, Commissioner, I welcome the regulation and the good amendments made by the rapporteur, Mrs Harmes, to continue the European Union's support for the Ignalina NPP decommissioning programme. The proposed EUR 780 million for the next period represents adequate funding for the programme, which is in line with expert opinion and meets realistic timetables for the implementation of the huge volume of activities. It is important to stress that due to insufficient funding, disruption of operations at a complex stage of disposal and dismantling of the two reactors should not be allowed in order to prevent risks to nuclear safety and radiological hazards to the region and to the whole of Europe. I do not share the view that greater co-financing by the Member State would lead to a more efficient use of the funds. I support maintaining the current allocation of funding from the European Union and Lithuania to 86% and 14% respectively. Any increase in co-financing would represent a significant financial burden for the country. It is not fair to the population and would undermine the reputation of the European Union in fulfilling its commitments to Lithuania for the decommissioning of Ignalina Nuclear Power Plant.

name: Ingeborg Gräßle (PPE).
text: Mr President, I would like to thank the The Committee on Budgetary Control visited all three nuclear power plants and dealt with decommissioning, most recently Ignalina in June 2018 – I was there twice. I understand that all colleagues from the countries concerned have a great interest in further funds for decommissioning. Commissioner, the Commission has made it extremely easy on this issue, and the ITRE Committee has endorsed the extremely simple one. I don't think that's a good thing. In 2009, an international feasibility study was carried out for alternatives to decommissioning after the fuel rods were removed from the reactor. Two international companies have won this. In 2010, under pressure from the Lithuanian authorities and with the commission's approval, this call for tenders was cancelled and handed over to Ignalina INPP as in-house work, and it was over. All I can say is that Ignalina will remain a nuclear site for the long term and for decades, centuries. It would have been essential to examine alternatives there, instead of creating a green meadow for a lot of money, which would not benefit anyone afterwards.

name: Jiří Pospíšil (PPE).
text: – Mr President, I have studied the whole case and I believe that Lithuania's demands are justified and that, above all, we should maintain the funding ratio, that is, 14% by Lithuania. If we change this ratio, I believe that it can create a negative picture of the European Union in the region, but also in the whole country, and we really cannot afford that.  I myself see how, in some postcommunist states, the European Union has recently been viewed relatively negatively, and the political dimension of the whole case is, in my view, more important than whether we give EUR 200 million more or less. So I am very much asking, in the final decision, let us see that lithuania continues to be perceived as the European Union stands by its commitments on Ignalina and that it does not change the rules on the go when removing this power plant.

name: Νότης Μαριάς (ECR).
text: Mr President, it is important to dismantle the nuclear power plant in Ignalina because, as has been said, old reactors of the same type as those in Chernobyl. After all, this has already been done in Slovakia. There is also a procedure for the corresponding nuclear power plant in Bulgaria in Kozlodoui, for which I read that the storage of radioactive materials will take place in Bulgaria. The question is: where will the radioactive materials from the dismantling of the plant in Lithuania be stored? Maybe in Kosovo, maybe in Skopje? We want an answer, because it is also important where radioactive waste is stored. From then on, I agree with Mrs Harms' comments on existing nuclear power plants. To say that the nuclear power plant in Akkuyu, Turkey, is now dangerous, and the European Union must do something about it. Let us not show up again after years here and the European Union will pay the cost of dismantling the nuclear power plant in Akkuyu.

name: Věra Jourová
text: Member of the Commission. – Mr President, I would like to thank the honourable Members very much for their valuable comments. Since 2001, the European Union has consistently contributed support for the decommissioning of Ignalina. The European Union is committed to meeting its commitment towards Lithuania, as provided for in Lithuania’s accession treaty. The decommissioning plan established by Lithuania, and agreed by the Commission, has scheduled activities until 2038, when all pre-existing installations will have been removed and the radioactive waste safely stored or disposed of. Based on that schedule, the Commission proposal covers all the needs for the key dismantling projects to be started up to 2027. As for your calls for increasing the budget, I cannot of course promise you anything. I don’t have the power to do so from my colleagues, but I will inform them of the core outcomes of this debate.  Finally, I want to thank Parliament for the great commitment to advancing this Multiannual Financial Framework package as much as possible.

name: Rebecca Harms
text: Rapporteur. Mr President, I would like to thank the Perhaps a few words briefly to my colleague Mrs Gräßle: the safe inclusion of nuclear power stations in decommissioning can be an alternative to the objective of restoring the green field as quickly as possible. But I would not advise against promoting rapid dismantling and greenfield everywhere in Germany, then proposing, so to speak, the method of shifting on the timeline for other countries. I believe that there are really good reasons for dismantling in Lithuania. I would like to thank the Commissioner for saying that, in fact, as Mr Langen said, there has now been an arbitrary change of strategy on the part of the Commission in the current debate with regard to funding. For me, it became very clear in the visits to Lithuania that the issue is also a question of real reliability, of trust between Lithuania and the European Commission. I make this appeal not only to you, but also to the Council. After all, it will not be the Commission alone, but it will also be the Council that will have to prove its reliability to the Lithuanians. Thank you for your attention and thank all the shadow rapporteurs once again.

name: Presidente. –
text: The debate is closed. The vote will take place on Thursday, 17 January 2019. Written declarations (Rule 162)

name: Ignazio Corrao (EFDD)
text: in writing. The programme of assistance with nuclear decommissioning aims to support Lithuania in the decommissioning of a nuclear power plant in Ignalina. The assistance specifically covers all radio safety issues related to decommissioning, which are fundamental from the point of view of the nuclear safety of the region. The programme is expected to be completed by 2038 and substantial sums are still needed to address the remaining radiosecurity problems related to the decommissioning of the plant. This is why the rapporteur has proposed an increase in the programme's budget totalling EUR 780 million, compared with the EUR 552 million set by the Commission for the period 2021-2027. The Union's financial support for this process will help to ensure effective and safe decommissioning, while increasing the Union's credibility in promoting nuclear safety. Furthermore, the funding and know-how acquired by Lithuania and all the parties involved could be useful and preparatory for the development of expertise in the field of future decommissioning.

name: Carolina Punset (ALDE)
text: in writing. – Nothing should be objected to the significant sum of money, close to EUR 800 million, which will cost the EU the dismantling of nuclear reactors at the Ignalina plant, covered by Lithuania's accession treaty to the Union. However, it seems to us that this report is a great opportunity to reflect on the dismantling costs arising from the use of nuclear energy. In the EU, there are more than 90 fully stationary and un dismantled reactors and our nuclear park is one of the oldest in the world, with 75% of its power plants with more than 30 years of operation and 15% with more than 40. With so many power stations closed and given the inaction of States to eliminate facilities stopped, the Commission should take action on the matter and force States to require the owners of the plants to dismantle these pockets of potential radioactive contamination.
